Answer: ...Happy birthday, Michael.

Question: Am I on camera?
Answer: Nope. Totally private. You can say whatever is in your heart. [Jan hangs up]

Question: Man, I'm so sorry. When do you find out?
Answer: They said this afternoon. They're waiting on a second opinion.

Question: Second opinion on what?
Answer: Um, I might have skin cancer.

Question: Who brought in donuts?
Answer: Somebody got donuts for my birthday!

Question: Are you serious?
Answer: Mmm.

Question: Here we go. Ohhhkay, this is great! [giggles] Thank you my friends, she is perfect! Ahhh, Dwight, may I have your chair please? And, um, some singles, if you will! Allllright. Nnnnn-dink! [puts single into delivery woman's pocket, giggles] Okay, um, alright. This has arms. Is that gonna be a... is that alright?
Answer: Uh... s-sure.

Question: [eating donuts while Dwight plays the recorder] Stop it. Stop! What is that?
Answer: It's 'For the Longest Time,' by William Joel. It's you favorite song.

Question: When does he hear?
Answer: Sometime today.

Question: What?
Answer: Listen up everyone! It is 11:23 exactly, the exact moment when you emerged from your mother's vaginal canal, so... huh?! Right, have a seat. Please.

Question: Listen up everyone! It is 11:23 exactly, the exact moment when you emerged from your mother's vaginal canal, so... huh?! Right, have a seat. Please.
Answer: [grinning] Ohhh, God.

Question: ...I feel like we should go get Kevin something. Do you think we can sneak out of here?
Answer: Maybe, but... we're gonna need somebody to create a diversion, and...

Question: On three, we're going to hoist away! Ready?
Answer: Okay.

Question: F. Alright, what's the damage?
Answer: Uh, thirty-nine sixty.

Question: Why tip someone for a job I'm capable of doing myself? I can deliver food. I can drive a taxi. I can, and do, cut my own hair. I did, however, tip my urologist, because... I am unable to pulverize my own kidney stones.
Answer: Here they come.

Question: What is this?
Answer: Uh, bologna, tomato and ketchup.

Question: These are all the same?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Bologna? I don't eat bologna.
Answer: Well, then just have the tomato and ketchup. Still good.

Question: [making peanut butter and jelly sandwich] Someone ate three feet of that thing?
Answer: Hell, yeah. Save room for ice cream cake.

Question: What about that meeting... later... to discuss finances?
Answer: Yes... [whispering] but don't expect any cookie.

Question: [whispering] But what if i'm hungry?
Answer: [whispering]

Question: [puts fabric softener into cart] ...What?
Answer: You use fabric softener?

Question: You use fabric softener?
Answer: Yeah, you don't?

Question: Yeah, you don't?
Answer: No, I do.

Question: Hello? Hey.
Answer: Kevin? Respect the birthday please.

Question: Kevin? Respect the birthday please.
Answer: No, um, no not yet. I will. Bye. [hangs up] It was just Stacy.

Question: Are you done? ...Good. Okay.
Answer: Here we go. Make a wish.

Question: Okay. Well, when she comes back we'll do it again. [notices Meredith hugging Kevin] Hello, what about the birthday boy? Haven't had a hug all day.
Answer: No one cares about your birthday. Kevin's waiting to hear if he has skin cancer.

Question: You dare me? How old are you?
Answer: Just... quit stalling.

Question: [loudspeaker] Jim Halpert? Price check on fabric softener, the kind that gives you...
Answer: Ma'am? Please don't touch that. That is not a toy.

Question: Ma'am? Please don't touch that. That is not a toy.
Answer: Oh I'm sorry. I'm sorry.

Question: How old are you?
Answer: I hate you.

Question: [to Kevin] Honestly, is there any way you can get on your fiancee's plan? Our health plan is s... just... it's terrible.
Answer: There you are. Good news. Did some research. It turns out that 98% of people with skin cancer fully recover.

Question: Why are you here? I didn't even invite you to my birthday party.
Answer: I work here.

Question: Where have you been? And don't say the bathroom, 'cause I kicked in all the stalls.
Answer: Well that's an invasion of privacy, so, I'm going to tell Michael.

Question: Is this trip related in any way to your... birthday?
Answer: How dare you sir. You are gross.

Question: No, it's alright. It's already up. Just leave it. Where's Kevin? Come on! Let's get our skate on!
Answer: Don't be scared! You're good! You're good!

Question: Think you can let go?
Answer: No. [laughs]

Question: Who is that?
Answer: Is that Michael?

Question: Is that Michael?
Answer: Yeah, I've been pretty much skating my whole life. I thought about playing in the NHL, but, you're on the road so much. You got no time to spend with your wife and kids. And I really want a wife and kids.

Question: Hey Pam, all this stuff with Kevin... um, it's pretty scary. And I'm thinking that uh, next time you're in the shower, you should check yourself out. You know, give yourself an exam. Those things are like ticking time bags. Alright? Think about it.
Answer: ...It's something to think about.

Question: I can't relax about it, you know?
Answer: Kevin. You heard anything yet?

Question: Kevin. You heard anything yet?
Answer: No, not yet.

Question: Michael?
Answer: Yeah. Carol? She sold me my condo! Hey! What, is this place on the market? Or...

Question: Yeah. Carol? She sold me my condo! Hey! What, is this place on the market? Or...
Answer: Uhh, no, I... don't just sell real estate. Uh, my daughter has a skating lesson.

Question: Oh, these... all your kids?
Answer: No just the front two.

Question: Oh, hey guys. Whats up? You wanna go for a ride? Is that okay?
Answer: Sure.

Question: Cool. Alright. Grab on. Here we go. Ready? Hang on tight. Alright. We are moving. We are reaaallly mooovin' now!
Answer: Push. Good! That's great. You got it. [Kevin's phone rings] Excuse me.

Question: Hello? Yeah okay. Alright. Okay, I will, thanks. [hangs up] It was negative.
Answer: Oh... God... [stomps] God! [throws hockey stick and yellow paper bracelet down] We're gonna beat this, okay? We're gonna... come here [hugs Kevin].

Question: Oh... God... [stomps] God! [throws hockey stick and yellow paper bracelet down] We're gonna beat this, okay? We're gonna... come here [hugs Kevin].
Answer: Well, apparently in the medicine community, negative means good. Which makes absolutely no sense. In the real world community, that would... be... chaos.

Question: Okay, who's this from? Wowwwee, look at that! Jersey!
Answer: Turn it around. Turn it around.

Question: Michael?
Answer: Yeah.

Question: That's not how I taught you, right? [singing] My hump, my hump, my lovely lady lump Check it out [Dwight imitating drumbeat]
Answer: Michael's birthday is hard for me because he gets very excited. But he's also under a lot of pressure, which builds up until he's ready to explode. As his right-hand man, it's my job to release that pressure so that he can enjoy himself, if only for a moment.

Question: Can you please stop staring at me? [Dwight continues to stare and then walks away]
Answer: To think that a man's skin could turn on him. It's brilliant, 'cause you'd never expect it. Most people think of their skin as an ally. [scoffs] Makes me rethink having skin at all.

Question: Let's go over some of the symptoms of marijuana use, shall we?  You tell me who this sounds like: slow moving, inattentive, dull, constantly snacking, shows a lack of motivation.
Answer: [nods] Hey...

Question: And the guys are saying, chug, chug, chug, but I'm so small and all I'd eaten that day was one of those Auntie Anne pretzels from the food court so I said 'Is it okay if I sip it?' and they said no, but Ryan seemed cool either way.
Answer: Stop! This is not Kelly Kapoor story hour.  Illegal drugs were consumed on company property, okay? Your ass is on the line, mister!  My ass is is on the line!  Now I'm going to ask you again.  What time did you go home last night?

Question: Stop! This is not Kelly Kapoor story hour.  Illegal drugs were consumed on company property, okay? Your ass is on the line, mister!  My ass is is on the line!  Now I'm going to ask you again.  What time did you go home last night?
Answer: Six.

Question: What's the hard way?
Answer: I go down to the police station on my lunch break. I tell a police officer, I know several, what I suspect you may have in your car. He requests a hearing from a judge and obtains a search warrant, once he has said warrant, he will drive over here, and make you give him the keys to your car, and you will have to obey him.

Question: Ry, is he bugging you? Dwight, dude, you gotta take a chill pill, man. It was one joint in the parking lot. You know, you're totally harshing the office mellow.
Answer: I can't stop this investigation. It is my job.

Question: Why don't you just cool it, cool it Dwight, please, God! [to Jim] Dude, where's my office? [Jim quietly laughs] I totally lost it, 'cause I was half-baked. Smokin' doobies. Doobie brothers, I was smokin' doobies with my brothers. Peace out, Seacrest!
Answer: Well, your office is behind you.

Question: Thanks. M-m-munchies. Who wants some munchies?
Answer: I don't think Michael's ever done drugs. I don't know if anyone has ever offered him any.

Question: Oscar visited Mexico when he was five to attend his great-grandmother's funeral. What does that mean to a United States law enforcement officer? He's a potential drug mule.
Answer: Have you ever taken any illegal drugs?

Question: Have you ever taken any illegal drugs?
Answer: No, I have not.

Question: Do you think it's possible that maybe you could have had some drugs in your system without you knowing about it?
Answer: What are you implying?

Question: What are you implying?
Answer: Have you ever... pooped... a balloon?

Question: Have you ever... pooped... a balloon?
Answer: Okay. I'm done with this.

Question: Do you know what this is? [pushing a photo toward her]
Answer: Yes, it's marijuana.

Question: How do you know that?
Answer: It's labeled.

Question: Well, how could you, if it just erased your memory?
Answer: That's not how it works.

Question: Now how do you know how it works?
Answer: Knock it off, okay, I'm interviewing you.

Question: No! You said that I'd be conducting the interview when I walked in here. Now exactly how much pot did you smoke?
Answer: [opens eyes wide in total surprise]

Question: Oh, um...[mimicking Stanley] Why do you keep CC'ing me on things that have nothing to do with me?  [Pam and Oscar laugh, Stanley walks in, and Oscar leaves quickly]
Answer: Is that supposed to be me?

Question: Is that supposed to be me?
Answer: Oh, hey Stanley. Uh, I was just doing an impression.

Question: Sold out? That has never happened in the history of jinx.
Answer: [mouths] C'mon!

Question: Where were you yesterday after work?
Answer: [smiles knowingly]

Question: Uh-oh. Uh-oh. Who's he calling?  Ratting somebody out.  Narc!  Narc!  Kevin?
Answer: That is so good, Michael

Question: Remember the narc bit? [laughs] Uh-oh, who's in trouble?
Answer: Attention everyone.  Drug testers are coming in a couple of hours to test everyone's urine.

Question: Waa... what? What are you talking about?
Answer: Company policy. If drugs are found on the premises there is automatic drug testing conducted within twenty-four hours.

Question: Is that true, Toby?
Answer: Oh, when you sign your job application you agree to comply with random drug testing.

Question: Kevin, what prescription drugs are you taking, besides Rogaine?
Answer: I'm not taking Rogaine.

Question: Angela, what about you?
Answer: I don't take any prescription drugs.

Question: Hey guys, what's going on?
Answer: We're having the best conversation.  [Jim, eyes wide, shakes his head, no]

Question: Oh, okay.  Well, Michael wants to see everyone in the conference room. [Jim shakes his head. Seems relieved to be getting away from Kelly] But you know what? We have a few minutes so you guys should definitely finish up your conversation. [Jim nods his head as if to say, 'Gee, thanks, Pam.']
Answer: So, I was looking so hot...

Question: No, uh, no. That was a test.  I was testing you, and you all failed. Miserably. When I said that Dwight was a narc, how many of you defended him?  How many of you said, 'Hey, you know what, he's right? What he's doing is protecting this office from the evils of drugs.'
Answer: Thank you, Michael.

Question: Where did you get these facts?
Answer: Are these facts scaring you, or are they not?

Question: Are these facts scaring you, or are they not?
Answer: They are not.

Question: Do you think that smoking drugs is cool? Do you think that doing alcohol is cool?
Answer: No, I don't. I have a glass of red wine with dinner about once a week.  For the antioxidants.

Question: Okay, enough, enough, enough! I have written down a list of illegal drugs. Take a gander. How many of these are you familiar with?
Answer: Hookah is not an illegal drug, Michael.

Question: Okay, you know what, Toby? Pam, can you take this down? [Pam throws her hands up to indicate she has no notepad] In addition to Toby's urine being tested, I would like to test his blood and his hair.
Answer: You can't do that.

Question: Okay, eeny, meenie, miney, moe, is random.  Okay, you know what? I'm going to need a volunteer to select one of these words and tell us of something tragic that happened in either their lives, or the lives of a loved one.  Yeah, Pam.
Answer: I know that Jim has an amazing story about a relative of his who got caught up in the world of drugs.

Question: Really? [Jim shakes his head no]
Answer: Uh, hmmm.

Question: Jim it's okay. You can t... [Jim looks at Pam and shakes his head, Pam looks at him and gestures for Jim to go up and tell his story] This would be a good place to let it out, Jim. These are people you can trust. These are people who care about you. [Jim shakes his head no] It's okay, just we will not judge you. We are here to not judge you. [Jim stands up] Oh, he's doing it, okay. [Jim looks at Pam] It's okay. [Jim pretends to try, looking teary eyed, shakes his head no, mouths 'I can't' and sits back down. Pam is amazed.] Oh. Okay, are you sure? [Jim shakes his head. Kevin pats his shoulder] That looked like it was going to be good. Alright. [Pam nods in admiration at Jim] Okay, well.
Answer: Wow! He really pulled out the big guns. Fake crying. Did not expect that.

Question: Okay, well Dwight just know that I've been very busy today and I got a lot of work to do and I wasn't planning on going to the bathroom and I don't even know if anything is going to come out, okay? So good. Thank you.
Answer: Hi, Linda. Dwight Schrute, Assistant Regional Manager. You might remember testing my urine a few years back when I was applying to be a volunteer sheriff's deputy.

Question: Oh, right. How are you?
Answer: I'm all better.

Question: What kind of filing?
Answer: Just forget it.  Just the urine.

Question: Like in a cup?
Answer: Yes in a cup, we're not animals, Dwight.

Question: For what purpose?
Answer: It's none of your business.

Question: Are you serious?
Answer: I need clean urine for the lady.

Question: Were you forced to do drugs at this concert?
Answer: No, just look. Look. Just... just fill up the cup.

Question: Do you want to give Michael your urine?
Answer: I want him to have all the urine he needs.

Question: I know that. Don't you think I know that?
Answer: Yeah, we do testing all over the country.

Question: Cool.  Hey, are you guys hiring?
Answer: You want to work at the urinalysis lab?

Question: You want to work at the urinalysis lab?
Answer: Yeah.  Maybe.

Question: What? [Jim shakes his head] Did you want to tell me something? You look like you want to tell me something. [Jim shakes his head no] You look like you have something really important to say and you just can't for some reason. [Jim smiles] Come on, you can tell me. Jim, you can tell me anything. [Jim stops smiling and looks down. Pam wonders what that means]
Answer: I'd like a magazine.

Question: What's wrong? Where's your costume?
Answer: It's a uniform and I turned it in today when I tendered my resignation.

Question: Why?  Wha...
Answer: I took an oath when I was sworn in and I broke that oath today.

Question: How much time do you have left on your break?
Answer: Ten minutes.

Question: Really?
Answer: Yes, sir.

Question: So you wanna? Thanks.
Answer: Dwight K. Schrute, I hereby declare you an honorary voluntary corporal in charge of assisting all activities security.

Question: Thank you, Michael. Very nice. Great. [To Hank]  Can I have a gun?
Answer: No, I don't have a gun.

Question: First of all, Hank, how many orange traffic cones do you have?
Answer: Two.

Question: Wow. What a terrible day to not be able to talk.  Dwight was literally carrying around his own urine and dressed like one of the Village People. Why does he do the things that he does for Michael?  I just don't get it. What is he getting out of that relationship?
Answer: [growling] Nice.

Question: And what did you say?
Answer: I said no.

Question: Last night? Let's see.
Answer: Go ahead. Don't lie.

Question: I won't. It's just that last night is really hard for me to remember because I was just a teensy bit high. Should I have not said that?
Answer: No, no, no. It's okay. Go ahead.

Question: Pam said you had something important to tell me. Is it bad? Am I getting fired? [Jim shakes head 'no'] Why aren't you telling me? It must be bad. They're taking away my kid. I knew it. [Jim waves arms and shakes head 'no'] They're not taking away my kid. Oh.
Answer: Oh, sure, I can definitely help you with that. Okay? Please hold.

Question: Oh, sure, I can definitely help you with that. Okay? Please hold.
Answer: Kelly Kapour. Say your prayers. Let's go. Conference room, pronto. Come on, step it up.

Question: How?
Answer: Exactly. I know. It's amazing.

Question: No, how could it reach the moon? Like, would you make it into a rope, or...
Answer: I have some hemp ropes at my house, they're really strong...

Question: Oh, me? Just one of the gang. Sitting in the back, doodling, not playing attention. Bam! Pow! Surprise! Got you! [Note pad reads, 'Creed -Shifty eyes / Ryan - Dilated pupils / Kelly - Hyperactive'] There's a Volunteer Sheriff's Deputy in your midst, and he is taking names.
Answer: One thing that you need to remember is that there's no way of knowing who's a user, who's an abuser, because we don't know. It could be anybody. Your instinct is to say it's somebody-like Stanley or Oscar...

Question: Excuse me?
Answer: No, no! Your instinct. That... Your gut reaction is to say that, but I don't! That's, that's... Those are instincts that have been created by media and hype. And they are wrong. What I am saying is that you just do not know who drug users are. It may be the person you least suspect. It may be somebody hot, like Pam, or it could be somebody matronly, like Phyllis, but just not me.

Question: No? okay, fine.
Answer: [on the phone] Michael, I'm gonna get going. I really don't think I need to be in this meeting.

Question: Has she been on the phone the whole time?
Answer: Yeah. Sorry you had to hear that. It was a lovers' quarrel.

Question: Okay, let's get personal for a second, shall we?
Answer: The scary thing is, it could have been any one of these people. They all had a motive. To get high.

Question: I don't... Let's just not talk about it, okay?
Answer: [reading from Michael's flier] 'Drugs: Let's not and say we did.' I think Michael was high when he wrote this.

Question: You know, sometimes I wish we just didn't have a conference room. [Kelly laughs] You know? He couldn't do that.
Answer: But then we wouldn't have any meetings.

Question: Oh, my God. Oh, my God, oh, my God. Hello? Yes, I am so, so sorry. Yeah, actually, I don't have that information just yet. Uh-huh. Listen, do you mind if I put you on a brief hold? Okay.
Answer: I look forward to drug testing. I used to get a runner's high, which is why now I swim.

Question: Why would I be worried? I'm not a drug user. I would never abuse my body like that. I mean, they are plenty of other ways to have fun. My body is 100% drug-free.
Answer: [telephone ringing] Dunder Mifflin. This is Pam. Um, hold, please. [to Jim] There's a Brenda on the phone for you. [to Brenda] Just one second, I'll transfer.

Question: Sheriff Pierce? I'm turning in my badge.
Answer: Where sis you get that?

Question: Where sis you get that?
Answer: I got it here.

Question: Right, well... Why don't you give me a couple examples of ways that you've helped us out?
Answer: Oh, God, there are so many. Roadside assistance, breaking up unruly parties, surveillance...

Question: Surveillance?
Answer: Crowd control, directing traffic...

Question: Mace! You... You've been carrying around weapons-grade Mace?
Answer: I've only had to use it once.

Question: So, uh... you found a band for your wedding yet?
Answer: No.

Question: Yeah?
Answer: Yeah, pretty stationery.

Question: Uh, on or off?
Answer: Off.

Question: Oh! What is on your face? Is that a disguise?
Answer: [leaving the room] Excuse me.

Question: I.D. badges are long overdue. Security in this office park is a joke. Last year, I came to work with my spud gun in a duffel bag. I sat at my desk all day, with a rifle that shoots potatoes at 60 pounds per square inch. Can you imagine if I was deranged?
Answer: That's a nice tie.

Question: That is... who makes that?
Answer: Um, I don't...

Question: Do you mind if I wear that for the photo?
Answer: Um...  let's um, let's keep our clothes.

Question: [walking into the Conference room] What's the dealio?
Answer: Just letting Oscar vent a little. We would use the break room, but the photographer's back there today.

Question: What's the problem?
Answer: Angela!

Question: So what, you're having a little spat. I forget, are you guys dating?
Answer: No.

Question: Michael, can I talk to you for a uh, second please?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Yeah?
Answer: These things just have a way of working themselves out.

Question: What do you know about conflict resolution? Your answer to everything is to get divorced. So...
Answer: Okay.

Question: Okay... what?
Answer: That was the right decision for me and my marriage.

Question: Yeah, well... that's not gonna fly here. Because in this office, it is till death do us part... assuming we don't get downsized. [leans over to Pam] Uh, Pam, will you get Angela and meet us in the conference room please?
Answer: [holding up a binder] A mediator's tool chest. Okay, well, before we get started, you should know that are 5 different styles of conflict.[in a comedic voice] My Shaolin temple style defeats your monkey style.

Question: Can we go? I have a lot of work to do.
Answer: No. Okay, this is important. The first style is lose/lose.

Question: What's the next one?
Answer: Just hold on, please! Okay, if we do lose/lose, neither of you gets what you want. Do you understand? You... you would both lose. Now I need to ask you, do you want to pursue a lose/lose negotiation?

Question: Just hold on, please! Okay, if we do lose/lose, neither of you gets what you want. Do you understand? You... you would both lose. Now I need to ask you, do you want to pursue a lose/lose negotiation?
Answer: Can we just skip to whatever number 5 is - win/win or whatever?

Question: Can we just skip to whatever number 5 is - win/win or whatever?
Answer: Win/Win is number four and number five is win/win/win. The important difference here is with win/win/win, we all win. Me too. I win for having successfully mediated a conflict at work.

Question: Come on, seriously, that?
Answer: I don't like looking at it. It's creepy, and in bad taste, and it's just offensive to me. It makes me think of the horrible, frigid stage mothers who force the babies into it. It's kitsch. It's the opposite of art. It destroys art. It destroys souls. This is so much more offensive to me than hardcore porno. I'm talking about the...

Question: How about, I leave it up?
Answer: How 'bout, she takes it down?

Question: How 'bout, she takes it down?
Answer: How about, Angela can keep it up on Tuesdays and Thursdays?

Question: How about, Angela can keep it up on Tuesdays and Thursdays?
Answer: Okay, that is called a compromise. And it is style 3. And it is not ideal. To sum up, win/win - make the poster into a t-shirt, win/lose - take the poster down, compromise - Tuesdays and Thursdays. And the answer is... make the poster into a t-shirt! Win/win.

Question: You solved it?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Are those all the other complains?
Answer: Mmm-Hm.

Question: You can't do that, huh? Huh, ok. Now you and I have a conflict. I order you to give me that file.
Answer: That... [shakes head and places hand over the file]

Question: Okay. [yanks the file away, despite Toby's resistance] There! No more conflict. [looks at the camera] I had to use win/lose on that. It was not pretty. [looks back at Toby] All right... is that it?
Answer: [sighs and pulls out a box under his desk] It's all Dwight's.

Question: Ohh... God. Alright. Why do I have to do everything?
Answer: Are you sure? [looks at Oscar, who is front of the camera, holding the baby poster in front of his chest]

Question: Are you sure? [looks at Oscar, who is front of the camera, holding the baby poster in front of his chest]
Answer: Oh, he's sure. Just shoot.

Question: How many of you have at one time gone to Toby to complain about another employee? [looks at all the employees, most of whom raise their hands] And... did you get what you wanted, or were you merely listened to, you forget about your problem, and you move on? [employees mumble 'merely listen to and forgotten...' ] That is outrageous! I love this place... and it pains me to see all of the negativity festering... [sighs] Okay, today we are going to get everything out of these files and into the open, where it can be resolved. Alright, how about the Phyllis/Angela dispute?
Answer: You already did me.

Question: That's what she said. [Jim mouths these words along with Michael] The thing is, Angela... you are in here an awful lot. You have complained about everybody in the office, except Dwight, which is odd because everyone else has had run ins with Dwight. Toby, by the way, what does 'redacted' mean? There is a file full of complaints in here marked 'redacted'... ?
Answer: Yeah, it just means whoever complained came to me later and withdrew it, so I took their name off.

Question: Whoa.. wha... wait. If someone has a problem with me, why would they withdraw it six months ago?
Answer: [notices Angela's intense concern] Um... let's move on. I volunteer. Did anyone have a problem with me?

Question: [notices Angela's intense concern] Um... let's move on. I volunteer. Did anyone have a problem with me?
Answer: All right, Pamela. Come on down! Let's do it! And [looks through the file]... okay. Just one complaint. Actually, it has been withdrawn. So that is no help to us. Next.

Question: Wait, what did it say?
Answer: Uh... [reading]'Does she have to plan her wedding on office time? Couldn't she do that at home?' [Pam looks Angela an angry look] Who else? Why don't we just warm up first? Warm up emotionally, all right?

Question: Uh... [reading]'Does she have to plan her wedding on office time? Couldn't she do that at home?' [Pam looks Angela an angry look] Who else? Why don't we just warm up first? Warm up emotionally, all right?
Answer: I have this kind of big secret about Angela. And I've been really nice to her... and I haven't told anyone. And what the hell?!

Question: I have this kind of big secret about Angela. And I've been really nice to her... and I haven't told anyone. And what the hell?!
Answer: Here is a Kelly complaint: 'Ryan never returns my calls.' Ugh, join the club.

Question: [crumbles up the complaint paper] Makin' progress. [Jim raises his hand] Yes?
Answer: Dwight tried to kiss me.

Question: What?!
Answer: And I didn't tell anyone because I'm not really sure how I feel about it.

Question: Okay, question. [looks at Toby] When a name is withdrawn, does that also apply to the permanent misbehavior file in New York?
Answer: Sure.

Question: Then why is there a picture of a white man on the door? [Michael, along with the camera, look at the standard stick man on the bathroom door.]
Answer: Okay, Phyllis. You complained that Angela's giving you dirty looks. And you tried to get off the party planning committee.

Question: [sighs] Well, what does Roy think about everything?
Answer: I don't know. I try not to bother him about this kind of stuff.

Question: You mean your thoughts and feelings?
Answer: Yeah.

Question: OK, Ryan.  You told Toby that Creed has a distinct old man smell?
Answer: I know exactly what he's talking about. I sprout mung beans on a damp paper towel in my desk drawer. Very nutritious. But they smell like death.

Answer: William Randolph Shakespeare once wrote in one of his plays, and I'm paraphrasing here, 'Love doth be poison.' Brilliant. And a lot of people don't give Shakespeare enough credit. They think it was somebody else. A-holes.

Question: When Michael suggested canceling Christmas, I was outraged, not on my behalf, but on behalf of baby Jesus. I mean, would he cancel Christmas because he got dumped or he was two weeks behind on his party planning, on top of the fact that his cats were ill? I think not. I think baby Jesus would suck it up and plan his party.
Answer: We didn't have a party planning committee in Stamford. Somebody would just volunteer to run out to Carvel and pick up an ice cream cake. So the fact that they have a committee here, fascinating.

Question: This is ridiculous. I... I've spent so much time, like I always do. And for that little trollop to come in here and throw her own party... Are you even listening to me?

Answer: This is the point, OK? You're wrong for me. In... In... every way. But I still find myself wanting to... be with you.

Question: This is the point, OK? You're wrong for me. In... In... every way. But I still find myself wanting to... be with you.

Question: Hey, Mister tally man, tally me banana, six hand, seven hand, eight hand, BRUNCH! [snickers] So delicious. Dinner, too. And every morning I would watch the sunrise and I would eat a mango. And after I finished vomiting, I was more relaxed than I ever have been. Lost six pounds, too. That's how I want every day to be.
Answer: Michael sends me a postcard from every vacation he goes on. Atlantic City, he wishes I was here. Busch Gardens, Virginia, all I got was this lousy postcard. And this time, I'm Jamaican-him-crazy. I don't know how far away he thought he was, because he put $10 worth of stamps on this.

Question: I just got back from vacation, mon, all right? So chill. Let's don't... Don't harsh my mellow, mon.

Question: Did he actually give you some ganja?

Question: You want some?

Question: ... Do you really not know? Because it is a big deal.

Question: The Aristocrats. A man and his wife and his children go into the offices of a talent agency. And the talent agent says, 'Describe your act.' And the man says something really, really raunchy and the talent representative says, 'What do you call yourselves?' And the man says, 'The Aristocrats!'

Question: [runs over after walking over fire coals] Hey! I want to say something. I've been trying to be more honest lately and I just need to say a few things. I did the coal walk! Just, I did it! Michael, you couldn't even do that.  Maybe I should be your boss? Wow, I feel really good right now.  Why didn't any of you come to my art show? I invited all of you.  That really sucked. It's like sometimes some of you act like I don't even exist.  [turns and looks directly at Jim] Jim, I called off my wedding because of you. And now we're not even friends.  And things are just like weird between us, and that sucks. And I miss you. You were my best friend before you went to Stamford, and I really miss you. I shouldn't have been with Roy. And there were a lot of reasons to call off my wedding. But the truth is, I didn't care about any of those reasons until I met you.  And now you're with someone else. And that's... fine. It's... whatever. That's not what... I'm not... Okay, my feet really hurt. The thing that I'm just trying to say to you, Jim... and to everyone else in this circle I guess, is that I miss having fun with you. Just you, not everyone in the circle. Okay, I am going to go walk in the water now. Yeah. It's a good day.
Answer: Pam, that was amazing. But I am still looking for someone with a sales background.

Question: Pam, you broke up with your boyfriend and then kept working together. How did that work out?
Answer: You remember you fired Roy for attacking Jim and I don't talk to him anymore really.

I don't know, could be good.  Or, uh, 'Super Duper Paper.  It's super duper.'  I don't know, something like that.

Answer: Well, it's... [Jan starts crying, high pitched whining] No, don't cry, it's gonna be OK.

I'm totally fine.  Everything is gonna be totally--- [Jim walks in]

Question: Pam.  [to camera] Sorry. [to Pam] Um, are you free for dinner tonight?

Question: What?! [Ryan smiles and glances at the camera]

Question: I'm a very good interviewee.  Why?  Because I have something that nobody else has.  And that is... my brain.  Which makes me charming, witty, intelligent... [long pause] and quick on my feet.

What is a scented candle?

I have a roommate, uh, Vijay Chokalingham, he's a sophomore at Queens College. Ugh, it's almost too easy.

Answer: [looking at the chair model's headstone] How did she die?

Answer: Mmm-hmm.

Question: What do I do?
Answer: Have you asked her what she wants to do?

Question: Have you asked her what she wants to do?
Answer: Well, I thought as the man that I should make the decision.

Question: Our first date was at the Anthracite Coal Museum.  We had both been before, but we pretended like it was our first time so we could get all the extra information.  They knew we were faking... 'cause they recognized us.   But we made them tell us all the stories.  All the safety information.  And we corrected them whenever they got it wrong. [Phyllis chuckles and nods, Dwight sighs and takes the rest of his sandwich out of the container and holds it up to Phyllis]   You want half a sandwich?
Answer: Okay.

Question: [dressed as Raggedy Ann] Shh. He wears that so he can sleep at his desk. Who are you?
Answer: Oh, I'm Carrie Bradshaw from Sex And The City.

Question: Thank you. Will you help walk me to the fax machine?
Answer: Sure.

Question: Inappropriate. Thank you. Who are you, Larry King?
Answer: Gordon Gekko.

Question: [dressed as a kitten] Meow. Sweet 'stume, dude. Who are you supposed to be?
Answer: Dave.

Question: You are?  [Andy hisses] A cat?
Answer: [buzzer noise] We were looking for 'kitten.'

Question: [dressed as the Joker] Hm mm mm mm. Want to see a magic trick? Heh heh heh! I'm gonna make a pencil disapp-- oh! [elevator doors close, reopen.] Disappear.
Answer: Okay, I think we are set. We have puzzles, string for Cat's Cradles. Burned this last night. A little road trip CD. Puppets.

Question: Road trip!  Right?
Answer: Breaker one-nine, copy?

Question: Breaker one-nine, copy?
Answer: Oh, copy that breaker. Those Duke boys are at it again.

Question: It's been a weird week since we found out I had to transfer. Michael wanted me to quit and get some job here in Scranton, and I said 'Well, why don't you quit and get some job in Nashua?' And he said 'I asked you first.'  And I said 'First!' at the same time he did. And then I said 'Jinx.' And then we never talked about it again and haven't been back to the conversation. So...
Answer: All right everybody. I'm out of here. Jim, you're in charge.

Question: Thought I'd go casual today. Morning everyone. Good morning.  Hello.  How are you Phyllis?
Answer: Ha ha ha. That's funny. [angrily] Take that sweatshirt off!  Hey buddy.

Question: Remember when I jokingly yelled at you to take your sweatshirt off? Totally joking. But, you should know, those colors are sacred. Not that I care. But if you're not a Cornell man, you probably shouldn't wear them.
Answer: No I get it. I totally understand. And uh, I just want to assure you, that I mean no disrespect. You see, I'm applying!

Question: Come on, you think you can get into Cornell?
Answer: Well if somebody who barely out-sells Phyllis, can get in, I should be fine.

Question: Mike you'll drive this every weekend?
Answer: We're gonna switch back and forth, the driving. Sometimes we'll just meet in the middle. It'll be fun. Wait a sec. Oh I love this song.

Question: Hey there. So uh, how do you think we're gonna do against Penn this year? Nathan Ford's arm looks pretty strong.
Answer: Well he's had a pretty good season so far--- Stop saying 'we.' You did not go to Cornell. Okay, you're just doing this to screw with me.

Question: I asked Tom and Pete to come early so we could play a prank on Jim at lunch! Pretty awesome, right? I think they're into the idea. They're probably thinking, 'That Pam Beasly, she's the coolest sister-in-law on the planet. She's the best! The absolute best.'
Answer: Okay, so here's what I'm thinking. I'm gonna say that before ceramics class, I took off my ring, and then when I changed back out of my smock, it wasn't in my pocket anymore, and I lost it.

Question: That's perfect. You know what would be even more hilarious? Remember that thing we did when Jim was in high school with his girlfriend?
Answer: Right! That would be hilarious! We should totally dog her, about being an artist, never making any money!

Question: So, not the ring then? The- the- Not doing the ring?
Answer: I think this is better.

Question: You were sleeping?  You were talking before.
Answer: Was I?  Really? Was I saying anything interesting?

Question: Was I?  Really? Was I saying anything interesting?
Answer: Not really.

Question: All right. What's the scoop, how far?
Answer: Four hours. Almost halfway there.

Question: We're only halfway?
Answer: Halfway! Okay, You know what I want to do, I want to pull over and find little bed and breakfast for when we meet in the middle. Emphasis on the bed. And the breakfast.

Question: Hey, how are you?
Answer: Hi! [smooches]

Question: Here we go, fourth time's a charm. 'Life's like a road where you just... one day here, and the next day back...Sometimes you deal with it, today you don't, sometimes you do, what you want... there's a world out there.... [Holly sobs] Hey. Are you crying?
Answer: No.

Question: Allergies?
Answer: No.

Question: Did Darryl touch you?
Answer: WHAT!?

Question: WHAT!?
Answer: No, Darryl did not touch me. Can we just keep going, please? [crying]

Question: No, Darryl did not touch me. Can we just keep going, please? [crying]
Answer: What's the matter?

Question: What's the matter?
Answer: It's not gonna work.

Question: Holly thinks that this relationship is over. Well, you know what? I am not gonna give up that easy. I'm gonna make this way harder than it needs to be.
Answer: Take that down. [Dwight has hung a large red Cornell banner from the ceiling]

Question: Excuse me?
Answer: Take. That down.

Question: What do you say?
Answer: Yeah, good. Can we--- [Dwight pulls out Cornell mascot bobble-head] Grr. Heh heh heh. That's Big Red Bear! That's a bobble Big Red Bear! God!!

Question: If you leave on Friday, by five, you'll be rolling in at... midnight? At best?
Answer: Yeah.

Question: Maybe I'll see an accident one weekend?
Answer: How long could we keep that up?

Question: How long could we keep that up?
Answer: Years!

Question: Years?
Answer: Yeah.

Question: Years?  Of just a few hours every weekend?
Answer: Here's my wish. I want you to meet a great guy, and I want you to be happy.

Question: So Pam, how much does an artist make after they leave art school?
Answer: Yeah, not a lot of money in the arts, right?

Question: Yeah, not a lot of money in the arts, right?
Answer: That's not really true. There's a lot of things you can do with an art degree actually.

Question: Wow, that's- that's a little rude. What's your deal?
Answer: Hey, just having fun Jimmy.

Question: Yeah. Right Pam?
Answer: Yup! [Tom and Pete give Halpertian looks to camera]

Question: You know what? I think we're a great couple. I think we're a classic couple. I think we're like Romeo and Juliet. I think we... go together so well.  We're like peanut butter and jelly, don't you think?
Answer: I do, I think so.

Question: Please?
Answer: You'll be okay

Question: What?
Answer: Dwight!

Question: Andy, I've been meaning to ask you, which a cappella group should I join? The Harmoniacs, or the Do-Re-Mi-Go's?
Answer: Hm. Assuming you had the voice to be in any of them, it's irrelevant. Because I called admissions and it looks like I, will be conducting your university interview.

Question: Yeah. Big one. So, should I not let you in now, or do you want to do the interview, and then I won't let you in?
Answer: [thinks] Interview.

Question: What?
Answer: The conference room!

Question: Who are your role models?
Answer: If I had to put Dwight's chances into a percentage, I would say he has none percent chance.

Question: That must be really fun for you and Marci huh?
Answer: Yup. She only knows how to play 'When the Saints go Marching In.'

Question: Yeah but, she doesn't think she's gonna be like, career musician right?
Answer: Here you go again! What is your deal today?

Question: Here you go again! What is your deal today?
Answer: Just saying. How many famous trumpeters can you name besides... Louis Armstrong?

Question: Just saying. How many famous trumpeters can you name besides... Louis Armstrong?
Answer: Miles Davis.

Question: Pete couldn't make the Mets. She's at Pratt. You played JV baseball. Will you lighten up a little bit?
Answer: I'm just calling it like I see it.

Question: Guys, what is going on?!  [Pete and Tom burst out in laughter]
Answer: We pranked you!

Question: Who was Cornell's eighth president?
Answer: Dale Raymond Corson!

Question: What are you writing? Can't even give Cornell your full attention?
Answer: On the contrary, I'm helping Cornell. By evaluating their interviewers.

Question: Interviewer has turned off applicant's interest in Cornell, and they are going to go to the vastly superior Dartmouth.' Ever heard of it? I think I have everything I need.
Answer: I have everything I need- [talking over each other]

Question: Well, I'll be the judge of that. What do you got?
Answer: Okay. I lost my engagement ring in ceramics class. Left it in my smock. I had this whole thing where I go back to class, wrongly accuse another girl. Look I even used makeup to put a ring around my finger, you can hardly see it, it's very subtle.

Question: Oh. Hey how about at Thanksgiving we prank Tom about being bald?
Answer: This is the last of it.

Question: You're not staying?
Answer: You know I have some things I need to do this weekend. I just remembered, so, I'll just ride back with you.

Question: I'll be down in just a second. [into house] Holly?
Answer: So um... I think I'm gonna go back with Darryl [Holly hugs Michael] Okay. [they kiss goodbye.] Goodbye.

Question: Da  na na na na.  No, no, check it out, look. Da  na na na na... want to do that?
Answer: Okay.

Question: That's when you hit me with what's getting you down, okay?
Answer: Okay.

Question: [Whistling, enters office in farmer overalls]  I thought I'd come in casual today. Man, I'm hungry. Anyone else feel like a beet?
Answer: Where did you get those?

Question: Where did you get those?
Answer: What, these?  Bernard Farms. Best beets in the state.

Question: What, these?  Bernard Farms. Best beets in the state.
Answer: I see what you are doing. But I do not know where you are going with this.

Question: Well you will. Soon as you visit, my new beet farm. [attempts to bite into a raw beet, beet is too hard] You're supposed to cook these, aren't you?
Answer: [scoffs] Cornell. [easily bites into a beet]

Question: [chuckling] Isn't it a seven-hour drive?
Answer: It's not that bad. But if I'm really jonesing to see you guys, I can always fly.

Question: I don't know if it'll be shorter to fly. [Holly gasps] You have to drive to Boston, right? That's an hour and a half. Get there an hour before the flight. Now you're up two and a half hours. The flight to Philadelphia is an hour fifteen. It's another two and a half hour drive to Scranton, assuming there's no traffic, because....
Answer: [interrupting Oscar] Well, I just want to say goodbye. [hugs Oscar]

Question: So, you're dumping Michael? Smart.
Answer: No, we're gonna do the long-distance thing.

Question: Oh! You guys are gonna keep dating? That's so romantic!
Answer: Yeah, thanks.

Question: [playing cat's cradle with Holly] Okay, am I grabbing this one?
Answer: [chuckling] No, that's not what you're grabbing.

Question: It's like Driving Miss Daisy, you know?
Answer: All right.

Question: Okay, okay. What kind of car games did you play in the 'hood?
Answer: I got a game. Cow surfing.

Question: Cow surfing?
Answer: Spot a cow, last person to say 'Jackson Five' has to get on its back and ride it.

Question: Really?
Answer: Were there even cows where you grew up?

Question: Were there even cows where you grew up?
Answer: Everybody got a government cow.

Question: Then why did you say 'Jackson Five?'
Answer: The man has a point.

Question: [visibly shocked] What? Why?
Answer: Because I wanted you to like me.

Question: Okay, Ready?
Answer: [setting stopwatch] Go.

Question: Hey, you know what would be fun? Like, sleeping.
Answer: Yeah

Question: We could stay in a cozy B&B with a fireplace?
Answer: Absolutely. Oh, and you know what, Darryl? You are invited to go as well.

Question: Absolutely. Oh, and you know what, Darryl? You are invited to go as well.
Answer: Oh, thanks. Thanks. No.

Question: [emerging from convenience store with two ice cream sundaes] Hey, look at that. Fun, right?
Answer: Mmm.

Question: Mmm mmm! Remember the 15-scooper we had last week? Wasn't that good? I was Scooperman, you were Scoopy-Doo. Remember what you said? You were laughing.
Answer: Yeah.

Question: Darryl didn't want any?
Answer: I didn't ask.

Question: Hey, y'all wanna hear some loud music or something?
Answer: I'm an atheist. Did you know that? I don't know your religion. There are so many conversations that we haven't even had yet.

Question: I'm an atheist. Did you know that? I don't know your religion. There are so many conversations that we haven't even had yet.
Answer: Hey, look, Pennsylvania license plate! That's crazy! All the way out here! Who can name all the states?

Question: Hey, look, Pennsylvania license plate! That's crazy! All the way out here! Who can name all the states?
Answer: [standing with Holly next to 'Welcome to New Hampshire' sign] Oh, it's really cold here.

Question: [starts to cry] Can we have another? I think I blinked.
Answer: [unlocking front door] This is me here.

Question: You don't think he could get in, though....right? I mean, I don't care, but I just don't see how he could. I doubt he could get in.
Answer: [reverently] He is fiercely intelligent.

Question: Why are you doing this to Andy?
Answer: You once told me that Andy and I had different strengths. Well, he can't do what I can do. I can get into Cornell, but he doesn't know how to make food and shelter from a golden retriever.

Question: I heard someone got engaged, you dog, huh? [punches Michael's shoulder]
Answer: Ow! God!

Question: Michael, did you tell your mom yet?
Answer: Nope. Nope. Not yet.

Question: You wouldn't tell your mom?
Answer: You love your mom.

Question: [on speakerphone] Hello?
Answer: Mom, I'm getting married.

Question: Why do you always do that? Whenever I'm getting married, you don't believe me.
Answer: Well, are you getting married?

Question: Well, are you getting married?
Answer: No. [laughs]

Question: And I'm out a fiancee. Are those the customer surveys?
Answer: Yeah, uh, this is all of them: Jim, Dwight, Phyllis, Stanley, Andy and -- oh. Oh, it's the receipt to my bridesmaid dress. What's that doing there? [hands stack of papers to Michael]

Question: Yeah, uh, this is all of them: Jim, Dwight, Phyllis, Stanley, Andy and -- oh. Oh, it's the receipt to my bridesmaid dress. What's that doing there? [hands stack of papers to Michael]
Answer: I'll take care of that for you. [crumples receipt and throws it in trash] Thanks.

Question: Uh, Pam. What do you want on your coffee?
Answer: Sprinkle of cinnamon.

Question: What does it say?
Answer: Dwight, your feedback is horrible.

Question: Wait, is this a joke? I'm getting that queasy feeling that sometimes accompanies jokes.
Answer: Do I look like I am joking?

Question: Do I look like I am joking?
Answer: No, but that's sometimes part of it.

Question: If I were joking, you would be laughing. Do you look like you are laughing?
Answer: Impossible to say. I can't see myself.

Question: Yo, Tommy Tuna, did you get your scores yet?
Answer: Nope.

Question: How can you even be sure?
Answer: It has my face on it.

Question: [Dwight slams something on desk] What was that?
Answer: Wow. That was Dwight. He seems upset about something.

Question: Describe him exactly. What color mustard is his shirt? Yellow or Dijon?
Answer: It is... more of a spicy brown, actually.

Question: What are you mumbling about?
Answer: How was your meeting with Michael?

Question: How was your meeting with Michael?
Answer: None of your business.

Question: Was it your scores?
Answer: Those can't be my scores, Jim. For your information --

Question: What do you think I am saying to you?!
Answer: I'm not talking to you.

Question: [on phone] Would you be able to do the same design, but with walls of gray? And a top that's gray too? Fabulous.
Answer: Oh, come on.

Question: What?
Answer: You too?

Question: You too?
Answer: Did my scores drop a little?

Question: Did my scores drop a little?
Answer: Jim, they are a poopy. [Jim coughs, presses button to end call on Bluetooth]

Question: [touches ear] Jim? Jim?
Answer: Are we even sure that's my file?

Question: Are we even sure that's my file?
Answer: No. [glances at it] Yes, I am sure, Jim. It --

Question: Here's what's going to happen. I am going to have to fix you, manage you two on a more personal scale, a more micro form of management. Jim, what is that called?
Answer: Microgement.

Question: [picks up phone] Hello?
Answer: Hello, this is Dwight Schrute from the Dunder Mifflin Paper Company.

Question: What is your name, sir?
Answer: I am Bill Buttlicker.

Question: Really, that's your real name?
Answer: How dare you? My family built this country, by the way.

Question: How dare you? My family built this country, by the way.
Answer: Be respectful, Dwight.

Question: Would you hold on one second? That's my other line.
Answer: What? No, but I --

Question: What? No, but I --
Answer: Hello? [laughs] No, I'm just on the phone with this stupid salesman. He's so dumb. Probably just gonna keep him on the line forever and not buy anything. Yeah, OK. [punches button on phone]

Question: Hello? [laughs] No, I'm just on the phone with this stupid salesman. He's so dumb. Probably just gonna keep him on the line forever and not buy anything. Yeah, OK. [punches button on phone]
Answer: It's up to you to change his mind.

Question: Oh, no. What's wrong?
Answer: You know what? That's private.

Question: You know what? That's private.
Answer: Boundaries, Dwight. Come on!

Question: Well, I should hope so. [Michael takes phone] Who is this?
Answer: Hello, this is Michael Scott, regional manager.

Question: Hello, Mr. Buttlicker. How may we help you?
Answer: Michael, I like the sound of your voice. You know what I'm going to do? I'm going to buy one million dollars worth of paper products today.

Question: Michael, I like the sound of your voice. You know what I'm going to do? I'm going to buy one million dollars worth of paper products today.
Answer: [shakes fist, whispers] Yeah!

Question: [covers phone, whispers to Dwight] See how it's done? [into phone] Thank you very much, sir. I don't think you'll regret it. [to Dwight] See what I did?
Answer: You are the master.

Question: Do you have a specific place in mind?
Answer: No. But anything within a five- to eight-mile radius is acceptable.

Question: Are you serious?
Answer: Get in! [he peels off into parking space]

Question: What's that?
Answer: They might be listening to us

Question: Who's they?
Answer: Customer service might be monitoring this conversation.

Question: In this car?
Answer: You never know. Better safe than sorry.

Question: [turns radio down] What are you thinking?
Answer: Who stands to benefit from our downfall?

Question: Who stands to benefit from our downfall?
Answer: The mob, maybe NASA.

Question: Is there some evidence?
Answer: [on Bluetooth] Ooh, cute shoes online.

Question: How many shoes do you need?
Answer: I don't know. Two, maybe three if one wears out. How many shoes do you need?

Question: I don't know. Two, maybe three if one wears out. How many shoes do you need?
Answer: I'm not talking to you.

Question: Who are you talking to?
Answer: Pam.

Question: I'm sorry?
Answer: Shh. Do you hear that?

Question: Shh. Do you hear that?
Answer: Hear what?

Question: Hear what?
Answer: Breathing. Is that you?

Question: Breathing. Is that you?
Answer: Well, I am breathing, yes.

Question: Well, stop. Hold your breath. I still hear it. Who's there? Kelly, is that you? Hold on. [puts down phone and runs away]
Answer: I need paper.

Question: Hear anything interesting?
Answer: What are you talking about?

Question: What are you talking about?
Answer: [laughs] I think you know.

Question: What are you up to, girl? Huh? Phyllis put you up to this? Stanley? Are they paying you?
Answer: Are you accusing me of something?

Question: Are you accusing me of something?
Answer: Of course I am. I know you're the mastermind, but you're too stupid to do it by yourself.

Question: Hey, how are you and Darryl?
Answer: Um, we're cool. [gets up to leave] Bye.

Question: What was?
Answer: Have you ever had a conversation with Kelly where she didn't go on for 15 minutes without taking a breath?

Question: Have you ever had a conversation with Kelly where she didn't go on for 15 minutes without taking a breath?
Answer: No, actually.

Question: Did you do something to her?
Answer: I don't think so.

Question: Hey, how's things?
Answer: All right.

Question: Yeah?
Answer: Living in the moment.

Question: Do you have any reason to believe that Kelly would be mad at me?
Answer: I don't play the politics game anymore, Jim. Can I tell you something? I played it full on in New York. I played it high stakes. For keeps. Made it to the top. But look what it cost. [takes sip of coffee] Can I tell you what else I learned?

Question: I don't play the politics game anymore, Jim. Can I tell you something? I played it full on in New York. I played it high stakes. For keeps. Made it to the top. But look what it cost. [takes sip of coffee] Can I tell you what else I learned?
Answer: Wait, that's pretty weird.

Question: What?
Answer: Well, Andy has a mug just like that.

Question: Oh, yeah, Kelly gave them out as party favors. Remember? You got one.
Answer: No. What party?

Question: No. What party?
Answer: Her America's Got Talent finale party over the summer. [Jim makes face] That's crazy. It was packed. I thought everyone was there. You were there. I remember you being there.

Question: I wasn't. But thank you. [to Pam] Do you know anything about this party?
Answer: Yes, I said you definitely should go, but you wanted to visit me instead.

Question: Is that it?
Answer: No. Why? No. [puts it in desk drawer and slams it shut]

Question: No. Why? No. [puts it in desk drawer and slams it shut]
Answer: OK, I'm gonna assume that was it. Here's the thing: I think you're right. I think it was Kelly. I think she's mad at us for not coming to her party.

Question: Oh, man, I knew it. Who are her co-conspirators?
Answer: Probably just Kelly.

Question: Yeah. What?
Answer: You were right.

Question: What's going on?
Answer: Why don't you tell us?

Question: Why don't you tell us?
Answer: Nothing's going on.

Question: What? I -- I don't know what you're talking about. This is the first I'm hearing about this.
Answer: Oh, come on. You juked the stats, cupcake.

Question: What's going on?
Answer: I love your tie, Michael.

Question: OK,  all right. OK, I did it. All right? I lied, whatever. Just fire me. But you know what? I did it because you guys didn't come to my party, and you said you would try to and then you didn't even show up, and so you're bad friends.
Answer: We have our confession. I'm calling security. [reaches for phone]

Question: Don't. Don't. Get away from that, Dwight, please. You know what? She's got a point about you two. You do have a problem dealing with people.
Answer: See? I wasn't lying.

Question: See? I wasn't lying.
Answer: You were lying.

Question: I have an enormous amount of trouble trying to get people to come to my place. And I hate it. I can't tell you how much leftover guacamole I have ended up eating over the years. I don't even know why I make it in such great quantities. Here's what we're gonna do. We are going to sit here for a while, make it look good. And maybe you should cry. Can you make yourself cry?
Answer: No problem.

Question: Pam Beesley?
Answer: Hey, what are you doing here?

Question: Hey, what are you doing here?
Answer: Who's that?

Question: Who's that?
Answer: It's Alex.

Question: Oh, that's gonna be great. Who's Chuck Close?
Answer: Oh, I love Chuck Close and his photo-realist paintings. But I have to work.

Question: Uh, well, actually there's something else I'd love to talk to you about. Can we go somewhere else to talk about it?
Answer: OK.

Question: What's up?
Answer: I'm gonna take a big leap and I want to tell you that I think you should not move back to Scranton.

Question: Why did you come to New York in the first place?
Answer: Because they have a great design program, and I wanted to see if I was any good at it. And I wanted to work on my art, too.

Question: Right. And that's why I think that you should stay here. Because I mean, you -- really you just got here, you know? You can't do New York in three months. You know, it has everything. It has -- all the opportunity is here. All the -- the whole art scene is in New York. You know, it would be nuts to go back to Scranton without getting to fully experience it.
Answer: Jim's in Scranton.

Question: Is that the Matsuhashi B-400? The world's tiniest Bluetooth? [reaches toward Jim's ear] May I?
Answer: Don't.

Question: Well, then. Why don't you look over some of our materials? [opens album]
Answer: Oh. Hmm.

Question: Um, what are we talking price wise?
Answer: You already said deal.

Question: Come on, how did you propose? Spill it. Were you wasted?
Answer: How did I propose, let me see... well, I drove her up to Nashua, and I had the ring, a big 10-carat diamond; it was beautiful. And I got down on my hands and knees, and a shooting star crossed overhead, and it just lit up the diamond like a shooting star. And we were in a restaurant, and I put the diamond into a cheeseburger.

Question: And she took a bite, started to choke. So what do I do? I have CPR training. Go around, start doing the Heimlich.
Answer: Perfect.

Question: So, how you holdin' up?
Answer: I'm pretty much devastated.

Question: You know what you should do? Take a vacation.
Answer: Maybe go to Sandals, Jamaica. Or the other Sandals, Jamaica. I just don't want to go by myself.

Question: Why are surveys important? Okay, hypothetical: A man wants to buy 500 reams of....carrots. And, so he's like 'What do I do? Where do I go? Do I go to the insensitive carrot supplier, the insensitive carrot salesman? Or do I go to the nice carrot salesman, who will maybe charge a few cents more per ream of carrot, but guarantee next-day delivery on your carrots? Most companies need their carrots the next day. Now, substitute paper for carrots, and that is why surveys are important.'
Answer: Great marks, Phyllis. [Phyllis walks out of Michael's office smiling]

Question: What do I do with my bonus check? [scoffs] Simple. Purchase paper from myself. Boosts my sales, which boosts my bonus. Last year I bought even more paper to make this year's bonus even bigger. Eventually, I'll get a bonus so big I can retire on it. And I'll use the paper to write my memoirs.
Answer: I taught Jim and Dwight everything I know about sales. But there are certain things that cannot be taught, and it is these things that I now must teach them.

Question: My job is to manipulate the customer into buying paper. In return, they give me money. I am the predator and they are the prey. Would a mouse give a positive review to a hawk? Should the hawk even care? [sighs heavily, nearly starts to cry] Excuse me, I've got work to do.
Answer: [laughs heartily and passes a newspaper to Phyllis]

Question: Hey, what are you laughing at?
Answer: [continue to laugh]

Question: Are you laughing at me?
Answer: We're laughing at this cartoon! [passes newspaper to Dwight]

Question: Perfect, isn't it?
Answer: [looks at cartoon] How is that funny? What are you really laughing at? Huh?

Question: [looks at cartoon] How is that funny? What are you really laughing at? Huh?
Answer: Haven't you been following the news? Ther university is using its non-profit status to fund its private real estate investments.

Question: Haven't you been following the news? Ther university is using its non-profit status to fund its private real estate investments.
Answer: [laughing louder] And he really nailed them on it. Somebody's finally holding them accountable!
