Question: See? That's how you do it! Makin' progress here. [steps in manure, trying to laugh it off] ...Darn! Heh.
Answer: There's a hose out back.

Question: Remember, you were gonna get a new chair, and you were gonna give your old chair to me. Remember that?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Michael?
Answer: I don't know. I haven't decided yet.

Question: I'm just gonna grab some lunch. You wanna come with?
Answer: Really? Absolutely! Yeah, that would be amazing.

Question: Really? Absolutely! Yeah, that would be amazing.
Answer: Woah, you guys going to lunch?

Question: Woah, you guys going to lunch?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Mind if I join?
Answer: Ohh, God!

Question: Where we going?
Answer: I have no idea.

Question: Look, I really need this new chair. I mean, seriously, how is it possible that in five years I've had two engagement rings, and only one chair?
Answer: [laughing uproariously with Michael and Jim] Stop it! Michael.

Question: [through the laughter] Oh, is somebody making fun of me?
Answer: The best. Great friends. Thank you, Michael. [all three are still laughing]

Question: Michael?
Answer: Yeah?

Question: Yeah?
Answer: Hey!

Question: You got a second?
Answer: I do.

Question: Hey, have I told you you look really nice today?
Answer: Oh, thank you.

Question: Yeah, is that a new tie?
Answer: Um, no, not... no. No, I got it at TJ Maxx, four dollars.

Question: You think that's good? Check out these pants. Nine dollars.
Answer: What?

Question: What?
Answer: Nine dollars. The boys' department.

Question: Yeah, right?
Answer: Very valid.

Question: Have you made a decision on the butter sculpture?
Answer: No. I haven't thought of it.

Question: What is this? All right, we're all on the same team. Is it- [steps in manure] Damn! Why is that in the kitchen?!
Answer: [Pam is making copies and is struggling with the machine] You might want to consider changing teams, because we would-we would love to have you.

Question: Yeah?
Answer: Yeah. I have my copies. [holds up messed up copies]

Question: So... why don't we try this out, we'll see what would happen. Give it a little test drive, what do you say? You pretend to be Angela's father, you will play Angela, and uh, I will pretend to be you. That way you can see what it looks like when you're up here.
Answer: [whistling Pachelbel's 'Canon in D;' switches to singing then back to whistling]

Question: What?
Answer: Although born just minutes from here, he speaks only German. Closed society. So, now, after the readings by all of your sisters, we will arrive at the vows. So, Konrad... [speaks German to minister; minister begins speaking in German] And away we go. This is a little taste of the ceremony, if you will. He's explaining why we're here, what we're doing here, making introductions, blah blah blah... Then he's gonna have Andy repeat a bunch of stuff. He's gonna ask Andy to produce a ring. I have uh, now just uh... just some twine for our purposes, and you will put the ring on her finger. Yadda yadda, then he's going to ask Andy, uh, if he would like to marry Angela. And you will reply, 'I do.' [Andy mouths, 'I do' silently] And then he's going to ask Angela if she would like to marry Andy, to which you will reply...

Question: Did somebody call Hank?
Answer: Hank, thank God you're here. The office is at a crossroads.

Question: So, there's no security problem? You know, I hustled up the stairs.
Answer: Yes. I need your sage advice. And everyone, whatever Hank decides, that is the decision. That will resolve this issue. [Hank takes some jellybeans from Pam's jar] Yeah, take as many as you want.

Question: So what are we talking about?
Answer: Okay. Well, we have a surplus. Imagine that your parents give you money for a lemonade stand-

Question: Is that the copier?
Answer: It is, yes.

Question: What?
Answer: I was just thinking. Let me see a chair.

Question: Well, what should I do?
Answer: ...Let me see the copier again.

Question: What do you mean?
Answer: Well Monkey, he's a real minister. And you said, 'I do.' And I said, 'I do.' And Andy wasn't signing a receipt; he was signing our marriage certificate as a witness.

Question: Are we, uh... are we leaving or what? [Mose hits Andy in the head with a deflated ball] Ow!
Answer: [on speakerphone] Michael.

Question: Is this why you're calling me?
Answer: No, no, no, no, no. No. I'm calling- [coughs again] I'm sorry.

Question: You want me to weigh in on a minor budget issue?
Answer: No, no, no. I want you to make the decision so I'm not the bad guy.

Question: The what now?
Answer: Branch managers who come in under budget get 15% of the savings.

Question: ...Like a tip? [calculates amount] $645?!
Answer: I hate disappointing just one person. And I really hate disappointing everyone. But I love Burlington Coat Factory. You go in there with $645, you are literally a king.

Question: [on the phone] We have that going out Tuesday... Okay? Sure, no, I can... I'll double-check that for you.
Answer: All right, attention everyone.

Question: Pam, would you stand up for a sec? [sits in Pam's chair] Hmm. See how relaxed I am? I like this chair. [slowly sinking into the chair] Offers good support, it is urkelnomically correct... it's a good chair. I think we're spoiled because we don't appreciate the things that we have. You think kids in Africa have chairs? No. They sit in big piles of garbage. You think they have copiers?  [the chair has slowly lowered itself almost to where Michael is not visible over the desk] They don't have copiers. They don't even- [struggles to get up from Pam's chair] Gah! They don't even have paper. And we are spoiled because we throw out perfectly good tiramisu because it has a little tiny hair on it. My point I this: I have seen the light in terms of what we need, and it is nothing.
Answer: Do you know?

Question: Do you know?
Answer: Do I know what?

Question: Do I know what?
Answer: I think you know.

Question: Know what?
Answer: Yeah, know what?

Question: Yeah, know what?
Answer: Does anyone happen to know what 15% of 4300 is?

Question: Does anyone happen to know what 15% of 4300 is?
Why'd you say dollars?
Answer: Because that is how my mind works.

Question: What's 15% of 200? [Michael doesn't answer] Thank you. Everyone, Michael is returning the surplus so he can keep 15% as a bonus.
Answer: Wait, what?

Question: Wait, what?
Answer: You can do that?

Question: You can do that?
Answer: Hey Michael, what's 394 times 5,912?

Question: Hey Michael, what's 394 times 5,912?
Answer: Let's see...

Question: You're gonna give yourself a bonus of $645 instead of getting the entire office something it really needs?
Answer: I don't need $645; I already have $645, more or less.

Question: You're gonna get us a copier then?
Answer: This is so stupid.

Question: Or chairs?
Answer: This is so, so stupid. And, God... [looks at his watch] that's my phone.

Question: Was that hot or what?
Answer: So what's it gonna be?

Question: So what's it gonna be?
Answer: Michael, you have to make a decision. The day is almost done.

Question: [groans in frustration] You think it's easy?
Answer: It's your job.

Question: Okay, you know what? Why don't you guys deal with it? I am going to get up, and I am going to be out in the common area. But you need to decide; otherwise I'm taking the bonus. All right?
Answer: It is a classic management tactic. You have two sides, a deadline, you know that neither of them are gonna concede. What you do is you put 'em in a room, and you just- [Pam and Oscar come to the door of kitchen] Hey.

Question: What?
Answer: I just figured I'd rather have new chairs than nothing at all.

Question: [wearing a fur coat] What did we learn this week? Well, one, thanks to me, my team is much, much faster at coming to decisions than I thought they would be. Number two, never buy a fur coat with a credit card until you absolutely have the money to pay for it. And three, [camera zooms out to see fake blood is splattered on the fur coat] you should know that some people think it's cool to throw buckets of fake blood on you as you are walking out of Burlington Coat Factory.
Answer: Truce?

Question: Truce?
Answer: Yeah, I guess, since I won.

Question: What is this?
Answer: Happy Holidays, Dwight. But do not open it till Christmas.

Question: You're so pathetic.  How long did this take you? Three hours?
Answer: Five minutes actually.  I am a black belt in gift wrapping.

Question: Really? If I can skin a mule deer in less than ten minutes, I ought to be able to cut my -- [sets briefcase on desk and sits in chair, desk and chair are made of paper, Dwight crashes to the floor]
Answer: Eh...

Question: Hey, Phyllis, do I need this invite to get in to the party?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Angela. You're going to move this for the party right? It's not on theme.
Answer: It's the nativity scene.

Question: Every year I do research to determine which toy will be the most popular of the Christmas season.  This year it's a doll. Half girl, half unicorn.  Catchphrase: 'My horn can pierce the sky'.  Pathetic. I bought out every store in the area over the last couple of weeks.  And as lazy parents become desperate I will sell them for an enormous profit.  Isn't that right princess? [makes doll nod]
Answer: That's the Christmas spirit.

Question: I am simply punishing those parents that would wait till the last minute to get their child a gift.  And such a genetically improbable one.  Look at that.  How does that happen?  King has sex with a unicorn?  Man with a horn has sex with a royal horse?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Oh, hey, is that Princess Unicorn?  I thought they were all sold out.
Answer: They are now.

Question: Really Andy? It's Christmas and your singing about nudity and France.
Answer: [sings] There's a hole in the wall where the men can see it all.

Question: What is it?
Answer: That is vodka and I mixed it with orange juice.  I call it an orange-vod-juice...ka.

Question: We're back on the 5th, should we just do it then?
Answer: Can not do it then. Monthly dental appointment, soft teeth

Question: What about February 2nd?
Answer: Ah... would you want to do it on Groundhogs day?

Question: Ah... would you want to do it on Groundhogs day?
Answer: No, no. I celebrate privately.

Question: Why don't we just do it now? We'll do it quickly.
Answer: Now? It's our Christmas party.

Question: Now? It's our Christmas party.
Answer: We'll do it quickly.

Question: [mimicking] What if we can't do it quickly? What if we cant do it--
Answer: Do you know how to do an intervention?

Question: Do you know how to do an intervention?
Answer: Hey, shut up. Here we go. Everybody gather up.

Question: Okay, how do you feel?
Answer: A little better. I threw up.

Question: Fire girl. [looks around] Too soon?
Answer: Yeah.

Question: Alright, well, let's look at this a little bit closer then shall we? [pulls a piece of paper out of his pocket]
Answer: When I was in college I used to get wicked hammered. My nickname was puke.  I would chug a fifth of socos, sneak into a frat party, polish off a few people's empties, some brewskies, some Jell-O shots, do some body shots off myself, pass out, wake up the next morning, puke, rally, more soco, head to class.  Probably would have gotten expelled if I had let it affect my grades, but I aced all my courses.  They called me Ace.  It was totally awesome.  Got straight B's.  They called me Buzz.

Question: Meredith, have you ever used alcohol to alter your mood or deliberately change your state of mind?
Answer: Sure.

Question: Do you sometimes have a drink to celebrate a special occasion or mark a holiday?
Answer: Obviously.

Question: Have you ever under the influence of alcohol questioned the teachings of the Mormon church?
Answer: Where did you get this?

Question: Where did you get this?
Answer: I got it on a website, that's not important.

Question: Okay, you know what Toby?  One of my employees is undergoing a crisis and I wish for just once you would take my side on this.  I'm doing your job man.  Hey, are you texting?
Answer: Yeah, 'cause this is kind of a drag.

Question: Alcohol is a drag. Yes.  Here's what I'd like to do.  I'd like to go around the room and have us each express to Meredith how her alcoholism has affected us.  I'll begin.  This Christmas party is perhaps the best Christmas party I have ever been to, but then you got so drunk that we had to stop and do this.  That's how your drinking affected me.  Anybody else?  Another time when Meredith's drinking affected you?   Come on people.  If we don't say anything she's not going to get any better.  [Kevin raises his hand] Yes, Kevin.
Answer: Well, Meredith, there was that one time you bought movie tickets and then you got too drunk to go, so you gave them to me.  And that was really cool.

Question: Okay, no, that's not what we're going for.  Who has a problem with Meredith's drinking?  It has to bother you.  It bothers me. Right? How does it bother you?  Dwight, don't you have anything?
Answer: No, I like Meredith.

Question: Who is going to tell us the latest dirty joke?  Who is going to tell us what you watched on television last night?
Answer: I am fine.

Question: Was John Belushi fine?  Was Bob Hope fine?  Hey-- come here.  If anything ever happened to you, I would be very angry at myself for not doing all that I could do.
Answer: I know I drink. I like to party

Question: You never showed me mercy when you were in charge.  Why aren't you wearing the hairnet?
Answer: I lost it. [Phyllis glares at her until Angela pulls out the hairnet and puts it on]

Question: [amid groans from the rest of the office] Alright, no, no, no.  No. That is the image, I think we can all agree is very disgusting.  But you know what, Meredith, you lit your hair on fire today.  What about tomorrow.?  What is going to happen when you come into work and you're dead?
Answer: I stab her in the brain with a wooden stick.

Question: Really?
Answer: Okay you know, this-- this is over.

Question: You know what the only thing I want for Christmas? I want Meredith to get better.  That's my only wish.  But you know what?  My wishes never come true, so I'm not going to wish that on her. I-- a watch would be nice.
Answer: [watching Meredith and Michael talk in his office] They've been in there for 45 minutes.

Question: What's up?
Answer: Do you take requests?

Question: Do you take requests?
Answer: Sure.

Question: [whispers to Meredith] I'll be down in a minute. [walks over to Toby] Could you write down the number of that rehabilitation center that you mentioned?
Answer: Sure. Wow. [Michael throws a pen at his head] Ow...

Question: We did?
Answer: Yeah, I thought we were going out for a drink?

Question: Yeah, I thought we were going out for a drink?
Answer: Oh, shoot.  Oh well, we'll have to go someplace else then I guess.

Question: The Bog? Cooper's, Kelly's...
Answer: We could go there, sure.

Question: [on phone] Hey Sasha, it's daddy.  Have you ever heard of this doll , Princess Unicorn?
Answer: [shouting excitedly over the phone] Daddy, daddy, daddy!!

Question: Something wrong with the doll?
Answer: No.  It's even-- it's even better than the one I wanted.

Question: Sunrise Rehab?  No! No! No!  I told you no! There is no way!
Answer: It's okay. It's all right.

Question: [dragging Meredith on the floor into the rehab center] Let's start meeting-- Hello. How are you?
Answer: This man is crazy! This man is crazy!

Question: Can I help you?
Answer: I have a deposit.  Alcoholic.

Question: So do I sign?
Answer: NO!!!

Question: Excuse me?
Answer: I'm not moving the tree.  Face it. The only power you have over me is this big secret that I know you're not going to tell.  And you want to know how I know that? Because then you won't be able to plan your stupid, tacky parties anymore. So you move the tree.

Question: I'm not moving the tree.  Face it. The only power you have over me is this big secret that I know you're not going to tell.  And you want to know how I know that? Because then you won't be able to plan your stupid, tacky parties anymore. So you move the tree.
Answer: Okay. [starts to walk away, then turns around] Angela's having sex with Dwight.  I caught them doing it after Toby's going away party.

Question: [answering the phone] Dunder Mifflin, this is Pam. I'm sorry, he's not in yet. Would you like his voicemail?
Answer: [heard yelling from the street] Yeah! Yeah! Yeah, okay! Twelve miles an hour. Eat that, Carl Lewis!

Question: [entering the office] Excuse me, everyone, can I have the floor please? Um, this is insanely awkward. It's kind of the elephant in the room, so I'll just... [sighs] No one has RSVP'ed to our wedding yet, and the deadline was yesterday.
Answer: Wait, you still don't know...

Question: Hmm?
Answer: Nothing.

Question: [to Jim] What are you doing?
Answer: How about we just... Just have to talk to you for a second...

Question: [sighs] How can he still not know?
Answer: We can't figure that out.

Question: Wait, what?  You can't take what?
Answer: I am telling Andy.

Question: Who should it come from, then?
Answer: [simultaneously] Angela.

Question: [to Dwight] Are you still having intercourse with her? [Dwight's expression implies 'yes']
Answer: What is wrong with you? She is engaged.

Question: What is wrong with you? She is engaged.
Answer: Did you ever have intercourse in this office? [Dwight's expression implies 'yes']

Question: Did you ever have intercourse in this office? [Dwight's expression implies 'yes']
Answer: Are you serious? Ugh. Where? [Dwight stares at Oscar; more forcefully] Where? [Dwight's expression implies 'at your desk'; Oscar's voice breaks] Where, Dwight?

Question: Are you serious? Ugh. Where? [Dwight stares at Oscar; more forcefully] Where? [Dwight's expression implies 'at your desk'; Oscar's voice breaks] Where, Dwight?
Answer: [coolly] Seems like you already know where.

Question: Because I wouldn't want an innocent person, who doesn't know anything about the form... [Angela puts headphones on; Kevin looks at Oscar] What?
Answer: That was good... It's just, at the end you weren't saying something that could also apply to the form.

Question: How about, 'I'm sorry I did such a whorish job filling out this form?'
Answer: There you go.

Question: [on the phone] That cannot be true! [Dwight jumps] You're going to charge me a fee to cut my own cake? Uh, no. No, no, no. What I'm saying is, I want to cut it myself...
Answer: [whispering to Jim] Trade seats with me.

Question: What is it?
Answer: You've got to tell Andy about us.

Question: Do you love me or not?
Answer: I've already admitted that I do. Why do you keep making me repeat it?

Question: I've already admitted that I do. Why do you keep making me repeat it?
Answer: Because you're engaged to Andy.

Question: Well?
Answer: Not yet.

Question: When?
Answer: When what? [clears throat] When what?

Question: When what? [clears throat] When what?
Answer: You know this can't go on.

Question: What can't go on?
Answer: We have to put an end to this.

Question: When will she be ready?
Answer: I don't know.

Question: Is she crazy in bed?
Answer: [boastfully] Yes.

Question: Stop. What?
Answer: How so, specifically?

Question: How so, specifically?
Answer: Okay, listen.

Question: Really?
Answer: This shouldn't be coming from his boss. And we should also consider the fact that that man has an anger issue.

Question: Okay, what does that mean?
Answer: Might get ugly.

Question: Thanks. [to Andy] Andy?
Answer: Yeah.

Question: What?
Answer: All right. See you later. [backs out of the parking space] Ahh.

Question: Are you serious?
Answer: Yep. [drives off]

Question: [to Dwight] What are you standing for?
Answer: If I'm sitting, I can't disable his neck or his groin.

Question: Is it true?
Answer: What have you heard?

Question: What have you heard?
Answer: That you're sleeping with Dwight.

Question: Is it true?
Answer: Andy, I'm engaged to you. I mean, we just signed off on our wedding flowers. Would I have said yes to formal chrysanthemums if I didn't want to get married? And, we went through all that stuff with our wedding cake...

Question: Andy, I'm engaged to you. I mean, we just signed off on our wedding flowers. Would I have said yes to formal chrysanthemums if I didn't want to get married? And, we went through all that stuff with our wedding cake...
Answer: Just answer the question. Are you sleeping with Dwight?

Question: Just answer the question. Are you sleeping with Dwight?
Answer: A little bit.

Question: How long has it been going on?
Answer: I don't know. I mean, we were together, and then he killed sprinkles, and then we stopped, and... I don't know exactly when we started up again.

Question: Who else knows about it?
Answer: Michael.

Question: Who else?
Answer: [quietly] Let me think about it... I, um... there... [Andy looks over to see everyone watching them]

Question: So listen, Michael, your branch has been doing great lately, and your sales staff is reporting very strong numbers. Out-performing last year, in fact. Um, and I don't know exactly how to put this, but... what are you doing right?
Answer: Right what?

Question: Right what?
Answer: Utica, Albany, all the other branches are struggling, but your branch is reporting strong numbers. [Michael smiles] Look, you're not our most traditional guy, but clearly, something you are doing... is right. And I just, I need to get a sense of what that is.

Question: This is going to sound sort of high-maintenance, but could we have it, like, three degrees cooler in here? I always think better when it's cooler.
Answer: Here's the thing. Michael is doing something right. And in this economic climate, no method of success can be ignored. It's not really time for executives to start getting judgmental now. It's Hail Mary time.

Question: [pokes his head in] Hey, what say we order up some pasta?
Answer: What say we do.

Question: Standard, you know? Nothing fancy.
Answer: So like, missionary...

Question: Do you love him?
Answer: I love you.

Question: Why should I believe that?
Answer: Andy, we are at a crossroads here. And we can either give in to what people are saying that we're not good together.

Question: Who says that?
Answer: Or, we can prove them wrong. Let's prove them wrong.

Question: Where's Dwight?
Answer: You okay, man?

Question: You okay, man?
Answer: No. Not at all, actually. But thanks for asking. Appreciate it. You know what? I'd also like to take this opportunity to thank all of you for lying. To my face. And not telling me what's been going on this entire time.

Question: No. Not at all, actually. But thanks for asking. Appreciate it. You know what? I'd also like to take this opportunity to thank all of you for lying. To my face. And not telling me what's been going on this entire time.
Answer: You are welcome.

Question: Hey guys, why don't we, uh, just cool off a bit?
Answer: I'm telling you to back down.

Question: Oh really? How are you gonna do that?
Answer: Through the use of force.

Question: What is your weapon?
Answer: Okay, you know what? That's enough. Because...

Question: Okay, you know what? That's enough. Because...
Answer: Hey, this is none of your business.

Question: Guess what? Not happening at work.
Answer: Yes!

Question: None of your business then. [Dwight and Andy high five] Good. So what weapon?
Answer: My bare hands.

Question: [innocently] How'd that get there?
Answer: There's a star-shaped thing taped under the kitchen table.

Question: So I was in the office, and I look over to our Accounting division, and there is Kevin Malone. Kevin is wearing a jacket that I've never seen before. And I call over to Kevin, 'Kevin, is that a tweed jacket?' And he looks at me and he says, 'Michael, yes it is a tweed jacket.' And I look back at him and I say, 'I feel the need!... The need for tweed.'
Answer: It's hard to try and evaluate yourself, Michael, but I appreciate you trying. [gets up] And thanks for coming in.

Question: [shouting] Come on! Where are you? Let's do this thing! Come on! Come on out!
Answer: [watching from the conference room] I can't believe they're gonna fight over me.

Question: Hey, has anything happened yet?
Answer: Where are you?

Question: Where are you?
Answer: Mm-mm. It's 4:10, I don't think he's gonna show.

Question: Come on, coward! Where are you? Where... [spots a note attached to the bushes; goes to read it] 'From the desk of Andrew Bernard.' [scoffs] A note. Pathetic. 'Dear Dwight, by now you have received my note. How are you? I am well. You are no doubt wondering why I have left this note. It has come to my attention that in any physical match with you, I would surely be bested.' True. 'The soft underbelly of my refined upbringing is my soft underbelly...' [as Dwight continues to read, Andy drives around the corner very slowly]
Answer: There's Andy, he's in his car. You guys, what is he doing?

Question: There's Andy, he's in his car. You guys, what is he doing?
Answer: Why isn't Dwight turning around?

Question: Why isn't Dwight turning around?
Answer: The Prius is silent if he keeps it under five miles per hour. He deserves the win.

Question: What's happening?
Answer: Andy's running over Dwight with his car.

Question: You give up?
Answer: Never! [hits Andy's car with his bike chain] Get out and face me like a man!

Question: You're not a man! You don't know how to take care of her! [hits his car with the bike chain] All you do is dress fancy and sing. [imitating Andy] 'La la la la la la la la la la!' What does that mean? You can't even protect her!
Answer: Protect her from what? Bears, you idiot? When's the last time you saw a damn bear in Scranton?

Question: Protect her from what? Bears, you idiot? When's the last time you saw a damn bear in Scranton?
Answer: Last year, idiot! [hits his car with the bike chain]

Question: Dwight! Are your legs broken?
Answer: No. My right one's falling asleep a little bit.

Question: Andy, are you all right?
Answer: Go away, Tuna! I'm winning this!

Question: Yeah, back off. This isn't your fight. Oh, how much is this gonna cost? [hits his car with the bike chain] Oh! What? Trust fund will take care of that! [hits his car with the bike chain]
Answer: What did you say? I'm sorry, I couldn't hear you.

Question: What did you say? I'm sorry, I couldn't hear you.
Answer: I sa- [Andy honks his horn]

Question: What? You stupid idiot! [Andy honks his horn] You're like, you're like a Sasquatch! You live in the woods...
Answer: Sasquatches are the strongest animal on the planet! So fine, call me a Sasquatch!

Question: I don't get it! How can she be sleeping with you this whole time and only sleep with me twice?
Answer: What?

Question: What?
Answer: What!

Question: She's sleeping with you?
Answer: I'm her fiance.

Question: Wow, what a day! Haha! I thought I was gong to get chewed out, but, hold on! Here's an attaboy for ya! What? Rollercoaster ride! Rollercoaster! It just goes to show, you leave Scranton, exciting things can happen. [sighs] Ahh!
Answer: [as Jim is collecting weapons, runs to the couch near reception and pulls out a crossbow; Jim catches him and he hands it over]

Question: What's this?
Answer: Looks like a red wire.

Question: Doesn't it?
Answer: No, it's going in a different direction then the other wires.

Question: What are you doing?
Answer: I got 500 feet of red wire at a flea market up by Dunmore High School. 20 bucks for the whole spool. Crazy, what a deal. [behind Jim, Dwight climbs telephone pole] Oh he'll be fine. I made it up there.

Question: What you talking bout, Wallace? [imitating What you talking bout Willis]
Answer: Hi Michael how are you?

Question: Hi Michael how are you?
Answer: Hi, I am well, how are you?

Question: Hi, I am well, how are you?
Answer: So listen, as you know, we haven't yet filled the regional supervisor job.

Question: Oh, have you not?
Answer: Correct. And I was wondering if I could get you to do some of the field work that would normally go to the supervisor [Michael makes exaggerated oh-my-gosh face at camera]. There is an area from Carbondale to Marshbrook, where we have never done any business.

Question: Fax, why don't you just send it over on a dinosaur?
Answer: Look, this is important, Michael.

Question: What are you guys talking about?
Answer: Some actress, whether shes hot.

Question: Who is the gal in question?
Answer: Hillary Swank.

Question: Have you seen her with her bangs?

Answer: Tuna, be nice to my friend Jim, ok?

Question: Tuna, be nice to my friend Jim, ok?
Answer: Why? When I look in the mirror, I don't like the face that looks back.

Question: Why? When I look in the mirror, I don't like the face that looks back.
Answer: Well, so what?  Your body's a ten.

Question: Well, so what?  Your body's a ten.
Answer: Forget it.

Question: [on phone] Mr. Schofield, please?
Answer: He's in a meeting.

Question: [on phone] Is Mr. Schofield there?
Answer: If you'd like to reach an outside line, please dial nine first. [Michael sighs, hangs up phone]

Question: So, you think Michael's going after the whale, huh?
Answer: I have a long term relationship with Harper Collins publishers and Mr. Schofield. I'm not worried.

Question: [on phone] Well, if you could do me a big favor and tell Mr. Schofield that Michael Scott has tickets to the Wilkes-Barre Penguins game this weekend, and if he would like to join me... Hello, Daniel. How are you? Uh-huh. I sure do. Yes. [referencing rolodex card] Wanted to ask, did Kathy ever make JV?
Answer: Look at that old dude and his rolodex go.

Question: Wow. High score?
Answer: And no, I cannot lower my current prices. [phone rings] Hold on. Hello? Mr. Schofield, thank you so much for taking the time to talk. I wanted to discuss your contract with us- oh, you're considering him. I thought Michael Scott left the paper business after his nervous breakdown.

Question: And no, I cannot lower my current prices. [phone rings] Hold on. Hello? Mr. Schofield, thank you so much for taking the time to talk. I wanted to discuss your contract with us- oh, you're considering him. I thought Michael Scott left the paper business after his nervous breakdown.
Answer: Michael has been talking to my biggest client. Master and apprentice pitted against one another for the fate of the greater Scranton area paper market.  So it's not exactly like 'Highlander,' but still...

Question: Hello, Dwight, I've been expecting your call. What do you want?
Answer: I would like to arrange a truce.

Question: So you heard Schofield is considering a switch, and you want mercy?
Answer: Meet me in our spot in four minutes.

Question: No. No. You think I am going to fall for that? There's no-
Answer: Michael.

Question: In which direction?
Answer: Toward the sun.

Question: At what time?
Answer: Noon.

Question: So you just rat me out? You could have said no.
Answer: And not come through for you?

Question: And not come through for you?
Answer: If you want a truce, I will give you a truce.

Question: [Michael, Ryan and Pam sitting at restaurant, phone rings] Oh. Dwight-elicious. Where you at?
Answer: Oh, hi, Michael. I'm so sorry I'm late. I got stuck in traffic.

Question: Really? That's weird. We didn't see any.
Answer: I hit a bear.

Question: What?
Answer: He's technically fine. I imagine the true horror will be when he wakes up in a zoo. [throws a fish into the vent at Michael's office] Hey, listen, will you do me a favor and order the meatball parm for me, with extra cheese?

Question: He's technically fine. I imagine the true horror will be when he wakes up in a zoo. [throws a fish into the vent at Michael's office] Hey, listen, will you do me a favor and order the meatball parm for me, with extra cheese?
Answer: Yeah, sure.

Question: Ok, I will see you very soon, alright? [takes all the items off Michael's desk and puts them into briefcase, including rolodex]
Answer: Okay, see you in a bit. Dwight hit a bear. He'll be here in a sec.

Question: Did you enjoy your lunch?
Answer: Dwight, not now, we've been robbed.

Question: No, Dwight, we were robbed. How would you even know? You're still stuck in traffic. [Pam holds up sign saying 'Dwight did it!!'] You?
Answer: Me.

Question: What about our truce?
Answer: I broke it.

Question: On purpose?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Why?
Answer: You think this is some kind of game? No, this is a war, and I will not stop, I will not rest. You have no idea what kind of enemy you've created. You have unleashed the wolf!

Question: You think this is some kind of game? No, this is a war, and I will not stop, I will not rest. You have no idea what kind of enemy you've created. You have unleashed the wolf!
Answer: Be that as it may, I have your meatball parm sandwich here, and I am going to eat it.

Question: Hi there. Dwight Schrute here. I was just calling to see if Michael Scott Paper was meeting all of your paper needs, and how is [reading off rolodex card] Brenda, age four, ponytail, and Simon, age 7? Oh, you don't say.
Answer: [holding up rolodex card] Schrute comma Dwight. And on the back he wrote, 'great salesman, better friend.' [turns card over] 'Tall' and 'beets.'

Question: And say hello to Cheri, who is your black wife. [hangs up and answers cell phone] I see you're begging for mercy, huh?  Well, you will find none here.
Answer: Dwight, do you mind if we talk?

Question: Dwight, do you mind if we talk?
Answer: Sure. That'd be fine.

Question: Really?
Answer: Yes. He does not have the authority to say that. I, on the other hand, am the president, the owner, and the founder. It is like you are buying software from Bill Gates.

Question: Are you saying you invented paper?
Answer: [hugging a crying Jim] Okay, okay.

Question: Excuse me, can I have your attention, everyone? Here's the deal, everybody, Jim Halpert is very upset and disturbed. I don't know if it was something you did, something you said, a look you gave him, maybe it was nothing at all, but here's the deal, ok? It stops now.
Answer: I guess I could be nicer.

Question: Oh, really?
Answer: Mm-hmm. [looks over to Jim smiling through windows to the kitchen]

Question: Yeah, okay, what the heck is happennin' here?
Answer: Two things I need you to understand. One, Pam and I are very happy together.

Question: What is that thing that Dwight always says? Paper is the soil in which the seeds of business grow?
Answer: It's not the soil! It's the manure! Paper is the manure! On-time delivery is the soil! Aah! [runs into office]

Question: I'm going to pull a date out of the air right now. April 13th, 2002. That is the last day that you evaluated your paper needs. Is it not? We all know that the economy is bad, and bloated companies like Dunder Mifflin...
Answer: Come on.

Question: Why don't you guys just e-mail me your best offers and we can finish it up that way?
Answer: That sounds like a fantastic idea. I will see you this weekend for the Penguins. Box seats as usual.

Question: Thank you, Mr. Schofield, for your time. Much appreciated. Oh, and tell me, um, how's your gay son?
Answer: Excuse me?

Question: Excuse me?
Answer: I color code all my info. I wrote 'gay son' in green. Green means go, so I know to go ahead and shut up about it. Orange means 'Orange you glad you didn't bring it up?' Most colors mean 'Don't say it.'

Question: I color code all my info. I wrote 'gay son' in green. Green means go, so I know to go ahead and shut up about it. Orange means 'Orange you glad you didn't bring it up?' Most colors mean 'Don't say it.'
Answer: How is Tom, the homosexual sophomore?

Question: How is Tom, the homosexual sophomore?
Answer: I wanted to start a company, not a war. Because in a war, you always fight those you are closest to. And the great tragedy of the civil war is that brother fought against brother. For what? What purpose did that serve? Apart from abolishing slavery? In that case, war was the right choice. This doesn't feel as important though. That's just how the world works, I guess.

Question: I wanted to start a company, not a war. Because in a war, you always fight those you are closest to. And the great tragedy of the civil war is that brother fought against brother. For what? What purpose did that serve? Apart from abolishing slavery? In that case, war was the right choice. This doesn't feel as important though. That's just how the world works, I guess.
Answer: He gives me leads and I take the leads from him and in exchange it makes him feel good. And if a friend can't make you feel good, then I don't want any friends. Except Dwight, because he is our only source of fertile leads.

Question: Uncle Dave?
Answer: He's undercutting us big time. He's actually taking a loss and paying the difference out of pocket.

Question: When are you ever responsible for your actions?
Answer: Get off my ass, you hag.

Question: Who is that knocking on my taste buds? Why, it's Mr. Lemon. Hmmm, nice to meet you.
Answer: It's good. But won't it feel weird cutting into a cross?

Question: It's good. But won't it feel weird cutting into a cross?
Answer: Don't think of it as a cross in the Judeo-Christian sense, think of it more as a symbol of your lives crossing in marriage.

Question: Are they looking at me?
Answer: Who?

Question: Who?
Answer: Everyone. Everyone just keeps looking at me.

Question: Are you sure?
Answer: Will you just talk to them, please? Pam just knew!

Question: Will you just talk to them, please? Pam just knew!
Answer: It's 4:30 in the morning.  Do you know where your kids are?  If you are Ryan's parents or Pam's parents or my parents, you do.  They're gonna be in this van.  With me.  Who am I?  Nothing to fear.  I am just a 44 year old guy with a paper route.

Question: It's 4:30 in the morning.  Do you know where your kids are?  If you are Ryan's parents or Pam's parents or my parents, you do.  They're gonna be in this van.  With me.  Who am I?  Nothing to fear.  I am just a 44 year old guy with a paper route.
Answer: [honking horn] Time to make the donuts. [laughs and drives away as Ryan tries to get in the van]  Come on.  Whoa! No, I promise I won't do it again.  Come on.  [does it again] De-nied!

Question: You didn't happen to bring any coffee, did you, Michael?
Answer: Milk and sugar.

Question: Oh, awesome.  You're a life saver.  [drinks from coffee cup] Wait, is this just milk and sugar?
Answer: That's what I said.

Question: Do you drink this every day?
Answer: Every morning.

Question: Okay, who covers Bans Pet Grooming?
Answer: Oh, they're my client.

Question: What are we supposed to do?  They keep undercutting us on price.
Answer: I don't want to hear excuses.  I want to see improvements.  This is unacceptable.

Question: Why are you telling me this?
Answer: I just think the bar should be lower for a newbie.

Question: Is this something you really want to have said?
Answer: I don't want to have said that.  But I think it's important that you know it.

Question: You know what we need?  We need some couches in here.
Answer: Michael, we should really consider getting a delivery guy.

Question: Oh, you know what you would love? Is if we built a loft.
Answer: Why would I love that? Can we afford a delivery guy?

Question: Why would I love that? Can we afford a delivery guy?
Answer: Like in a dorm room.  You put your desk underneath, you have your loft up top.  You can sleep up top.

Question: Would you let Charles know that David is here, please?  Jim, hey.
Answer: Hey, David.

Question: There he is. There he is.  How was the trip up?
Answer: A lot better than a month at the Scranton Radisson, I'm sure.

Question: Okay?
Answer: Maybe, and I don't know, if you had just returned Michael's call none of us would've lost clients.

Question: I've been wondering that myself lately.  We're just gonna get started, we're gonna figure this out. Rest assured.  Jim, can you come in with us please?
Answer: Uh, Jim hold on. [whispers] You know, David, uh, Dwight's been my guy.  Okay?

Question: Uh, Jim hold on. [whispers] You know, David, uh, Dwight's been my guy.  Okay?
Answer: Hmm.

Question: How much can we afford to pay a delivery guy?
Answer: Well, if these numbers you gave me are correct--

Question: Why do you think Staples and Dunder Mifflin can't match your prices?
Answer: Corporate greed?

Question: Corporate greed?
Answer: Look, our price model is fine. I reviewed the numbers myself.  Over time with enough volume, we become profitable.

Question: Did it help?
Answer: Hi, Jerry.  Michael Scott.  Well, this is slightly embarrassing. [laughs] Um, I'm going to have to... ask you to pay me a little bit more money for that delivery we dropped off yesterday.  Yeah. We did. We got the check, but we're just going to need a much, much bigger check.

Question: Now, would corporate approve a temporary price reduction for returning customers?
Answer: God, no.

Question: Really? Does he do good work or--
Answer: [scoffs] No, Jim. I use a bad apiarist. [sighs]

Question: Okay.  Hey, Dwight.  Can I talk to you?
Answer: Sure thing.

Question: You're just out of business?
Answer: We have maybe a month.  I don't know what I'm gonna do.

Question: Good, right?  Hello.
Answer: [over phone] Idiot, we're starting back up.  This is Dwight, by the way.

Question: Did I ever tell you about the day that Steve Martin died?
Answer: Steve Martin's not dead, Michael.

Question: You want to hear something sad?
Answer: I would love that.

Question: Really?
Answer: I went to Fort Lauderdale.

Question: Was it nice?
Answer: Yeah, it was amazing.  There was a great Pad Thai place, though.

Question: Now, this is the projection over three months?
Answer: We still have the inventory sitting-- [everyone starts chattering at once]

Question: Let me float something out there, okay?  Can I just say-- can I say something?
Answer: Yeah, yeah.

Question: What is wrong with you?
Answer: Jim, you're-- you're pretty close with him.  You think they'd be up for hearing an offer?

Question: Jim, you're-- you're pretty close with him.  You think they'd be up for hearing an offer?
Answer: Oh, I don't know. You know, they've taken a good deal of clients, so--

Question: You know what?  Why don't I do it, okay? Michael adores me.  I'm the man for this job.  Charles, you got my back on this?
Answer: No, Jim... I think you should go.

Question: [knocking on door] Hmm?
Answer: Hey, can I talk to you guys for a second?

Question: Hey, can I talk to you guys for a second?
Answer: We're not hiring, Jim.

Question: You know I love a good guessing game, but why don't I just tell you what I'm here for?  Turns out you guys have made a pretty big dent in the Dunder Mifflin sales.
Answer: Oh, that's nice.

Question: Seriously?  Are you being serious?
Answer: He's bluffing, Pam.

Question: Never accept their first offer.  What is your second offer?
Are you kidding me?  That is insultingly low.  I don't even want to hear what your first offer was.
Answer: What do you hear?

Question: What do you hear?
Answer: [mumbles]

Question: Okay, now I don't know that I can get this. I do have to go to the board for approval. How's about $60,000.  Hmm?  $60,0000.  Michael?
Answer: [stutters] We'll have to talk--

Question: What?
Answer: We'll have to talk about this.

Question: Are you kidding me?
Answer: Well, Jerry, the one who got away.  May I ask why you're leaving the Michael Scott Paper Company?  Really?  Please hold.  [gets up and runs to kitchen]  Charles.

Question: Well, Jerry, the one who got away.  May I ask why you're leaving the Michael Scott Paper Company?  Really?  Please hold.  [gets up and runs to kitchen]  Charles.
Answer: Dwight.

Question: May I have your attention?  The Michael Scott Paper Company is broke.
Answer: What?  How'd you hear that?

Question: What?  How'd you hear that?
Answer: They've been calling all of their clients and begging them to pay more money.  That can only mean one thing.  They're desperate.  Which can only mean one thing.  They're total failures.

Question: No, I mean, great detective work.  'Cause this must be the first case you've ever cracked, right?
Answer: You don't crack a case.  That has pejorative connotation.  That's like calling a policeman a cop.  You solve a case, and yes, I've solved plenty.

Question: So how long can they stay viable?
Answer: What are your top five cases?

Question: What are your top five cases?
Answer: I'm gonna answer Charles first.

Question: Because you have embarrassed me for the last time today.  Got it?
Answer: I'm not-- I'm not following you.

Question: So you've thought it over, yes, and you accept our offer.  We can finally put this whole thing behind us?  Hmm?
Answer: No.

Question: Can you give us another minute please?
Answer: Yeah.

Question: How could you do this to me, Michael?  You just cost me $60,000.
Answer: Why are you assuming you'd get the whole thing?

Question: Why are you assuming you'd get the whole thing?
Answer: It's a lot of money, okay.  But we need money coming in every week.  We need jobs.  Wouldn't you rather have a fishing pole than a fish?

Question: It's a lot of money, okay.  But we need money coming in every week.  We need jobs.  Wouldn't you rather have a fishing pole than a fish?
Answer: I would rather have $60,000, honestly.

Question: Agreed?
Answer: Agreed.  But that's all, okay.

Question: Shut up, shut up.  Hello?
Answer: I want my old job back.  I want my old parking space back.  I want a Sebring.

Question: Do you realize what you're asking for here?  You're talking about salary plus health benefits--
Answer: And dental this time.

Question: Okay.  Deal.  Okay?
Answer: Can we have the room please?

Question: Can we have the room please?
Answer: Yeah. [David and Charles leave room, Michael shuts the door and closes the blinds]

Question: Yes! Can you believe it?  That's what I'm talking about!
Answer: There are certain defining moments in a person's life.  The day he is born.  The day he grows hair.  The day he starts a business. And the day he sells that business back to Dunder Mifflin.  What have I learned from all of this?  It is far too early to tell.  I just know that I am flying high and I don't even want to think about it.  I just want to enjoy it.

Question: There are certain defining moments in a person's life.  The day he is born.  The day he grows hair.  The day he starts a business. And the day he sells that business back to Dunder Mifflin.  What have I learned from all of this?  It is far too early to tell.  I just know that I am flying high and I don't even want to think about it.  I just want to enjoy it.
Answer: Hey, guys--

Question: Someone is returning!  He started his own company, and now he's back.  Who could it be? I'll give you a hint.  He is a man.  A man you have missed with all your heart.  A man who has ruined all other men for you.  Who is it?
Answer: [whispering] Who is it?

Question: [whispering] Who is it?
Answer: [whispering] Who is it?

Question: [whispering] Who is it?
Answer: [whispering] It's Michael Scott.  [applause; Michael jumps through sign] Hold it up.  Conference room, five minutes.

Question: Well, I guess the first order of business is to welcome back me, and Pam and Ryan.  [scattered applause] And how about casual Friday again, huh?  Reinstituting casual Friday?  You all look great.  What I want to do right now is try something a little different.  I'm going to throw it out there, starting with this meeting.  I want you guys to run it.  I want you to say whatever you want,  take it away.  Your meeting.
Answer: [after a few moments of silence]  Wh--what are you doing?

Question: [after a few moments of silence]  Wh--what are you doing?
Answer: If there is something that you would like to say as a group, then by all means, you may say it to me right now.

Question: Can you give us a hint?
Answer: When I needed salespeople for my new paper company,  everyone here turned their back on me.  Am I going to ask them to beg for forgiveness?  No. Am I going to ask for big, crying apology? No.  Am I going to ask them to slit their wrists for me? No.  I just want a tiny, microscopic version of that.

Question: When I needed salespeople for my new paper company,  everyone here turned their back on me.  Am I going to ask them to beg for forgiveness?  No. Am I going to ask for big, crying apology? No.  Am I going to ask them to slit their wrists for me? No.  I just want a tiny, microscopic version of that.
Answer: Oscar, what were you going to say?

Question: Oscar, what were you going to say?
Answer: Nothing.  I didn't say anything.

Question: Do I still have a job here?
Answer: Not important. [everyone mutters] Okay, alright.  Yes. Yes, you have a job.  Frankly, you have a job because Ryan and Pam are starting with us as salesmen.

Question: Wait, what?
Answer: How is that going to work?

Question: How is that going to work?
Answer: It's going to work very smoothly, because Pam and Ryan are bringing over a ton of clients from Michael Scott Paper Company and--

Question: Yeah , aren't we getting those clients back?
Answer: No, you lost those clients.

Question: Okay, Dwight.  Let me explain something to you.  I set the rules and you follow them.  Blindly. Okay?   And if you have a problem with that then you can talk to our complaint department.  It's a trash can.
Answer: [to Ryan] Don't fall in love with me, kid.

Question: [laughs]  Boscov's at the Steamtown Mall?
Answer: It sure looked good on the mannequin.

Question: What?
Answer: Isn't that what you said to a bunch of my clients when you were stealing them?  That I didn't have enough time for them?

Question: Isn't that what you said to a bunch of my clients when you were stealing them?  That I didn't have enough time for them?
Answer: Oh, I, um...

Question: Can't you just not look at his feet?
Answer: Excuse me? Oh. You're so educated, aren't you Toby?  So trained to deal with a hysterical woman.  I don't want to look at his feet.  [storms off] Do your job!

Question: Excuse me? Oh. You're so educated, aren't you Toby?  So trained to deal with a hysterical woman.  I don't want to look at his feet.  [storms off] Do your job!
Answer: Well, I was in the Seminary for a year and dropped out 'cause I wanted to have sex with this girl, Cathy.  Followed her to Scranton.  Took the first job I could find in H.R.  Later she divorced me.  So no, I wouldn't say I have a passion for H.R.

Question: Okay, what are you still doing at your desk?
Answer: What are you still doing not at your desk?

Question: What are you still doing not at your desk?
Answer: Did you even read the memo?

Question: Did you even read the memo?
Answer: All my files are now in reverse alphabetical order--

Question: We're in crisis mode here, do you understand?  The two unqualified so-called salespeople are being favored because they all failed together.  And frankly, I'm not convinced that Michael and Pam didn't have a thing going while they were gone.
Answer: Can I address that?

Question: Can I address that?
Answer: No, you're too close.

Question: Stanley, how do you feel about those two taking your clients?
Answer: It's not right.  I don't like it.

Question: Her face is okay, but-- Jesus!  What --what are you doing here?
Answer: I don't know.  I saw a crowd.  I thought there might be a dogfight or something--

Question: Of course.  What is like a hostage?
Answer: Excellent question.

Question: Can I just say something?  I know that tempers are high, but I think the best way to handle this might be to just talk to Michael directly.
Answer: Oh.  Well, that--that's a great idea, Jim.  Oh, I totally see your point.  Okay, we'll talk to Michael directly.  So uh,  meeting is over, I guess.  I'll see everyone upstairs.

Question: I do?  Well--Where is that bowl?
Answer: Hey, you have a second?

Question: Hey, you have a second?
Answer: Michael Scott Paper Company only.

Question: Against who?
Answer: You.  Us.

Question: What?
Answer: It's gotta be because they all want their clients.

Question: It's crazy what's going on out there today, huh?
Answer: I know.  Yeah, it's...kinda--

Question: Want to play a game?
Answer: Hey gang. Where you been?

Question: Hey gang. Where you been?
Answer: Lunch.

Question: Where'd you eat?
Answer: A restaurant.

Question: What'd you have, Stanley?
Answer: I had a salmon salad.  With water, no ice.  I was going to get a soda, but the waiter talked me out of it.  Her name was Flo, she had black hair.

Question: So since you guys already ate, you won't be eating the stuff you brought with you for lunch, will you?  [walks into kitchen] Oh, wow, Stanley.  Is that egg salad?  Andy brought some salmon.
Answer: That looks great.

Question: Dwight, is that a meat sandwich?  You guys hungry?
Answer: I can eat.

Question: Mom. What kind of sauce is on your salmon?
Answer: Dijonnaise.

Question: Hey, Meredith.  Can I talk to you privately for a second?
Answer: About what?

Question: About what?
Answer: Your outfit.

Question: What? What's wrong with my outfit?
Answer: You--you might consider pulling it down a touch.  It's ri--it's riding up a little high.

Question: A bunch of prudes.  You know, Oscar's allowed to wear sandals,  but I'm not allowed to wear open-toed shoes?  [pulls down dress, office gasps]  Is that how it goes?
Answer: Meredith, your boob is out.

Question: Dammit, Meredith, where are your panties?
Answer: It's casual day.  Happy?  [bends over to get a file, exposing herself to the office]

Question: It's casual day.  Happy?  [bends over to get a file, exposing herself to the office]
Answer: [playing chess with Jim]  No. IF you do that, I'm gonna do that.  IF you do that, I'm gonna do that.  IF you do this, I'm gonna do that.

Question: Well, what if I just do this?
Answer: You don't want to do that.

Question: I'm sorry you feel that way, Mr. Bart.  Is there anything I can do to make things better?
Answer: Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa.  Give me the phone.  Give me the phone.

Question: Who let this boy on the phone?
Answer: Ah! Mr. Bart!  Ugh! [slams phone down[ I cannot believe you lost that account.  He was my client for ten years!

Question: You're a secretary! What do you know?
Answer: Okay.

Question: Hey, hey guys.  You know what I want you to do?  Shake hands, get over it.  That was not a shake, Dwight.
Answer: We want our clients back or we quit, Michael.

Question: Who quits?
Answer: Me.

Question: You want us to apologize to you?
Answer: Yes I do.

Question: Gasp.  Are you talking about a secret meeting?
Answer: Whatever you guys did earlier.

Question: Just do it, okay?
Answer: I'll do--

Question: Are you kidding me?
Answer: Deceit does not come easy to me.

Question: Are you giving us our clients back?
Answer: If we could just focus and go down the line, and everyone would say,  'apology accepted', I think we would all feel better.  And then we can break out  my gift to you--complimentary white chocolate bark.

Question: So?
Answer: Fine, have your clients.  I can see that's what you wanted all along.  [everyone mutters 'okay'] However, I rescind my apology.

Question: What'd I tell you about building forts in my warehouse?
Answer: Michael gave all of our clients back to their old salespeople, so now there's not enough for both me and Pam to stay on.

Question: If you really think that, will you tell that to Michael?  That would go a long way coming from you.
Answer: Yeah.

Question: Then why would you want to set me up with your daughter?
Answer: I don't know.

Question: Jim. Can I talk to you for a minute?
Answer: Sure.  Let me just finish this turn.

Question: Eh, she's nice, I guess.  You know what?  Best thing to do, Pros and Cons list.
Answer: Pro for Ryan, he went to business school, he's my number one choice.

Question: I have a very difficult decision to make.  It's like last week I was at the video store.  Do I rent Devil Wears Prada again? Or do I finally get around to seeing Sophie's Choice?  It is what you would call a classic difficult decision.
Answer: You don't understand clothing, Toby.  You're dressed like this amorphous blob of khaki.

Question: Listen up, Flenderson.  You're being weak and ineffectual.  I'm cowboying this meeting, okay?  Here are the new rules.  Earth tones only.  Also, women are forbidden to wear pants.
Answer: All right, come.  Sit down, Dwight.

Question: Ooh, where has this guy been?
Answer: Casual Fridays are cancelled.  [everyone protests]  Let's just not do it anymore.

Question: Pam, can you come in here, please?  Have a seat.  [clears throat] Well, there's no easy way of saying this.  So I think I will just...drag it out.  Since the dawn of time there has been--
Answer: Just tell me.

Question: Okay, I get it. [Michael laughs] Why are you giggling?  Is this a joke?  [Michael continues to laugh] Michael, is this-- did I get the job?
Answer: [laughing] Yes, you did.

Question: I did?
Answer: Yep.

Question: For real, you're not kidding?
Answer: No, you--no.

Question: I did?
Answer: No, you're the best person for the job.  You're going to be great.

Question: Oh, really?
Answer: Yeah.  'Cause you said I didn't

Question: What about Ryan?
Answer: I don't know, I offered him his temp job back.  We'll see.  He was not happy at all when I offered him this job and then I told him he didn't get the job, so--

Question: Oh! What's our receptionists name?
Answer: Erin.

Question: Could you send her in?
Answer: [opens door] Erin.  Michael wants to see you.

Question: This is very difficult to say, but no one here like you in the office and we are going to have to let you go.  [pick up phone] Hank, could you come up here please?  Hank is our security guard--
Answer: Oh, I can go.

Question: Do they not like me, though?
Answer: I don't know, actually.

Question: Guys, I'm scared. I'm really scared. I think I'm growing into a giant. Because look at this normal sized coffee cup. Looks so tiny in my giant hand now. Anybody want to go to lunch with me later on?
Answer: I do.

Question: Okay. How about a woman? Pam?
Answer: Oh, I can't do lunch. I was just sending you an email. Jim and I need to leave early today to meet with our contractor.

Question: Oh, really? Ok.
Answer: Just sent it.

Question: What about the rest of you? [complete silence]
Answer: At Dunder-Mifflin there is a very strict no lunch with the boss policy and I don't know who instituted it. I think it started right after my predecessor stepped down, but at the Michael Scott Paper Company I really enjoyed having lunch with Pam and Ryan everyday. So, rules be damned, I wanna have lunch with these people.

Question: Who else? Who else? Ryan?
Answer: I don't do lunch. I'm eating five small meals a day now.

Question: Ok. Anyone? Anyone? At all? Accounting? I am accounting on you to go to lunch with me.
Answer: No. I don't want to stay late to have a two hour lunch.

Question: What?
Answer: Work.

Question: Ugh! God! What happened to you people? [talking like a robot] We are just office drones. We are office drones. All we do is work... is work.
Answer: If you don't take out his battery, he just keeps going all day.

Question: Hi, guys. How you doing?
Answer: Erin, how many times do I have to tell you? It is not necessary for you to ask us how we are doing every time you interact with us.

Question: Erin, how many times do I have to tell you? It is not necessary for you to ask us how we are doing every time you interact with us.
Answer: Right. I'm sorry.

Question: [sighs] Now, how can I help you?
Answer: Did somebody here leave a map in the printer to Youngstown, Ohio?

Question: Did somebody here leave a map in the printer to Youngstown, Ohio?
Answer: Attention, office. Who here is planning a trip to Youngstown, Ohio? I will take your silence to mean that you are all hiding something. This location is the Superior Court -

Question: Attention, office. Who here is planning a trip to Youngstown, Ohio? I will take your silence to mean that you are all hiding something. This location is the Superior Court -
Answer: So someone is going to a court. Big deal.

Question: Ok. Right. Oh, so this morning we are having breakfast together and I just looked up from my cereal and I said, ' You know what I want to do today? I want to marry you.'
Answer: I had just woken up. I didn't look cute. That's how I knew he meant it.

Question: Michael? Michael sorry to bother you. Are you going to be working down here? Do you want these down here now?
Answer: No work. No work. No work. I come in here to release frustration. Ooh. Ah. Ah. Ah. Ooh.

Question: Now you got it. Hey, you want some espresso?

Question: Andy's afwaid?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Are you all afwaid?

Question: What?
Answer: Funk is the problem and the solution.

Question: So, like, a disco cafe?
Answer: Wha - No. No. Not even close. I can't force you to go down but I can entice you. I'm gonna be down there. Erin will be down there from time to time... and all-you-can-eat espresso.

Question: [to Michael] Is there a cookie?

Question: Aw, what the hell? [goes to Vance Refrigeration] Hi, Jessica. Is Bob in?

Question: It's pretty important. He wouldn't want to be disturbed. Can I give him a message before he gets off?

Question: Phyllis?

Question: What happened to Phyllis?

Question: Can you please go back to work instead of masterminding these situations were in we hurt ourselves?

Question: You all took a life here today. you did. The life of the party. Erin?

Question: Where?

Question: Are those staples?

Question: What dance competition? I was just dancin' casual with my friends, y'all.

Question: Really?
Answer: Yeah. At least for one more dance.

Question: Really?
Answer: Yeah.

Question: Would you like to dance?
Answer: No. [Camera pans to down to show her swinging her foot to the music]

Question: I didn't think I did. How's everything going?

Answer: It is hard to imagine you playing softball.

Answer: The girls school?

Question: The girls school?

Question: [whispering] Okay, I'm gonna go in there and change the computer. Are you sure you can change his watch?
Answer: [whispering] I can do it.

Question: [whispering] What do you need from me?

Question: [wakes up, joins in with the laughter] Uh oh. What's so funny?

Question: [at company picnic] All right, you ready for this?

Question: Are you blind?!

Question: Can you see things with your eyeballs?!

Question: Back off, Dwight. [serves] Hyuh! [the opposing team misses the ball, the Scranton team cheers] What?

Question: Are you ready to play SlumDunder Mifflinaire?

Question: That is correct! [both run to another side of the stage, acting out a different scene] How did you know that?! [pantomimes electrocuting Michael]

Answer: Two hundred and fifty dollars is more money than I've ever seen in my life. I will say, C, a gun. He shot himself in the head.

Question: The economic downturn has been difficult recently, forcing the closures of both Camden and Yonkers, to be followed soon by what other branch? For five-hundred thousand dollars, is it A.) Scranton, B.) Buffalo, C.) Utica, or D.) toothbrush!

Question: [pantomimes biting off Michael's fingers, Michael screams] How did you know that?!

Question: David, is this true?

Question: Are we losing our jobs or not, David?

Answer: [whispers] I guess not.

Question: And?
Answer: We're- we're closing the Buffalo branch.

Question: How could you possibly think that the right way to announce a branch closing was in a comedy sketch at the company picnic?

Question: What about the fact that they're here today? What about that? That didn't throw up any alarms? No, Michael needed a little bit for his comedy sketch, and he thought, 'oh, this would be really funny.'

Question: Damn it, Michael, I told you that in confidence. Now I have to go over and deal with these employees and their families. A little boy just walked up to me and said, 'is my daddy gonna have a job by Christmas?'

Question: How do you figure?

Question: Here's an accounting question for you: what does one fiance plus one lover equal? Answer: one whore.

Question: What? She is sitting there, casting aspersions-

Question: You all right?

Question: You sure?

Question: I don't know. You know, this is a company picnic, so technically that is a company injury, you know? Safest thing to do is get that examined, right David?

Question: All right, you know what? You're just trying to get rid of our best player.

Question: How do you think it went before the Buffalo thing?

Question: How long will that take?

Question: I'm sorry, can we just hurry this up? I've got a game to get back to.

Question: What'd you think?

Question: Yeah, it looks like Pam won't make it back. Okay?

[laughs] Ohh! [goes back into the room to hug Pam]

Question: [hands Dwight a cup of water] There you go. Is there anything else I can do?

Question: [chugs water, throws away cup] Yes. Umm... see those files behind Kevin's desk?
Answer: [nods] Mm hmm.

Question: [to Oscar, motioning to male intern and female intern] Think she did him?

Question: [entering break room] Who's getting married?
Answer: Nobody.

Question: Did everybody know about this but me?

Question: What are you gonna do about it? There's no shotgun, so... free at last, free at last!

Question: [annoyed] How do you know this?
Answer: [still typing] People tell me things. I guess I have a face you can trust. I think it's because of my low cheekbones. And... boom. [finishes typing, turns to face Michael] Okay, what is it, what can't I guess?

Question: [still typing] People tell me things. I guess I have a face you can trust. I think it's because of my low cheekbones. And... boom. [finishes typing, turns to face Michael] Okay, what is it, what can't I guess?
Answer: I hate, hate, hate being left out. Whether it's not being picked for a team, or being picked for a team and showing up and realizing the team doesn't exist. Or that the sport doesn't exist? I should've known. Poopball?

Question: I hate, hate, hate being left out. Whether it's not being picked for a team, or being picked for a team and showing up and realizing the team doesn't exist. Or that the sport doesn't exist? I should've known. Poopball?
Answer: [to Maurie, the Asian intern] Man, I know how you feel. Third wheel. I have been the third wheel so many times in my life. My mom told me something once that made me feel a lot better. She said 'The third wheel is what makes it a tricycle.'

Question: What are you talking about?
Answer: I'm talking about your group date with Megan and Eric.

Question: At Tink's?
Answer: Yes

Question: How'd you know about that?
Answer: Well...

Question: Did Stanley tell you?
Answer: [confused] Stanley was on your group date?

Question: [confused] Stanley was on your group date?
Answer: No, Stanley was with his wife. I waved at him, but he didn't wave back.

Question: [laughs] Does anybody else know about this?
Answer: No.

Question: So, what is the scuttlebutt? Anybody hear anything?
Answer: [stare blankly at Michael]

Question: Nothing? Well I got a little somethin' somethin'. I don't know if I should say...
Answer: Just keep it to yourself then.

Question: Who?
Answer: Teri, Stanley's wife. She's at an interior decorating expo in Philly. Stanley hates crowds, kids, and music. I think you should check your facts.

Question: What are you talking about?
Answer: Stanley's wife is out of town.

Question: Oh, was he? Well who, his sister?
Answer: [chuckles]

Question: Drugs?
Answer: Making out.

Question: WHAT??
Answer: I am very happy right now. Thrilled perhaps, to be part of the office, to be part of the conversation. When you have somebody's attenton, and their eyes are lighting up because they are very interested in what you have to say, [Michael is seen whispering to Jim, then Pam] that is a great feeling, and I experienced that firsthand today. It is wonderful to be the center of attention.

Question: No... no. He's holding a pencil. He could be doing a crossword puzzle with that pencil. What's that letter, right there? Same letter here and here. What haven't you guessed?
Answer: T.

Question: [opening blinds as Stanley walks past] Hey, Stanley! Where you goin', big guy? Up to no good?

Question: I'm meeting a client. Do you have a problem with that?
Answer: No, no, no, no. I just had a quick question for you. I'm casting a movie and I'm looking for a woman who can dance, beautiful woman. Do you know anybody?

Question: No, no, no, no. I just had a quick question for you. I'm casting a movie and I'm looking for a woman who can dance, beautiful woman. Do you know anybody?
Answer: Goodbye. [walks away]

Question: [giddy, whispering] Did you hear Stanley's having an affair?
Answer: I did. From you. You gotta stop telling people.

Question: Do you know if it's true? Do you have any idea? Because you might be ruining his life.
Answer: [stares at Jim silently, then walks away]

Answer: [as Michael gets in car] That is ridiculous. Of course not, why would you think that?

Question: [as Michael gets in car] That is ridiculous. Of course not, why would you think that?
Answer: So It's not true. Okay, well... ahhh, those interns, they told me they saw you at a club, and they all said it was you, it was clearly just... racial profiling gossip.

Question: Wait, hold, hold, hold... so it IS true?
Answer: Yeah, but Michael, I'm going to go break it off. That's where I'm headed right now. I swear.

Question: Did you hear about Angela? That's pretty weird.

Question: Yeah... what do you mean exactly?
Answer: Well, the fact that she is apparently dating an 81-year-old billionaire. Owns a Quizno's on the turnpike.

Question: Uh huh. [gestures to Kevin to keep it quiet] Alright?
Answer: How do you un-tell something? You can't. You can't put words back in your mouth. What you can do is spread false gossip so that people think that everything that's been said is untrue, including 'Stanley is having an affair.' It's like the end of Spartacus. I've seen that movie half a dozen times, and I still don't know who the real Spartacus is, and that is what makes that movie a classic whodunit.

Question: How do you un-tell something? You can't. You can't put words back in your mouth. Question: [to Oscar in break room] Did you hear the rumor about me? That I'm gay?

I left my cell phone here.

Question: We're not fired?

Question: You called Bob?
Answer: I'm sorry,

Question: You okay baby?

Question: Dunder Mifflin is about to be sold. But first an investment banker has to drop by and sign off on our branch. And... I'm... pretty nervous about it. And... I'm... making some cosmetic tweaks to help create a more appealing environment. Is that dishonest? Well, think of it this way: when you look in the mirror and you see your push-up bra and your fake eyelashes and your make-up and your press-on nails; the principles that I am applying to the office are the same ones that have made Lady Gaga a star... or any number of drag queens.
Answer: Hi -

Question: [entering on a Segway Scooter] I see you've met Computron, our virtual helper. I'm Michael Scott. Welcome. Welcome. Computron is just one of the many modern devices that I have incorporated into the office. Watch this. Computron?
Answer: Yes.

Question: What is the world's largest ocean?
Answer: Calculating. Calculating. Pacific!

Question: Pacific Ocean. Pretty cool, huh?
Answer: Great news, Michael. We're now the official paper supplier of the NFL.

Question: For the record? Not on board with fake Stanley... although, I get it.

Question: - since you made the trip out. And I got us reservations at Cooper's Seafood. You like lobster? You've had lobster before, right?

Question: Are you calling me wrong?

Answer: Sorry. Hey, Toby Flenderson. Nice to meet you. How can I help?

Question: Sorry. Hey, Toby Flenderson. Nice to meet you. How can I help?

Question: Um, are there any outstanding liability issues to be aware of?

Question: So, the staff?

Question: In what way?
Answer: You know, uh, what does it mean to be happy. [shakes head] Keep philosophers busy for awhile.

Question: So... generally?
Answer: Yes.

Question: What about non-safety issues, in terms of liability? Sexual harassment. Anything like that?
Answer: Oh, I don't know.

Question: Hey, Tobes. Whatcha doin'? Whatcha guys talkin' about?

Question: HR stuff? [pulls up a chair] HR Pufnstuf. Right up my alley. [pointing to Eric's notes] What is that? What kind of stuff is that?

Question: Talkin' bout, uh, what?

Question: This is a building where friends become lovers and lovers become sexually interactive. [to Toby] Right? Would you agree with that?
Answer: Michael, this is really inappropriate to talk about.

Question: I feel very sorry for that banker because he has to evaluate what we are worth. He has to decide what we are capable of and how do you do that? What is Jim capable of... or Pam... or Kevin? [clip montage over Daryl's Dunder Mifflin jingle]
Answer: I don't care if he goes and files a report and says that we're nothing special because I think our future is very bright. We have only just begun.

Question: Computron, I'm gonna pull your plug. Ok? Buddy?

Question: What?
Answer: The Electric City. Scranton!

Question: What?
Answer: The Electric City. Lazy Scranton, the Electric City. They call it that 'cause of the electricity. The city's laid out from East to West and our public parks are libraries are truly the best. Call poison control if you're bitten by a spider.

Question: What?
Answer: The Electric City. Scranton!

Question: What?
Answer: The Electric City. Scranton!

Question: What?
Answer: The Electric City. Scranton!

Question: What?
Answer: The Electric City. Scranton!

Answer: Ugh.

Question: Oh, yeah. [clapping and chanting] I got a big box, yes I do. I got a big box how 'bout you? [points to Erin]
Answer: [clapping] I got a big box, yes I do. I got a big box how 'bout you? [points to Oscar]

Question: [clapping] I got a big box, yes I do. I got a big box how 'bout you? [points to Oscar]

Answer: Guys, um, who's Gabe? This note says to put the box aside for Gabe Lewis, who's coming tomorrow?

Question: Guys, um, who's Gabe? This note says to put the box aside for Gabe Lewis, who's coming tomorrow?

Question: Have you tried making everything smaller?

Question: Alright, he's on his way up. Okay. Are we ready?

Question: Welcome. Scranton hot dog from Scranton?

Question: We're very excited too, aren't we guys? Right?

Question: You sure it's saber?

Question: So you've just been bought by Sabre. You've probably got a lot of questions. Hi. I'm Christian Slater. What's it like to work for Sabre? Let's find out together. Working at Sabre means taking on the challenge of the road that rises to meet you. Sabre is respecting the past, but opening a window to the future. Have you ever tasted a rainbow? At Sabre, you will.

Question: [Christian Slater impression] So you've been shown a nonsensical video. You're probably wondering, 'What's going on?' Well, you're not alone.
Answer: Wow. Really terrific.

Question: Hey, who the hell's going through our stuff?

Question: Ok, did everyone get one? With these bottles, we eliminate the need for plastic water bottles, which are the scourge of the environment.

Answer: Little cups? Like paper or plastic or... ?

Question: Little cups? Like paper or plastic or... ?
Answer: I don't know what they're made of.

Question: What?
Answer: Looks like we kicked it. [indicates water jug is empty]

Question: Which ones?
Answer: All of them.

Question: Well, I wish that I could do something, but it's kind of policy, you know? Above my pay grade. You know?
Answer: So maybe we should call. We should call someone. I could help. I'm good with bosses. Call one of the higher-ups?

Question: So maybe we should call. We should call someone. I could help. I'm good with bosses. Call one of the higher-ups?
Answer: You know what? Let me see what I can do.

Question: You know what? Let me see what I can do.

Question: There's a finger-painting station and a curly slide. Am I too old to go here?

Question: Oh. Adorable, right? [opens kiddie bathroom, sees man on toilet] I walked in on someone in the bathroom.

Question: What?

Question: Who? The -
Answer: I don't know. I don't know.

Question: The guy we're meeting with?
Answer: I don't know, I don't know.

Question: Turn me around. Now. [Michael starts to leave, Jo whistles] Hey, Buddy. Is it something I said?

Question: Aw, thank you. I've been working on it since I was a little girl. To, um, to what do I owe the pleasure of this videochat?

Question: Ok. I feel very strongly that you can't just come in here and change everything that people have been doing forever. Is Christian Slater back there? Because... he knows. He'd know what to do.

Question: Pam and Jim? Hey, I'm Jerry.

Question: Oh, so you saw it already?

Question: What if we just bring it up? We just put it out in the open?
Answer: That's the weirdest possible solution to the problem.

Question: I have come here today to talk to Mr. David Wallace about this whole thing going on with Sabre. [rings doorbell] He will know exactly what to do. He is not a big fan of me dropping by announced. But then again, who is? [loud drumming as door opens] Hey. Hi, sorry.
Answer: Michael.

Question: No, you kidding? Come on in. Come on.

Question: You hungry? I'm just having lunch.

Question: Huh? Hey. [continues drumming]

Question: Can I just stay here and never go back?

Question: No problem at all. This is great. So what are you guys up to?

Answer: Oh, no, sorry. Just, um, we're kind of planners. But we're also flexible too, so you know what? Maybe we can just discuss it when the time comes.

Question: Oh, no, sorry. Just, um, we're kind of planners. But we're also flexible too, so you know what? Maybe we can just discuss it when the time comes.
Answer: Yeah, if the time comes, we can discuss it.

Question: Is this because Jim walked in on you going to the bathroom?

Question: Seriously? You told her?
Answer: Did it? It might have come up while we were waiting for you.

Question: Did it? It might have come up while we were waiting for you.
Answer: And you - you thought that might have something to do with how the meeting is going?

Question: And you - you thought that might have something to do with how the meeting is going?

Question: Well, you didn't consider the fact that it might not be going super well just because it might not be going super well?
Answer: Nope. 'Cause we're really nice people but you don't seem to like us.

Question: I'm being perfectly pleasant. Did you ever consider that you might not be as charming as you think you are?
Answer: Oh, this coming from the guy who still uses a children's toilet? Why didn't you just lock the door, man?

Question: Oh, this coming from the guy who still uses a children's toilet? Why didn't you just lock the door, man?
Answer: It doesn't lock for the children's safety.

Question: Sabre is changing everything. [Michael and David sitting in hot tub] Site blockers. They don't let us use cups. So I started thinking, who could handle this? Who would know what to do? David Wallace would know what to do. What should I do, David Wallace?
Answer: I don't know. I mean, what can you do?

Question: I don't know. I mean, what can you do?

Question: Exactly. What are you thinking?
Answer: I, I - It's a tough one.

Question: Ok? You know how kids leave their toys everywhere? Okay. So this is a vacuum. It's like a shop-vac type of thing. [imitates vacuum] Teaches kids how to pick up their own toys. Right? Baseball gloves, hacky sacks, drumsticks. [sucking noise] Picks it up!
Answer: So the kid's making the noise to pick it up.
