Question: No, you?
Answer: Uh, no, actually. So nothing? No movies, or parties, or anything you might want to invite someone to?

Question: Uh, no, actually. So nothing? No movies, or parties, or anything you might want to invite someone to?
Answer: Nothing. It's wide open.

Question: The what?
Answer: Suck it. That's what it's called.

Question: Huh? Catchy. Kids'll love it.
Answer: Like it.

Answer: You know when people say getting fired was the best thing that ever happened to them? I feel sorry for those people. That's the best thing? Really? Ugh.

Question: You know when people say getting fired was the best thing that ever happened to them? I feel sorry for those people. That's the best thing? Really? Ugh.

Question: That's your toast?
Answer: No. This is my toast.  I think this whole thing with Sabre is going to work out. I have a very good feeling about it.

Question: Mm. Wow. That is metallicy. Ugh. That's like drinking a battery. Ah, really gets you in the fillings, doesn't it? Okay, anyway, welcome.
Answer: [singing] Well, it's a mess, what a mess. What you gonna do? You're going to take out your Suck It and you suck it. Suck it. Yeah, take out your Suck It and you suck it.

Question: [singing] Well, it's a mess, what a mess. What you gonna do? You're going to take out your Suck It and you suck it. Suck it. Yeah, take out your Suck It and you suck it.
Answer: Suck it!

Question: [on phone] Vancouver Court Hotel, how many I help you?
Answer: Hello Vancouver, this is Michael Scott calling from the United States of America!  I have a reservation in your fair city from February 12th to the 19th, first week of the Olympics.

Question: What?
Answer: [looking through Michael's email] I'm not seeing anything under 'confirmation.'

Question: Could it be under 'affirmation?' Cause you have thousands of those.
Answer: No. [to hotel employee on phone] We're trying to look it up right now.

Question: Uh, sir? A lot of people are trying to get last-minute reservations at hotels here for the Olympics, but we've been fully booked for months.
Answer: Well, I have been booked for three years, so you should have that. I've always heard that British Columbia is a very nice place, but I am not getting that from this conversation.

Question: Uh-huh. Seven nights in our street-view economy single?
Answer: That's it!

Question: Yeah, how may I help you Mr. Scott?
Answer: Alright, I would like to cancel my reservation, please.

Question: Today, Jo Bennett, the CEO from Sabre, is coming to see us here for the first time. She bought us sight unseen, like a mail-order bride, so she's gotta be kinda nervous. I mean, are we ugly? Are we smart? Are we cool? Are we too cool? Do we speak English?
Answer: [Jo Bennett enters with two humongous dogs, everyone stands to welcome her except Dwight] Why hello!

Question: Do you always stay seated when a lady enters the room?
Answer: I am treating you the same as a man, for whom I would also not stand. Unless it was the President. Or Judge Judy.

Question: [gesturing to Michael] I thought this guy was the manager?
Answer: Oh, he is. He's the co-manager, and that's the other co-manager.

Question: Two guys doing one job? We gotta do something about that!
Answer: Got some Valentine's cards for my coworkers and my bro-workers.

Question: What, no candy?
Answer: Valentine's Day, right around the corner. Erin and I have been on zero dates. So I got her a Valentine's Day card, but I didn't wanna seem 'too eager,' so I got cards for everyone in the whole office to kind of dilute it a little bit.

Question: This is knucklehead talk. I'm not gonna bite it, you know. You can't give me gravy and tell me it's jelly, because gravy ain't sweet! Is it, Jim?
Answer: I don't think so.

Question: Michael?
Answer: Forget the question...

Question: I... Why would you just say something like that?
Answer: Because, well, Jim. Where I'm from, two types of folk: those who ain't, and those who are knee-high on a grasshopper. Which type ain't you ain't? Ya'll come back now.

Question: Because, well, Jim. Where I'm from, two types of folk: those who ain't, and those who are knee-high on a grasshopper. Which type ain't you ain't? Ya'll come back now.
Answer: Do you even know what that means?

Question: Do you even know what that means?
Answer: Yes.

Question: [opening card] Oh, you did? Aw, a bird and a dog!
Answer: Yeah, well it's Snoopy and Woodstock.

Question: You named them?
Answer: Uh, Charles Schultz did. I thought it was relevant cause I got you all those birds for Christmas, remember?

Question: Uh, Charles Schultz did. I thought it was relevant cause I got you all those birds for Christmas, remember?
Answer: Uh, yeah I do remember. [reading card] Aw, they love each other.

Question: That's right, darlin', now you're the proud new owner of a Sabre handbook and my autobiography. Now, you all must be in a tizzy. I can see it on your faces, I mean, what's going on now? I mean, who owns Dunder Mifflin? Right? I mean, Sabre? What's that? Some company I've never heard of? Down in Tallahassee? Where is that? Near Mars?
Answer: No, we know. Texas!

Question: I don't think I'm gonna miss being manager. You know how some people say they're not in it for the money? Well, with all due respect to this job, I think I'm definitely in it for the money. And quite honestly, the women.
Answer: Hey, you got a second?

Question: Hey, you got a second?
Answer: Sure. You here to tell me that you think I would be a better manager and that you are sorry for being such a jerk?

Question: Sure. You here to tell me that you think I would be a better manager and that you are sorry for being such a jerk?

Question: What?
Answer: Exactly that. I think that you absolutely deserve the manager position more than I do.

Question: What? Really?
Answer: Yeah!

Question: What are you reading?
Answer: The Atlantic.

Question: Why, is there an untapped gay market?
Answer: Sabre has no caps on commissions. He can make a lot more money in sales.

Question: Manuel who?
Answer: Well, according to the manual, there is no cap on commissions. I have been hustled.

Question: Really? Aw, that is so sweet of you! But, I cannot accept, because I have been thinking about it, and I think I wanna go back to sales.
Answer: Really?

Question: Really?
Answer: Really.

Question: Why would you do that?
Answer: I'm turning myself in right now!

Question: Did you see Saw?
Answer: Of course I seesaw. Mose and I seesaw all the time.

Question: No, uh, the movie. Did you see the movie Saw?
Answer: Oh, yeah. Great film. Almost as fun as going on a seesaw.

Question: Could we lure him into an old warehouse or something?
Answer: I have an old barn!

Question: It's kinda smelly, but that might be a plus! And then what?
Answer: We do what they did in Saw! ... I mean, we don't kill him, obviously. I have a mask...

Question: Okay, that's your idea? Exactly like in the movie!? That is the most idiotic thing I have ever heard in my life!
Answer: Well suggest something else then! Don't just...

Question: He's supposed to cut his leg off? Think!
Answer: Don't just criticize my idea!

Question: How is that possible?
Answer: Well, in your old office there were all those ledges and extra space.

Question: Oh, yeah. Fine, fine. Leave it here. I have to make some sales anyway. Who should I call with my magic sales fingers? [Michael's phone rings] Michael Scott, head of sales.
Answer: [on phone] You gotta do something, man. You can't just sit there.

Question: Why don't you just let me handle the Tolkien references, okay dumb jock?
Answer: Well, I think he can be corrupted. Like Gollum.

Question: Who's hungry?
Answer: What is that?

Question: What is that?
Answer: It's ants on a log. Michael would always have me bring them in at 2:30 and say 'Who's hungry?'

Question: It's ants on a log. Michael would always have me bring them in at 2:30 and say 'Who's hungry?'
Answer: Oh. I'm fine. Thank you, though.

Question: Do you want me to spin you in your chair and make you dizzy?
Answer: Why would I wanna do that?

Question: Why would I wanna do that?
Answer: It's a thinking technique. All the top executives do it. It keeps the brain moving, and a spinning brain is a working brain.

Question: Why not? It's part of the sales experience.
Answer: It's not really 1992 anymore.

Question: I know, obsessed with me much?
Answer: Well, everyone got one.

Question: What did yours say?
Answer: Friends are worth sharing a doghouse with.

Question: It's no wonder that Andy gave Kelly such a romantic card. I can't compete with her. That girl can sing, and dance, and gets all of her clothes at the mall. And I feel like such a fool for thinking that Andy was only going after one girl, cause Andy Bernard is a playboy. And, why shouldn't he be? He's got it all.
Answer: Ho-ho. There he is, the IT guy. So you discovered the break room.

Question: Listen, I know you have to say that, but we got a little problem here. There is an employee named Jim Halpert, and he is doing some terrible things, okay? He is molesting people via the internet. And we need to stop him.
Answer: I think that you should call the cops.

Question: Are you... you threatening me?
Answer: Threatening you? No. [tries to crush an aluminum can, Dwight  crushes an apple]

Question: Threatening you? No. [tries to crush an aluminum can, Dwight  crushes an apple]
Answer: What is that smell? Do you smell that? What is that? Like a sulfur deposit under here?

Question: What is that smell? Do you smell that? What is that? Like a sulfur deposit under here?
Answer: Michael, stop.

Question: No, I'm serious, we don't have to put up... Is it the dogs?
Answer: Michael...

Question: Are you kidding me?
Answer: No.

Question: And you guys are okay with this?
Answer: She sent an email, so.

Question: Believe me, if I got that card? We'd be in the bathroom doin' it right... now.

Question: For the record, I fought this. Alright? And now, I'm not really sure what we do.

Question: Lethal Weapon?
Answer: That's it. I think we should do it the Lethal Weapon way.

Question: You two are grown-ass men. What do I have to do, fire you and get two people in here who don't need so much management?
Answer: What? What I'm saying...

Question: What? What I'm saying...
Answer: Michael's saying he's better at being manager, and I agree, cause he's a better people person, weirdly.

Question: And weirdly I'm a good dog person, right guys? [dogs go to him] See? They love me.

Question: [Erin leaves room] Excuse me? Everyone? Please check your emails, I just sent you the following message: 'Coworkers, you may have received a Valentine from me. Please understand this does not mean that I like you in any way.'
Answer: You don't even like us as friends?

Question: You don't even like us as friends?
Answer: Phyllis, you guys are like my closest friends. I just mean I don't like-like you.

Question: What are we, five?
Answer: Please don't read into this card. Yours in professionalism, Nard dog.'

Question: [entering with Erin] Um, why did I just receive a mass email from you that said that you don't like me? Do you realize how hard that makes me like you, Andy?
Answer: It's n-- that wasn't... I like someone else.

Question: Who?
Answer: It's not... Whether or not, you...

Question: Who, what?
Answer: Yeah, I guess Andy never liked Kelly. How about that?

Question: Yeah, I guess Andy never liked Kelly. How about that?
Answer: Oh, it smells good in here.

Question: Erin, what about my keyboard? [Erin hits a button on an electronic keyboard, playing a beat] Aw, so good to be home. How about a little Bosa Nova?
Answer: Oh! [hits another key, they awkwardly dance together]

Question: Well, well, well. Hm. Boss for, what was it? Oh, four and a half hours? New record. Low. Previous record? Henry Rosston. Boss for nine years, four months. And he only left because he had family matters to attend to and he [Jim dunks Dwight's tie in his coffee cup, Pam smiles] what? Michael!
Answer: [entering elevator with Ryan] I can't help but think that something we did made this possible.

Question: Oh temp, I like that. I'm going to engrave that into a piece of wood. Care to celebrate with a drink?
Answer: I would love to. [elevator doors close, then reopen in the lobby] Why not?

Question: I would love to. [elevator doors close, then reopen in the lobby] Why not?
Answer: Because! Martini bars are pretentious. No thank you.

Question: [on the phone] Hey, did I tell you we were going to have a baby?  Oh, thank you very much.  I'm excited.  Oh, definitely.

Answer: Everyone, may I have your attention? I would like to introduce you to Mr. Danny Cordray. He is going to be joining us as our new traveling salesman. Say hello to Danny!

Question: Everyone, may I have your attention? I would like to introduce you to Mr. Danny Cordray. He is going to be joining us as our new traveling salesman. Say hello to Danny!
Answer: [bleep] me!

Question: O-kay. You know what? No. No. This is not some sort of construction site...or all of Italy, where you can just go around treating people like meat. We are to respect him. I respect him because he reminds me of somebody. Can anybody guess who that is?
Answer: Josh Duhamel.

Question: No, me. Right? Sorta like...a little younger version of me.
Answer: It's hard to judge ourselves accurately, isn't it.

Question: Michael?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Can I talk to you about something?
Answer: No, you may not.

Question: You hired him?
Answer: Guys, let me ask you something. Do you want your life to be better or worse or stay the same?

Question: Guys, let me ask you something. Do you want your life to be better or worse or stay the same?
Answer: Stay the same.

Question: No, no. Wrong. He would have stolen your clients, but you know what? He can't now. This guy used to steal sales from us; now, he's going to steal sales for us.
Answer: Where's he gonna sit? There's no more seats.

Question: Where's he gonna sit? There's no more seats.
Answer: He doesn't need to sit, he's a traveling salesman. Look, I am not going to exclude good people from our staff simply because they are threatening to you. And unless you have a better argument than that, I suggest you leave.

Question: Where's he gonna park? There's no more reserved parking spots.
Answer: Good-bye!

Question: What's something you really care about?
Answer: Reverse snobbery.

Question: Holy crap. Are you kidding me? You just made that-that's amazing!
Answer: Go ahead.

Question: [singing] Which me am I gonna be today?
Answer: Which me am I gonna be today?

Question: Which me am I gonna be today?
Answer: I gotta closet full of mes. Am I gonna be the happy me?

Question: I gotta closet full of mes. Am I gonna be the happy me?
Answer: Or the me that stinks.

Question: Oh, my gosh! We're almost out of time. How much for another half hour?
Answer: Oh, don't worry about it.

Question: Wait. Seriously?
Answer: Yeah.

Question: So we're just, like, jamming as friends?
Answer: One, two, three, hit it.

Question: Did ya?
Answer: Yeah. Way ,way, way back.

Question: Let me handle this, Jim. Drop the act, Cordray, okay? We all know that you probably thought that Pam was too 'meh' or thin without being toned. But I wanna tell you something-she is one of the plain hearty women of Scranton that make this city great. And so what if she doesn't wear makeup? [Pam mouthing 'I wear makeup'] We like her better that way! And you steal clients, don't you? Don't you!
Answer: Okay...that's different.

Question: Oh, that's different, is it? Okay...thief. You better check your things, people. In fact, where are my keys? Oh, there in my pocket. False alarm. Okay. [awkward pause] So...you're gonna be workin' here?
Answer: Uh...I mean-yeah.

Question: Hey, crazy, um...so...that's it? You're just-you're fine?
Answer: It's after 5:00, Jim. I'm not gonna take this home. [shakes Danny's hand]

Question: This morning, Danny Cordray stole a sale from me. So what do I do? I go out and I steal Danny Cordray. The sale that mattered, I made. Boom. Funny thing about it, we don't even need him. We already have Packer on the road. Chhguuh! Crap. I forgot about Packer.
Answer: [singing and playing drums] Sun's in her eyes, tongue full of flies. Would you like to share my paaaaaaad?

Question: [singing and playing drums] Sun's in her eyes, tongue full of flies. Would you like to share my paaaaaaad?
Answer: Croak, croak, croak. Bullfrog in love. Croak, croak, croak. Bullfrog in love and I gave her the croak that meant I love you.

Question: What about this one? It's kinda badass, right? Just seems kinda crazy in a way I might need right now.
Answer: I don't know. [looks at Stanley, who took his mug and is drinking out of it] Oh! That's... not... yours.

Question: Stanley just drank OJ out of my mug, and didn't seem to realize that it wasn't his hot coffee. So the question has to be asked, is there no limit to what he won't notice?
Answer: What's a seven letter word for purse?

Question: What's a seven letter word for purse?
Answer: [sitting at Phyllis' desk, dressed like Phyllis; high pitched voice] Satchel!

Question: So what kind of statement are you making with that costume, Kevin?
Answer: The statement that I am making, Oscar, is that I kind of look like Michael Moore.

Question: Dunder Mifflin, this is Erin! Happy Halloween! How can I haunt you today?
Answer: A lot of people are really getting into Halloween this year! [puts head down over fake bomb made from cardboard, high pitched voice] Six seconds, MacGruber! [lifts head] Pam's got a lot of fun stuff planned! [puts head down, high pitched voice] Uh, two seconds MacGruber! [lifts head] Including a... costume contest, and bobbing for apples, and a Ouija board... OHHH! BOOM! OHH EXPLOSION! [throws fake bomb, takes off sunglasses, points to camera] MACGRUBERRRR!

Question: What?
Answer: You're only one third as beautiful and only half her height.

Question: Lame. Why don't witches wear panties?
Answer: Oh, here we go!

Question: [laughs] OH! Who likes to water ski on Lake Erie? No wai-where does Dracula like to water ski?
Answer: Lake Erie.

Question: So, wait, drivers are going to be able to sell paper on the road?
Answer: That is correct.

Question: Has anyone started calling you 'Gabe-wad' yet?
Answer: Not here.

Question: Really? We're good?
Answer: Yeah. We're cool.

Question: What's under your shirt?
Answer: Oh. It's a ream of paper. Thought you might hit me.

Question: Darryl Philbin is the greatest guy in the world. And you know what I'd like? I would like to have all the racists brought together and take Darryl Philbin out to lunch. Just to see what they're missing.
Answer: [leans hobo sack against the refrigerator] It's a great stick, right?

Question: [leans hobo sack against the refrigerator] It's a great stick, right?
Answer: It's really good. It's a classic. I think you might win the whole thing with that.

Question: Everyone realizes that this coupon book isn't actually worth fifteen thousand dollars, right? You'd have to spend two hundred thousand dollars on crap you don't actually need to get fifteen thousand dollars worth of benefits. I'm not the only one who sees this, right?
Answer: No.

Question: You own a bar?
Answer: Public School, at exit 11.

Question: Hey, man, can I get a plus five? It's all guys.
Answer: Hey, what's the crowd like, Danny? Our age?

Question: Hey, what's the crowd like, Danny? Our age?
Answer: Okay.

Question: Pam is gonna choose whoever has a scent most like that of her father. Does anyone remember what her dad smelled like?
Answer: I think he-

Question: Hey hey hey, quiet, here she comes! Did you hear about that Danny guy? Heard he used to date Pam.
Answer: So four years ago, when I was in Stamford, Connecticut, and dating someone else, Pam went on two dates with Danny. Which was obviously the greatest love story ever told, given how much people are walking on eggshells around us.

Question: And looks so handsome in his UNIFORM! Please?
Answer: No. No, I'm not gonna-no.

Question: Tuna! Tuna! Do you want us to skip this party?
Answer: I don't care.

Question: You know what else? [pulling fake teeth out of his mouth] The-this... this sucks for Jim. Right? But it also sucks for us. Because we don't get invited to a ton of Halloween parties. [puts teeth back in]
Answer: Yeah, and everyone else is gonna be there. Stanley, Phyllis, Angela, Darryl... Creed's a maybe.

Question: [removes teeth] Creed's going?!
Answer: Madge from the warehouse just made her first sale. Madge. We should have been doing this a long time ago.

Question: Erin! Would you please do me a solid and get Darryl Philbin on the speakerphone?
Answer: [answers phone] Hello?

Question: [answers phone] Hello?
Answer: Hi, Darryl, come out here, please.

Question: [leans over toward Erin] Um, hit the speakerphone button. The speakerphone button? The same button as you hit before... or sit on it.
Answer: This whole delivery slash sales idea? You know whose idea that was? That was Darryl Philbin's. He thought of that way before the corporate fat suits.

Question: This whole delivery slash sales idea? You know whose idea that was? That was Darryl Philbin's. He thought of that way before the corporate fat suits.
Answer: So, what happened?

Question: So, what happened?
Answer: I got in the way. I said no. And it just stopped. But then corporate comes up with this idea, but you know what? They need to know that it was yours. And I don't care if I take a bullet. We're gonna call them, we're gonna put them on speakerphone right now...

Question: I got in the way. I said no. And it just stopped. But then corporate comes up with this idea, but you know what? They need to know that it was yours. And I don't care if I take a bullet. We're gonna call them, we're gonna put them on speakerphone right now...
Answer: Oh! [fumbles for phone]

Question: Uh uh. Corporate stole nothing, okay? Darryl told me, and then I told them, giving Darryl full credit, so... no need to [mimicking Andy] screw corporate! Or anything like that, so. Let's give Darryl a round of applause, as planned. [claps]
Answer: I'm a little peeved at Darryl right now.

Question: What is taking someone from behind?
Answer: No. Shh. Michael, listen. This cannot stand. We can't have workers going straight to corporate. Makes your job superfluous.

Question: You were?
Answer: Okay, well then, uh, I mean,  maybe we could do it like... next Halloween.

Question: What are you talking about?
Answer: Well Jim and Pam basically begged us not to go...

Question: Jim and Pam really don't want you to go?
Answer: They're really upset about the whole Danny situation.

Question: Guys? You're arguing over a one in sixteen chance. Over a prize worth... forty bucks.
Answer: Um, fifteen thousand bucks, Oscar.

Question: Yeah, shut it, Oscar. Pam?
Answer: This is an amazing prize. I mean, I don't even want to give Pam a compliment, because she's so blegh, but she did a good job. I really want that coupon book.

Question: [staring at Gabe and Kevin] What the hell are they talking about?
Answer: Hmm, Kevin and Gabe. Probably about the extremes of the human physique.

Question: Do you think that Kevin is going over my head? I don't-[sees Kevin and Gabe fist-bump] Oh my GOD. Okay. All right. All right. You know what? That's inappropriate, Kevin. I am your boss, and if you have something to say, it goes through me, and then I take it to Gabe. Chain of command. Do you understand?
Answer: I am so sorry.

Question: Oh, you're sorry?
Answer: I just thought-

Question: What did you just thought?
Answer: Well, Gabe asked me if there were any really cool Lady Gaga moves that he could do for the catwalk. And so then I tol-[tries not to cry]

Question: Okay? But I- I am so sorry that I didn't tell you first.
Answer: Well, don't let it happen again.

Question: [hysterical] You think that I would let this happen again?! NO WAY JOSE.
Answer: I-

Question: Can you imagine? It's just crazy.
Answer: That is crazy. We would never care if Andy or Kevin went to your party.

Question: It's not like you guys had some long relationship right? Big painful breakup I don't know about?
Answer: No! Two or three dates.

Question: Was it two? I thought it was three.
Answer: No, we um, we had plans for a third, but then I don't know, you never called me back, so...

Question: Yeah? [stops laughing] It was though, that's what happened.
Answer: [stops laughing] Well, great, I just wanted to make sure that things weren't weird.

Question: Okay, this whole going over my head-gate? Is making people act weird. The chain of command is crumbling. Do you know what just happened? I just made Kevin cry. And Gabe looks like Lady Gaga. That's not Halloween. Halloween should be a day in which we honor monsters and not be mad at each other.
Answer: I'm not mad. Are you mad?

Question: I'm not mad. Are you mad?
Answer: You went over my head. And then you lied to my face. So my head and my face have taken a beating.

Question: Is it?
Answer: Yes.

Question: How many freakin' vampires am I supposed to care about these days?
Answer: I guess you could say I'm still in costume. I'm a rational consumer.

Question: Stupid coupon booklet. Have you seen my costume? I'm a rational consumer.
Answer: Yeah, I uh, heard you say it to Phyllis. That's a good line.

Question: Pam. Can you vote for other people?
Answer: Yeah, I gotta get in on this. [mocking Darryl] Hey, it's cool, man, I work in the warehouse! I'm cool! I'm hip and I'm jive! And I don't care about nobody! Do you know who I am? Happy Halloween, jerk!

Question: Yeah, I gotta get in on this. [mocking Darryl] Hey, it's cool, man, I work in the warehouse! I'm cool! I'm hip and I'm jive! And I don't care about nobody! Do you know who I am? Happy Halloween, jerk!
Answer: Still don't know who I am? I'll give you a hint. I go over other people's heads.

Question: Still don't know who I am? I'll give you a hint. I go over other people's heads.
Answer: Michael, this is a bad idea.

Question: What's a bad idea?
Answer: Dressing up as somebody-I mean, when has that ever worked for you?

Question: Dressing up as somebody-I mean, when has that ever worked for you?
Answer: NEVER! [tosses wig] Okay, you know what? Fine.  I'm not Darryl. And thank God I'm not Darryl.

Question: NEVER! [tosses wig] Okay, you know what? Fine.  I'm not Darryl. And thank God I'm not Darryl.
Answer: Could you for once just let us enjoy a party instead of making it about all your issues?

Question: Could you for once just let us enjoy a party instead of making it about all your issues?
Answer: [walking down the runway] Raaah! [waves sword]

Question: I don't like your tone! Look, they were sold out of all the other costumes, okay? I think we all live in the real world, here. Let's not pretend to be unaware of what sells in this office.
Answer: What should we ask?

Question: What should we ask?
Answer: Hey, can I play? Why don't you ask if Darryl is a bad friend who backstabs people in the back?

Question: Hey, can I play? Why don't you ask if Darryl is a bad friend who backstabs people in the back?
Answer: We have one question to ask the spirit world and you want us to ask that?

Question: We have one question to ask the spirit world and you want us to ask that?
Answer: He says no.

Question: Dwight, you saw Darryl move it, right?
Answer: Let's just say I saw exactly what the two of you wanted me to see.

Question: If you had one word you would use to describe Darryl what would that word be?
Answer: [hands are being forced to the letters] A... S... S... H... E... T?

Question: [hands are being forced to the letters] A... S... S... H... E... T?
Answer: An asset!

Question: This is some party, huh?
Answer: When you work hard, you play hard around here.  Even if you don't work hard. Oh, here's something. Uh, why didn't you ever call Pam back?

Question: When you work hard, you play hard around here.  Even if you don't work hard. Oh, here's something. Uh, why didn't you ever call Pam back?
Answer: Are you serious?

Question: Are you serious?
Answer: Yeah. I mean, I'm not saying that everyone has to fall in love, or anything, I'm just saying... but you know, to not even call her back is...

Question: You know what it was? I think she gave me her number but then her fours look like eights, and...
Answer: Could be. But you also called her the second time so you had the number right.

Question: Halpert, you lookin' for someone to bang your wife?
Answer: Nope.

Question: Okay. You wanna know?  I didn't call her back because she spent the whole date talking about you. She was obviously in love with you.
Answer: Fifty seven. Fifty eight.

Question: Do you honestly want to know why I didn't call her back on a date over four years ago?
Answer: Hey. She had a nice time. It seems rude.

Question: I did. And it's just one of those things that's going to keep gnawing at me, like 'gnaw, gnaw, why? Why didn't he? I have no idea why.'
Answer: Okay. Honestly. I didn't call you back because I-thought you seemed a little... dorky.

Question: Thank you! Thank you. I got it. Now I know. You thought I was a little dorky. You know? [gibberish sounds] Okay. Well, excuuuuse me.
Answer: In the future, you need to get Michael's approval on anything before coming to me.

Question: That was-okay, you make one mistake in fifteen years and you drag me over the coals, after everything I did for you?
Answer: What have you done for me?

Question: What have you done for me?
Answer: Oh...

Question: What have you done for me?
Answer: Well...

Question: Ohh. Dropping bombs, right? [explosion noise] This really make you think, Michael?
Answer: Stop it! Stop, stop. We're thinking. We're thinking about it.

Question: Okay, why don't we simplify this? Darryl brings it to Michael, Michael brings it to me, no one calls Jo.
Answer: Unless you and I decide we want to talk to Jo, then we'll give her a call.

Question: What's up, man?
Answer: Sometimes it seems like it was better down in the warehouse, you know?

Question: Sometimes it seems like it was better down in the warehouse, you know?
Answer: When I was a freshman in college, I worked at the student newspaper, the Cornell Daily Sun? This was at Cornell. I had to write an op-ed column every day.  Bernard's Regards.

Question: When I was a freshman in college, I worked at the student newspaper, the Cornell Daily Sun? This was at Cornell. I had to write an op-ed column every day.  Bernard's Regards.
Answer: This was your freshman year.

Question: I started to ask myself, 'Do I have big plans here?' I didn't want to become editor of that paper, so I got up and walked right out of Walter Bernard hall, and that's actually when I heard eight male voices, singing, unencumbered by instruments. I was hooked. So is becoming CEO of this company your a capella group?  Come on, we're going to Danny's bar. Public School.
Answer: No. I got some work to do. I do got big plans with this company.

Question: To be honest, I still can't believe he didn't call her back. Who doesn't call a dork like that back?
Answer: Oh, wow!

Question: Di-Did you say vampire?
Answer: Oh, no, it's just that if a vampire had to cough, he would do it like this. [coughs into elbow]

Question: Uh-huh. Right. And ruin their cloaks? Do you have any idea how expensive wool is in Transylvania? [looks at camera] 'Cause of the euro.
Answer: Well, other things you can do to help cut down on the spread of disease are to wash your hands regularly. Don't come in if you're sick.

Question: Does the Nard-dog want Nard-pups? Yeah. I want a big ol' litter of Nard-pups. All jumping around, sucking on the teet. Put 'em in a box, give 'em to my neighbors. Yeah, I want kids.
Answer: [handing out cards] For all your paper and printer needs. For all your paper and printer needs. For all your paper and printer needs.

Question: Are you talking to me?
Answer: [whispers to Pam] Ok, your turn.

Question: [clears his throat] So who is the godfather?
Answer: Our friend, Seth, and his wife there.

Question: Okay. Old friend, like, you've known him since kindergarten?
Answer: No, I met his wife in Mommy and Me. They're a great couple. You should meet them later.

Question: Thank you. Anyone else with a prayer or a remembrance? [Dwight and an eldery man stand up at the same time, Dwight stares at him, man sits back down]
Answer: Good morning. Dwight Schrute. Thank you all for your prayers and your remembrances. Like Justin and his disfigurement, I too have had a horrible year. They say that the middle class is disappearing, and with it, the soul of America. So, as a gift to this beautiful congregation, I would like to offer a 4% discount on all Dunder Mifflin Sabre products if you buy a printer at full price.

Question: Right now?
Answer: Well, she can't bring this up with her.

Question: Okay. All right, come on. [picks up Cece from Pam, whispers to her] Where are we going? Where are we going? We're gonna take a little field trip.
Answer: [whispering, going into the bathroom with Cece] Okay. Okay. There's my girl. All right. Hold on one second. There we go. What's that face for? Oh, my-oh, my God. Cece, no. No, no, no, not on the dress! Cece, stop!

Question: [whispering, going into the bathroom with Cece] Okay. Okay. There's my girl. All right. Hold on one second. There we go. What's that face for? Oh, my-oh, my God. Cece, no. No, no, no, not on the dress! Cece, stop!
Answer: [seeing Jim come in with Cece wearing an old t-shirt] What?

Question: [seeing Jim come in with Cece wearing an old t-shirt] What?
Answer: What?

Question: What?
Answer: Honey, no.

Question: At this time, will the families please come join me?
Answer: Jim and Pam and Cece really seem to be clicking. They are totally gelling. It's as if they leave my office and they go to another office that sells happiness. And good for them. That's great, because, you know, the paper industry's not gonna last forever.

Question: For all their generosity of spirit, they password-protect their wireless?
Answer: Try 'Jesus.'

Question: [walking around and greeting people] How are you? Good morning. Good morning.
Answer: Good morning.

Question: You don't know them all?
Answer: Nope, and we're gonna need a loaves and fishes kind of miracle to feed 'em all.

Question: Jesus is not your caterer. [baby voice to Cece] But he should be your caterer 'cause you're a little angel. Why didn't your parents get you a caterer? [normal voice] They don't think.
Answer: [to Cece] Hm. Don't listen to her. She's just jealous 'cause she doesn't get to come home to someone as cute as you.

Question: Huh, you think she is jealous about having a baby?
Answer: I don't know. I'm just hungry.

Question: Okay, well, you know what? Everybody's hungry. [Pam looks at Jim] Sorry. I think I'm just hungry.
Answer: Oh, after you.

Question: I cancelled my plans to come to this thing, and they repay me with this?
Answer: You know what, guys, let's just enjoy lunch.

Question: With what? How? Sometimes, Michael. Sometimes.
Answer: Excuse me, everyone, on behalf of the youth ministry that's leaving for Mexico, I just wanted to thank our hosts and tell you about those good-looking guys and gals over there. [group of young adults cheer and applaud]

Question: [chuckling] Who takes a kid to Mexico?
Answer: I would run to Mexico if that's where the sandwiches are.

Question: Greg, hello, it's Dwight from the vestibule. You want to know my eleventh commandment? I will not be undersold.
Answer: [overhearing Dwight's conversation] Hey, Dwight. Dwight, hey.

Question: Are you kidding me? Stop it.
Answer: I'll call you back.

Question: My parents explained it to me this way. You wouldn't hesitate to save a family member from a burning building, but what if the earth was your building and all the people on it were your family?
Answer: What if the moon was your car and Jupiter was your hair brush?

Question: What if the moon was your car and Jupiter was your hair brush?
Answer: Shh.

Question: Thank you. Or should I say gracias?
Answer: [sighs] Cece went down.

Question: [holding up an empty serving dish] What was this? You're out of it.
Answer: Scones.

Question: Is it just the one jug of apple cider? [Pam shrugs, woman walks away]
Answer: Who the heck was that?

Question: Who the heck was that?
Answer: I think that was sconesy cider, noted baptism reception critic.

Question: Why do we have to do something together? I volunteer at a clinic on my own time.
Answer: Yeah, well, that's just a pick-up scene. Okay, we don't have to volunteer. But I think we should hang out more together.

Question: We are hanging out-right now. You want some more of this?
Answer: Look at these people. These are church-going people. And they know how to party.

Question: Welcome to the party. Everybody have their kool-aid?
Answer: No. Okay, you know what? This is inappropriate. What is wrong with you guys? What is wrong with you? What is so horrible about wanting to get together and do something nice? Why did you guys even come today? What's so great about your lives that you think you're better than everybody else? That you can make fun of everybody else? You're mean. You're mean girls. Like the movie, Mean Girls. And Kevin and Stanley, if you don't stop worrying so much about what you're gonna put in your gullet, you're gonna die in about a month.

Question: No. Okay, you know what? This is inappropriate. What is wrong with you guys? What is wrong with you? What is so horrible about wanting to get together and do something nice? Why did you guys even come today? What's so great about your lives that you think you're better than everybody else? That you can make fun of everybody else? You're mean. You're mean girls. Like the movie, Mean Girls. And Kevin and Stanley, if you don't stop worrying so much about what you're gonna put in your gullet, you're gonna die in about a month.
Answer: Oh, hey, Mee-Maw, would you watch Cece for a second? Don't worry. She's asleep. I'm just gonna track down some more chairs.

Question: Oh, hey, Mee-Maw, would you watch Cece for a second? Don't worry. She's asleep. I'm just gonna track down some more chairs.
Answer: Fine, fine. I guess I'll watch Suzanne's purse and your baby.

Question: [on the bus] Hey. Hey. Is this the bus to Mexico?
Answer: Yeah! [cheers, applause]

Question: Are you coming?
Answer: If you'll have me, yes.

Question: Really? [cheers, applause] Thank you. All right.
Answer: [seeing Michael on the bus] Michael. Get off the bus.

Question: Hey, right?
Answer: Michael, what am I supposed to tell my clients if they ask about you?

Question: Michael, what am I supposed to tell my clients if they ask about you?
Answer: Tell them that I died, and I turned into an angel, and when they feel a breeze in a room with all the windows closed or that-that chill on the back of their neck, that is just me watching over them.

Question: Okay, but what about the bigger corporate accounts?
Answer: Tell them that I'm in a meeting.

Question: Michael, I'm just about to close a sale. Can I authorize a 15% discount?
Answer: No, you may not.

Question: [standing in the church sanctuary, talking to the stained glass] Why you always got to be so mean to me?
Answer: [seeing Cece gone from the couch he left her] Uh, MeeMaw, where's Cece?

Question: [seeing Cece gone from the couch he left her] Uh, MeeMaw, where's Cece?
Answer: I don't know. I lost the purse too.

Question: How long till we get to Mexico?
Answer: Well, two days minus how long we've been on the road. 45 minutes? So, like, two days basically. Maybe more.

Question: Well, two days minus how long we've been on the road. 45 minutes? So, like, two days basically. Maybe more.
Answer: Ooh. What are we building down there again? Like, a hospital? A school for Mexicans? What?

Question: Ooh. What are we building down there again? Like, a hospital? A school for Mexicans? What?
Answer: I don't know, I thought it was like a gymnasium or...

Question: Why aren't they building it themselves?
Answer: They don't know how.

Question: Do we know how? I don't know how. You know how?
Answer: Well, Carla knows.

Question: Carla knows. Oh, I feel like there were so many more people on this bus. There were, like, 200, 300 people before. Hey, Carla? Carla? Hi. What are you doing?
Answer: Oh, trying to sleep.

Question: What is happening? Oh, God, what is happening?
Answer: Do you smell like a weird, warm cheese?

Question: Do you smell like a weird, warm cheese?
Answer: Oh, God, you know what? I'm gonna be in Mexico for my half-birthday.

Question: Oh, God, you know what? I'm gonna be in Mexico for my half-birthday.
Answer: And the Christmas party.

Question: Hey, guys, has anybody seen the baby?
Answer: Here's her carrier, but no Cece.

Question: Jim, Jim, I want to give a toast. Where's the little girl of honor?
Answer: I don't know, dad. I don't know.

Question: I don't mean to bug, but do you know when those subs are due into port? I got a hungry bunch of Mcphersons over there.
Answer: I don't know. Hey, have you seen my baby?

Question: I don't know. Hey, have you seen my baby?

Question: Oh, I'm glad you asked, Jim.  Because apparently there's a rumor running around here that I am a sexist.  I can't work here effectively if you guys think I'm something that I am not.  I am not a sexist.  Raise your hand if you have a vagina.  [Deangelo raises hand, Kelly and Pam sheepishly raise hands] Raise your hand if someone you love has a vagina.  [Deangelo raises other hand, along with rest of office] Yeah, yeah.  Okay.  Just about everyone.  What about Deangelo's hand?  Oh wow.  He's got 'em both up.  [Ryan raises both hands]  Yeah.  Uh huh.  [others raise both hands] Yeah, so it bothers me when I hear that there's gossip around here that I treat women lesser than men.  Okay?  Frankly, we all look a little ridiculous when that happens.
Answer: I'm not a feminist, but I think that the men in this office are being given chances that the women aren't.

Question: Dwight, what's your take?
Answer: What's the argument here?  NBA, WNBA.  One is a sport, one is a joke.  I love sports, I love jokes.  Room for all.

Question: What's the argument here?  NBA, WNBA.  One is a sport, one is a joke.  I love sports, I love jokes.  Room for all.
Answer: Man, you're smart.  [Erin arrives with new executive assistant]  Oh, hey!  Hi!  Hello.  Welcome.  Uh, everyone, I'd like you to please welcome Jordan Garfield.  This is everyone.

Question: So, Jordan, uh, where did you work before?  Uh, a law office?
Answer: No, Anthropology.  We don't have this in that size, pretty lame.

Question: Lame?  You worked at Anthropology?
Answer: Yeah.

Question: That's like my dream job.  How did you even get that job?
Answer: Well, I umm -

Question: You chose this job over that job?
Answer: Okay, okay, back to work, Kelly, we have a lot to get done today.

Question: So, umm, is this your first office job then?
Answer: Yeah.

Question: [heading into Deangelo's office] Jim, you coming?
Answer: Oh yeah, did he text us?

Question: Oh yeah, did he text us?
Answer: Yeah. [Jim looks at cell phone as Dwight's phone vibrates]

Question: Jim, what are you doing?  Get in there.  This is not the time to take a stand.  At least he likes one of us.
Answer: He didn't text me.  [Andy's phone chimes]

Question: Andy, what are you doing?
Answer: I'm going in, into the belly of the beast.  Gonna infiltrate and change from within.  [joins the group in Deangelo's office]  What's up, mancave! [makes barking noises]

Question: Internally, for office use [Jim quietly enters Deangelo's office and sits down] where do we get our paper from?  Do we go -
Answer: [to Jordan] Don't worry, the first day's always the hardest.

Question: Can I help you?
Answer: Nope.  Just... [Deangelo continues staring at him] Okay. [gets up and leaves office]

Question: So, he kicked you out of the inner circle, huh?
Answer: Well, there is no inner...circle.

Question: Dwight?  Deangelo wanted me to ask you if there's anything I can help you with.
Answer: Really?  Anything.

Question: Really?  Anything.
Answer: Do you need anything?

Question: Do you need anything?
Answer: Deangelo, tell your whore to leave me alone.

Question: Hey!  Kelly, that's the last time I'm gonna talk to you about your paycheck!  Okay?  We pay you a fair salary here, and if you're only here for the money, maybe you shouldn't be here at all.
Answer: No one likes a money grubber.

Question: I'm sorry, Mr. Howard, I apologize for grubbing for money.  I can't do this.  I can't do this.  I'm sorry.  I just can't do it.  Deangelo, Ryan is not my boss.  Okay?  Frankly, he hasn't had a real job here in years.
Answer: Ohh.

Question: Is this true, Ryan?
Answer: I did not see Rango.

Question: [knocking on door to Deangelo's office as loud yelling comes from inside it] Hey!  It sounds like you guys are having a lot of fun, but it's really loud, and some of us are trying to work, so do you think you could do it a little more quietly?
Answer: Well, that's gonna be tough, because we're getting a dunking clinic from Magic Jordan himself.

Question: [chuckles] Oh, you mean Michael Jordan?
Answer: [laughs] Total brain burp.

Question: You know what?  Instead of a game, why don't we do an exhibition?  I'd love to see that dunk of yours.
Answer: Yeah, we'll set that up one day.

Question: Why not?
Answer: Only because no one has called NASA to request a liftoff. [laughter] Let's go downstairs!  Okay?  Let's do it.

Question: Only because no one has called NASA to request a liftoff. [laughter] Let's go downstairs!  Okay?  Let's do it.
Answer: Pass.  If I wanted to see a pissing contest, I'd lock Mose in the chicken coop.

Question: Seems a little close, you sure that's the real foul line?
Answer: 15 feet from the baseline, so, you need me to move it in?

Question: 15 feet from the baseline, so, you need me to move it in?
Answer: Nah, that's 15.  Yeah.

Question: And uh, you know what, to make it interesting, Jordan, why don't you sit underneath the basket?
Answer: Seriously?

Question: Seriously?
Answer: Yeah, come on.  I'll dunk over you.  Best seat in the house.

Question: Someone want to sit in Kevin's lap?  Angela?
Answer: No.

Question: Oscar?
Answer: No thank you.

Question: Alright?
Answer: Yup.

Question: [ambulance pulls away in parking lot] Now what?
Answer: [Deangelo enters office in hospital gown with bandage on his head] Deangelo?

Question: [Deangelo enters office in hospital gown with bandage on his head] Deangelo?
Answer: [speaking gibberish] Tablab.

Question: Oh my God, are you alright?  Erin, will you call 911 please?
Answer: Who should I say is calling?

Question: Who should I say is calling?
Answer: Erin.

Question: All in favor of the baskets full of chocolates, teddy bears, and balloons? [all but Dwight raise their hands]
Answer: Wait, wait. All in favor of the knapsack filled with canned goods, chainsaw, gasoline, and emergency radio in case he wakes up post-apocalypse? [Dwight raises his hand]

Question: Wait, wait. All in favor of the knapsack filled with canned goods, chainsaw, gasoline, and emergency radio in case he wakes up post-apocalypse? [Dwight raises his hand]
Answer: Nope. Baskets have it.

Question: [on phone] Well, I really appreciate the offer, but I'm just happy the way things are. Okay. Thank you. [to Pam] That was Jo, asking me if I wanted to take over as acting manager while they find a replacement. I told her... I don't want to mess this up, right? There's a consensus, people are happy.
Answer: [on phone] Dwight Schrute. Yes, I would. Thank you. [hangs up] Jordan, gather my things from my desk. [Dwight walks to the manager's office, rubs the door frame, sits at the desk reverently]

Question: What have you done?
Answer: Mose... you'll never guess where I am right now.

Question: Do I at least get to go with you in this fantasy?
Answer: You'd slow me down.

Question: Excellent. Morning announcements! There's been a problem with some people sharing copier codes. Your copier code is a distinct 21-digit number that is unique to you, and you only, okay? Don't share it. [Kevin looks exasperated] Jo Bennett, our CEO, will be here today for a high-level meeting involving Gabe and myself.
Answer: Ooh, about what?

Question: Ooh, about what?
Answer: That's on a need-to-know basis.

Question: Question, if we already fomented insurrection, may we be grandfathered in?
Answer: Define foment.

Question: Oh my God, what is wrong with you?
Answer: Gotcha! Why are you late?

Question: Gotcha! Why are you late?
Answer: It's none of your business, actually. It's very medical and personal.

Question: I know, right?
Answer: Hey, Andy?

Question: Hey, Andy?
Answer: Yeah?

Question: Yeah?
Answer: Can I talk to you a second about these client memos?

Question: Can I talk to you a second about these client memos?
Answer: Sure. What's going on? [in room with Gabe]

Question: Sure. What's going on? [in room with Gabe]
Answer: Are you still in love with Erin?

Question: Are you still in love with Erin?
Answer: What?

Question: What?
Answer: Because I am. I need to get her back. [crying] I can't be alone anymore. Andy, do you like being alone with me right now?

Question: Because I am. I need to get her back. [crying] I can't be alone anymore. Andy, do you like being alone with me right now?
Answer: No, this is horrifying.

Question: No. I don't like being alone with me either, okay? I have to get her back. Are you still gonna date her?
Answer: We're just friends, okay?

Question: We're just friends, okay?
Answer: Do you promise that?

Question: Do you promise that?
Answer: Yeah, fine, I promise. We'll never date again. Can we go outside now?

Question: Yeah, fine, I promise. We'll never date again. Can we go outside now?
Answer: No, just give me a second. I don't want anyone to know I've been crying.

Question: [seeing the Join the Fist flyers that Jim is hanging] Hey, hey, hey, hey. What do you think you're doing? What's this? What's the Fist?
Answer: Oh, it's just a social club. You know, like the French Revolution, or the Black Panthers, or communism. It's just a club. Guys talking, you know.

Question: You expect me to believe that you're starting a rebellion?
Answer: Nope. Social club. God, I hate when everybody calls us a rebellion. [Darryl enters and brandishes his fist, Jim returns the gesture]

Question: Okay, you know what? I would love to join The Fist.
Answer: And we would love to have you. But not today. Unfortunately, it's a bad day, what with Operation Overthrow and everything, but I have noted it.  [Dwight tears the sign down, Jim hangs two signs in its place]

Question: [looking at empty vending machine] No food now? Someone has to do something about Dwight!
Answer: He put some snacks in the freezer for us.

Question: You mean the frozen mice for the piranha?
Answer: No. The blueberry Slurpee pouch.

Question: Erin, I am in love with you. I don't believe in much, okay? I don't believe in horoscopes. I don't believe in Christmas. Uh, uh, I sure as hell don't believe in God. [Erin and Angela both look taken aback]
Answer: [quietly] What?

Question: [quietly] What?
Answer: Or maybe there's a God. I don't know. I mean, it's just not a guy with a long white beard. [Erin looks shocked] Or it could be. I mean, it's possible that that is exactly what - what God is. But for all of the disbelief [phone rings] I believe in us. I believe in love. You have made me believe that for all of the hokum [phone continues ringing] out... there... uh, do we not have voicemail?

Question: Or maybe there's a God. I don't know. I mean, it's just not a guy with a long white beard. [Erin looks shocked] Or it could be. I mean, it's possible that that is exactly what - what God is. But for all of the disbelief [phone rings] I believe in us. I believe in love. You have made me believe that for all of the hokum [phone continues ringing] out... there... uh, do we not have voicemail?
Answer: Dwight doesn't trust robots to give us our messages.

Question: Jo is coming later today. I cannot have a subordinate trying to make me look stupid. Okay? I need you to promise me that you'll be on your best behavior.
Answer: I promise...d other people that I would be on my worst behavior. And I gave them my word, so...

Question: What?
Answer: If I had thought that there was a real chance that Dwight would be permanent manager, I would have pre-quit. And you might be saying to yourself, 'Well that's pretty premature to think,' but I always say, it's better to be pre-pre-preprepared.

Question: How you doing, Jordan?
Answer: I'm good.

Question: Why are you telling me this?
Answer: Now I want you to find out what people are saying about me, things they don't want me to know abou-[Dwight opens a box and sits down in shock] Ohh... it's a holster.

Question: Dwight, are you carrying a gun?
Answer: The holster was a gift from my great-uncle Honk. Um, I don't know. I guess he's saying that he's proud of me.

Question: The gun is just an accessory to the holster, okay? I can't walk around wearing an empty holster.
Answer: Why do you need to wear the holster at all?

Question: Why do you need to wear the holster at all?
Answer: Why do you need to keep wearing those booby shirts all the time?

Question: Why do you need to keep wearing those booby shirts all the time?
Answer: Thank you.

Question: Why would I put a banana in my holster?
Answer: In case you weren't hungry now, but you got hungry later.

Question: Dwight, no gun, okay? Don't make us call Jo.
Answer: Okay. All right. Fine. Everyone calm down. Someone get me a banana. Sorry I freaked you guys out - aah! [Dwight goes to flip the gun and it fires near Andy's ear, making everyone jump]

Question: My God. There is a hardwood floor underneath this carpeting. Why would they do that?
Answer: [trying to find a pitch] Eeeeeeee... There's like this crazy ringing going on. I can't - eeeeeee... I can't find perfect C.

Question: Hey, what happened?
Answer: Dwight went on a shooting spree, and then he shot Andy in the head.

Question: I'll look on WebMD. What are your symptoms?
Answer: Oh, everybody. Oscar found a reason to look on WebMD.

Question: Okay, why are you calling Jo?
Answer: I think I should go the hospital.

Question: What's wrong with you?
Answer: It's my ear.

Question: Really? You did? What hand was I holding the gun in? What did Andy's tie look like?
Answer: Navy blue. Little red anchors.

Question: I am supposed to collect eyewitness accounts. Who saw Dwight do this? [all raise their hands]
Answer: Okay, really?

Question: Okay, really?
Answer: Would you consider this a terrorist incident?

Question: Would you consider this a terrorist incident?
Answer: I felt terrorized.

Question: Dwight, why is it on us to protect you?
Answer: Because you guys are my best friends, and I mean that. Managing you for this last week has been the greatest honor of my life. And if you ruin this, I will burn this office to the ground. And I mean that figuratively. Not literally. Because you guys are so... so important... to me. I love you guys. But don't cross me. But you're the best.

Question: There he is! Our hero! [Both Dwight and Erin move to hug Andy] You look fantastic. How you doing? Here, tell us your war stories.
Answer: Well, I burst my eardrum. Doctor said it could take weeks to heal.

Question: Did they say what caused it? Because I know you like putting Q-tips deep into your ear canal.
Answer: Yeah.

Question: How's your hearing?
Answer: Temporary deafness in one ear. It was both ears. I couldn't hear a thing Darryl was saying while we were in the waiting room.

Question: American Idol? What? No.
Answer: Okay. I guess I can just not go. Do you guys wanna hear my solo?

Question: Okay. I guess I can just not go. Do you guys wanna hear my solo?
Answer: No.

Question: [singing] Why did my temporary boss go on a shooting spree?
Answer: Okay, fine. You can go on your singing audition.

Question: Oh, is it my turn? Ooh, I'm on the spot. I don't know. Um... you know what? I think I'm good.
Answer: Thank God.

Question: Nope. When Jo's here, can you work in 'Shagadelic, baby,' at least three times in a conversation? Oh, and when I cough can you do jazz hands?
Answer: What's jazz hands?

Question: What's jazz hands?
Answer: [quickly shakes his hands back and forth]

Question: [after entering the men's room] What the [bleep] is that? [runs out of the bathroom] Oh, my...
Answer: Hey, all! Cornelius, Bobo, have at it. Nobody let my dogs hump each other. They don't seem to know they're brothers.

Question: Hello, Jo. Welcome. Well, shall we begin?
Answer: Slow yourself down there. Just like a man. Wants to jump right into it while I still got my socks on. Jim Halpert - the only man that ever turned me down.

Question: Well, I don't know about that. Just wasn't for me. But let me assure you, Dwight is firing on all cylinders. Right?
Answer: Well, some pretty big shoes to fill. I was sorry to hear about Deangelo. He was a good man. Tragic. [Jim coughs]

Question: [does jazz hands, Jo notices and eyes him oddly] Well, what can you do? Life.
Answer: We have to clean this up now!

Question: Hey, Andy, did you tell Erin about our conversation earlier when you said you would never want to date her again?
Answer: Uh...

Question: Did I say that earlier? Yes, I did. Because you, Gabe, were crying...
Answer: No, I was not.

Question: And sobbing uncontrollably. Yes. Uh-huh. You were in hysterics. And my maternal instincts kicked in. Is it actually how I feel? Yes. Or no. That is... between me and my diary.
Answer: Oscar, can you print out last year's sale statements?

Question: Oscar, can you print out last year's sale statements?
Answer: Hey, Dwight, gimme a back massage.

Question: You're kidding me. [reaches under Kevin's jacket] Oh God, what am I touching? It's moist.
Answer: I don't feel anything.

Question: Okay, how's that?
Answer: Knead it. Knead it like a pizza.

Question: Dwight! Walk me out. Let's talk soon. And stay on top of these people. You gotta admit it - it's nice to have a little power, eh? How's it feel?
Answer: Jo... I accidentally fired a gun in the office today.

Question: What?!
Answer: I am telling you this because I care too much about this job to be blackmailed into doing it poorly. All I've ever wanted was to be manager here. And if you feel that you cannot promote me over this one accident, I understand. But if you think that extortion is worse -

Question: Shooting is worse! Are you kidding me? It's not even in the same - you shot a gun? What is wrong with you?
Answer: It was a Beaumont-Adams, if that helps.

Question: Who else would be responsible?
Answer: Pam made me put a banana in my holster.

Question: Okay. Did I make a mistake? Yes. Do I regret the decision that I made? Yes.
Answer: Oh, stop asking yourself easy questions so you can look like a genius.

Question: You three are my search committee. You're in charge of finding me my next manager. All righty?
Answer: Yep.

Question: Till then, we need a new acting manager. Now, who's got the most experience in this office?
Answer: Uh, well, we probably don't want to go just on seniority.

Question: Who is it?
Answer: Hey, Dwight. What's up?

Question: Hey, Dwight. What's up?
Answer: Shut up.

Question: Well, you do know that Jo was right to take the job away from you, right? There's no debating that. But, I will say... in your one week, every single one of the orders went out on time. And I think that is shagadelic, baby. [Dwight sees Creed claiming the desk in the manager's office]
Answer: [giving Kevin numbers for the copier] Four, one, seven, one...

Question: Another one?
Answer: Yes!

Question: Could you turn the volume down on the beeping?
Answer: Six, nine, shut up, Oscar. Eight...

Question: Do I love being manager?... I love my kids. I love real estate. [slowly getting more excited] I love ceramics. I love my job. I-I love wrestling.
Answer: [to Jordan] Find out what language this is. [speaking in strange language]

Question: [pointing at a whiteboard with BOBODDY written on the left side, vertically] BO-BODDY! BO-BODDY. What does the first 'B' stand for?
Answer: What are we doing?

Question: What are we doing?
Answer: We're making acronyms. Okay! What does the first 'B' stand for?

Question: We're making acronyms. Okay! What does the first 'B' stand for?
Answer: Um... Business!

Question: [conducting interview] Your paper experience is very interesting. Do you think you could use that experience to inform decisions here?
Answer: Absolutely--I, yes. In fact, I actually have a three-step plan that I believe could effectively double your profits.

Question: Really?
Answer: Yeah.

Question: [waiting for Fred to continue] ...What is it?
Answer: Nice try.

Question: I'm sorry, what is your three-step plan?
Answer: Well, I mean, I can't just hand you my plan. I mean, if you guys give me the job, then, then you'll get the plan.

Question: [speaking faster] Well, I'm not gonna just make up that I have a plan. I got a plan. Believe me, you guys want it. You're in paper, right?
Answer: How would we know that, if you don't...

Question: I guess I could be, if I was... who would do that?
Answer: How about this. Why don't you give us a part of the plan, and that way we know you have it.

Question: [confused] W-What?
Answer: That's a verbal trademark. That's an agreement.

Question: We are the Search Committee, hand-picked by our CEO, and tasked to find this branch's new manager. Not everyone we meet will be good, but someone's bound to be, right? [Andy, Kelly, and Darryl are each dressed up in suits for their interviews, Andy is also wearing an 'Andy for Manager?' pin on his jacket] And, to be honest, I think a lot of the decent candidates are right here in-house, so, I'm not too worried. But I'm really excited to spend a lot of time with Toby and Gabe. [quietly] Did you know that Gabe's last name was Lewis? I had no idea.
Answer: [in elevator with Phyllis and Darryl, all three are smiling, to Darryl] Good morning.

Question: Did you have a nice drive in?
Answer: I did.

Question: The manager job? Nah, I'm barely interested. I just can't not go for it. You know, it's not the Bernard way. We give it the old college try, and then, in defeat, we show grace.
Answer: Still, I'd really like to see this office with you in the boss's chair.

Question: [checks to see that she is alone with Phyllis] Did you hear anything?
Answer: Oh, I'm sure they'll let us know when they get the results. [Erin crosses fingers and smiles excitedly]

Question: [to Dwight, who is reading the want ads] Should you really be so blatant about that?
Answer: They won't make me manager, and I won't settle for anything less. I've gone about as far as I can here. That's obvious. Time to take my talents elsewhere.

Question: Are you really going to apply for work at Scranton Breadworks?
Answer: Bread is the paper of the food industry. You write your sandwich on it.

Question: Can you do any better on salary?
Answer: Unfortunately, that range is set at corporate.

Question: What about mileage when I use my car? I mean, gas ain't cheap, you know.
Answer: Heh. We think that 25 cents a mile is pretty generous.

Question: How about 27? And uh, when I make long-distance calls, will they be monitored or is it on the honor system?
Answer: [on phone] Okay. [hangs up, smiling] How odd, a very unusual phone call from the Senator's office. The Senator wants me to have lunch with him at The Botanical Gardens.

Question: How will your experience selling refinery equipment translate to our smaller scale here?
Answer: You don't work in sales, do you.

Question: You see, I sit across from a man. I see his face. I see his eyes. Now, does it matter if he wants a hundred dollars of paper or a hundred million dollars of deep-sea drilling equipment? Don't be a fool. He wants respect. He wants love. He wants to be younger. He wants to be attractive. There is no such thing as a product. Don't ever think there is. There is only... sex. Everything... is sex. You understand that what I'm telling you is a universal truth,... Toby.
Answer: Yes.

Question: Okay, I-I am, I'm almost a little concerned that you might be overqualified for the position. [Robert and Gabe chuckle at this, then Gabe stops chuckling] Do you, um, do you think that you are?
Answer: Do I look like someone who would waste my own time?

Question: Do I look like someone who would waste my own time?
Answer: No. [Robert then nods his head at Jim]

Question: Can you... [seems intimidated, clears throat] You are a man of great confidence. Could you speak a little more to that, and, what the role of confidence... would be... in a dialogue with a subordinate?
Answer: Will you be heard? Will you have a voice? Will I steamroll over you? Do you feel heard right now, Jim? Do you have a voice, right now? You can answer me.

Question: Will you be heard? Will you have a voice? Will I steamroll over you? Do you feel heard right now, Jim? Do you have a voice, right now? You can answer me.
Answer: Yes.

Question: That was your choice, not mine. The fallacy is that it is up to the steamroller. It is up to the object... whether it will be flattened or not, and I can tell from the small interaction we've had already, you won't be flattened by anybody. Do you agree with me, Jim?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Think about it! What other mammal, besides humans, drinks the milk of another mammal? I mean, you don't see a bear drinking raccoon milk.
Answer: [Jim and Gabe laugh, Toby smiles and nods] Oh.

Question: Oh? Uh... we haven't started the interview yet. Were you--were you joking?
Answer: Uh... [looks at camera] yes?! I was. [sits back down] Little joke!

Question: Uh... [looks at camera] yes?! I was. [sits back down] Little joke!
Answer: So, how would you go about settling interpersonal conflicts within the office?

Question: So, how would you go about settling interpersonal conflicts within the office?
Answer: I thought that was your job.

Question: Well, for instance, how did you deal with it when two warehouse guys got into a fight?
Answer: I'll answer that, Jim. I would use it as an opportunity to teach, uh, about actions... and consequences... of actions. [Jim and Gabe stare at Darryl]

Question: [noticing Erin in the background leading a black man dressed in a suit through the office] Who's that?
Answer: [ignoring Darryl's question] So I think all we need is a resume, and we'll be good right?

Question: [ignoring Darryl's question] So I think all we need is a resume, and we'll be good right?
Answer: I... I just thought you knew me.

Question: Yeah, it's no big deal, just something that looks like that. [shows Darryl a resume] Cool? [goes to put the resume away]
Answer: Let me... [Jim shows him the resume again, Darryl looks at it a little longer this time] Oh. Cool. [Jim gives Darryl a thumbs-up, then looks at the camera as Darryl gets up to leave]

Question: [at the cafe on the first floor] Did, uh, you just interview?
Answer: Ohh, unfortunately, yes.

Question: What do you mean?
Answer: That business can't attract anyone. It's awful up there. Those people seem like they're in prison, waiting out life sentences in a... dying industry.

Question: What makes you feel qualified to judge a place after a mere interview? [Robert stares at Dwight] What are you doing..? [Dwight sits up abruptly] Stop trying to figure me out.
Answer: I just did.

Question: Stop trying to figure me out. [Robert turns to ignore Dwight] Do you even know anything about paper? How it's made?
Answer: I saw an episode of how they make paper on Sesame Street. [nods at Dwight mockingly]

Question: I'm gonna prevent inferior men from sullying my place of work with their weak, passionless leadership. Do you see my hat? No? That's because I just threw it in the ring.
Answer: You guys pay for relocation, though, right?

Question: You guys pay for relocation, though, right?
Answer: Well, why would you need relocation, if you already live in Scranton?

Question: Well, why would you need relocation, if you already live in Scranton?
Answer: Well, I'd want to move further away, you know? Just... I don't want any chance to run into my co-workers outside the office.

Question: Well, I'd want to move further away, you know? Just... I don't want any chance to run into my co-workers outside the office.
Answer: Can I ask why you're leaving your current job?

Question: Can I ask why you're leaving your current job?
Answer: [pulls out a tupperware from his briefcase and takes out a tupperware] I'm leaving my other job because they were all jerks, really. [opens tupperware] You know, all of 'em. You had your jerk-wads, and your jerk-offs, so, just between the wads and the offs, I just... I had to get outta there. [begins eating sandwich]

Question: Is this a bad time to be doing this?
Answer: I'm having a bad time. [chuckles]

Question: Oh, why did I believe that weirdo in the lobby? These are the nicest people I ever met.
Answer: [limo driver lets Angela out of the limo at the office parking lot] Thank you.

Question: It's a little flashy. I mean, what am I? Naomi Judd?
Answer: Tell us the freaking story!

Question: Okay. He took me to the replica of Monet's Japanese bridge, and then he put this flower behind my ear, which normally, I would hate, 'cause it's so civil rightsy. Then he got down on one knee, and he said, will you be a Senator's wife?
Answer: [laughing] Oh-ho-ho! He talked about himself in the third person?

Question: [laughing] Oh-ho-ho! He talked about himself in the third person?
Answer: Yes, Pam. Not everyone is as informal as you and Jim. [imitating Jim's voice] Oh, hey Pam, dude, whatever, wanna marry me? [Erin, Kelly, and Meredith laugh]

Question: What's up? Weird thing. Totally awkward, but you left your notebook on the reception desk.

Question: What?

Question: Some people doodle at work when they let their mind run. They draw houses, penises. Funny how the houses are always colonials and the penises are always circumcised. Don't you think? Well, I doodle too, but I'm not an artist. So I draw words and lists.
Answer: That is fascinating. And, by the way, I am so glad I asked. People were just sort of- Did you just move my name?

But what I really mean is 'I have no idea what your talking about, but I'm gonna go ahead and hire some people for the warehouse and hope that you eventually start feeling better.'........I really hope that's what he and I mean.

Question: Almost instinctively, she turned to her husband. 'Oh, wait,' she thought, 'I don't have a husband.' For Lydia and her husband had had an argument, one they couldn't get past. She had quit the book club, the choir, citing something about their high expectations. Her lips slowly grew together from disuse. Everytime she wanted to act and didn't, another part of her face hardened, until it was stone. And that fevered night, she rushed to the nursery, threw open the door, 'Baby, are you okay?'
