Question: [feigning surprise] A dart? Are you kidding me? Who would put a poison dart, well, I mean, I don't know that it's poison. I mean, I just have to imagine. God, I'm glad he's OK though. Kinda sounds like he deserved it, opening another man's treasure and all. Wow!
Answer: [on a golf course] Well, mister ball, it's been a pleasure. Now, give my regards to hell. Da! [hits ball]

Question: [to Robert] You think you're excited? You should feel my nipples. [Robert gives a fake laugh]
Answer: Oh, that reminds me. [reaching into golf cart] Little something from all of us. [hand Dwight a small wrapped gift]

Question: This is the last time I'll ever see Dwight. It's a weird feeling, it's, um, what's the word? It's not, it's not bittersweet. It's uh... sweet. Yeah.
Answer: [entering Andy's office] Hey, man. Selling cookies for Jada. Want the same as last year?

Question: [entering Andy's office] Hey, man. Selling cookies for Jada. Want the same as last year?
Answer: Would if I could. And I can so I will. Put me down for one box. Don't care what it is, dealer's choice.

Question: [entering Andy's office] Knock, knock. Hey, Sasha's first year in the troops, so I'm selling cookies for her. Anyway, would you like some?
Answer: No. No.

Question: What?
Answer: I been selling here for five years. This is my spot.

Question: You can't claim territories. This is the only place I interact with people. Can't you sell at your church or barber shop? [Darryl looks hurt] Or chess club, or?
Answer: You know what? It's your first time, let's split the office. You can have sales, the annex, Creed, and I don't know I'll just take, uh, accounting.

Question: You know what? It's your first time, let's split the office. You can have sales, the annex, Creed, and I don't know I'll just take, uh, accounting.
Answer: That's it? Yeah, well, ok. Thanks Darryl.

Question: That's it? Yeah, well, ok. Thanks Darryl.
Answer: OK, great.

Question: When can I introduce you to my grandson? He's a wonderful swimmer. Shallow end, deep end. He does it all.
Answer: Well, today might be kind of tough, Irene. I have to talk to my old boss, Andy, and tell him I'm staying in Florida. [hands Irene a mug]

Question: [takes mug] Thank you. [takes a sip] Oh, what kind of tea is this?
Answer: Oh, I boiled some Gatorade.

Question: [approaches Kevin] Would you like to buy some cookies?
Answer: Cookies, eh?

Question: Cookies, eh?
Answer: [singing] Oh, the springtime thinks that it's the best. And fall time thinks that it's the best. Cold time has, kind of a strut. And Valentine's thinks that it's the best. But gather round, peeps, I'll tell you the truth. Nothing beats the cookie season, that's the truth.

Question: No, no, no. It's not fair. What if Kevin wants to buy cookies from me?
Answer: I do.

Question: See?
Answer: That doesn't mean anything. [to Kevin] Kevin, do you want to buy cookies from me?

Question: That doesn't mean anything. [to Kevin] Kevin, do you want to buy cookies from me?
Answer: Oh, I definitely do.

Question: You know, why don't we split the order? It's only fair.
Answer: No. Wait, no. I'm buying, I make the rules. I actually do want you to fight over me. I wanna be wined and dined and... 69ed.

Question: What's that?
Answer: I'm gonna tank the Sabre store at the presentation to the board.

Question: I thought you liked the store?
Answer: Well, the store is lovely. You created a wonderful space to showcase our product line. Great job. Cheers.

Question: But, there's a reason we sell our products online and over-the-phone. Have you ever used Sabre electronics, Jim? [Jim shakes head] They're cheap. They're unintuitive. The Sabre store would work if we adopted the carnival model of leaving town once everyone's wives do us.
Answer: Wow. When you put it that way, I guess it does sound pretty terrible.

Question: How did that look?
Answer: I'm not just saying this, that was the best thing I've ever seen.

Question: When you guys do that whole power of two shebang, how 'bout I pop up also? I guess we'd have to say 'power of three'. Hm, actually, you know what, yeah, that actually works. [to Nellie] You'd spin off right. I'd spin off-
Answer: You know what? That is a great idea. Cathy, write that down and print it out. It's gonna make some really good toilet paper.

Question: You know what? That is a great idea. Cathy, write that down and print it out. It's gonna make some really good toilet paper.
Answer: [enters room] All right. There he is.

Question: What are you doing here? I thought I got rid of you?
Answer: Can I just talk to you for one quick second?

Question: Can I just talk to you for one quick second?
Answer: What, your stylist ran out of 'messy spray'? [others laugh]

Question: What, your stylist ran out of 'messy spray'? [others laugh]
Answer: Um, actually it's, it's for your own good. I think maybe we should- [gestures toward hallway]

Question: You want to do something for my own good? Turn around, walk out that door, do not stop 'til you get to Scranton, find my cell phone charger, mail it back to me, and then go hell. [others laugh]
Answer: Nice. [To Jim] Hey, Halpert, anyone ever tell you you look like Wooly Willy?

Question: Nice. [To Jim] Hey, Halpert, anyone ever tell you you look like Wooly Willy?
Answer: [to Packer] Silence.

Question: Can you help me? I'm trying to make a video chat with Andy.
Answer: Just open the program and type in his user name.

Question: Can you just do it?
Answer: [after briefly typing] Here, type in your password.

Question: [video chat begins, Andy's head enters the screen from the side] Hello?
Answer: That's so weird. There's something wrong with my laptop. [turns laptop on its side] Oh. I fixed it.

Question: [on phone with Jim] He said, 'I did like Dwight'? He's gonna fire him.
Answer: No, no, I think it was more like, 'you know, I liked him, but I don't anymore because he did a bad job, so I'm definitely gonna yell at him'.

Question: Did you actually try your hardest?
Answer: Yes... my pretty hardest. Look, you haven't dealt with him in awhile, all right. He's like super Dwight. It's like he's been bitten by a radioactive Dwight, or som- Stanley, back me up.

Question: [to Kevin] What's a skinny guy like Toby know about cookies? You can't trust him to understand the wants and needs of the thick man. Maybe Toby from two years ago.
Answer: [laughs] Yeah.

Question: That's true. If I have a question about my cookies at midnight, who am I gonna call? Darryl. Toby's probably in bed with some model.
Answer: Thank you.

Question: Look, I need this. Ok? Your daughter is a pretty little girl. Let her go door-to-door. You think people gonna buy cookies from my [hesitates] chubby daughter?
Answer: Oh. [looks away]

Question: [to Kevin] Oh, you know what you have to do? To decide? You need to make them do things for you. And, like, buy you things.
Answer: Or have them sing that song! That the frog does in Looney Tunes.

Question: I don't buy it. It, that is a freckle. That is not a tan, ok? I'm gonna have to inspect it in person when you get back here. I want you looking totally 'puerto ricania' when i see you.
Answer: Well, Andy, I'm not coming back.

Question: What?
Answer: I have a job here. I work for an old lady. [turns laptop to put Irene into view]

Question: Andy?
Answer: Yeah, that's awesome. That's great.

Question: No, it's not worth it? That's too bad. 'Cause I was feeling particularly hungry this year.
Answer: Yeah, ok so what, you buy 40 boxes?

Question: Yeah, ok so what, you buy 40 boxes?
Answer: Hungrier.
Hungrier.

Question: You're not talking... triple digits?
Answer: Oh yeah, I'm talking triple digits. [folds arms satisfied while Toby and Darryl look at each other] Again. [both start performing Hello! Ma Baby again]

Question: You again? Gosh, I keep throwing you away, you keep flying back here. You're like an Amish return stick.
Answer: OK, great, listen to me. Listen to me. [Dwight makes funny gesture] No, no, I know. Will you just let me tell you one thing, please?

Question: OK, great, listen to me. Listen to me. [Dwight makes funny gesture] No, no, I know. Will you just let me tell you one thing, please?
Answer: Yes, you may tell me one thing. Wait, you want to borrow money?

Question: Yes, you may tell me one thing. Wait, you want to borrow money?
Answer: Listen to me. Robert is going to veto the Sabre store.

Question: Wait. [holds up fingers] He's gonna kill the store? And he's gonna fire me?
Answer: Yes.

Question: You know what? You might want to get to the airport. It's gonna take you a long time to get through security with all those beauty products. Bye.
Answer: Dwight, come o-

Question: Gross! Don't lick my hand! God, why is there so much saliva?
Answer: AlI had to do was think about pie and my salivary glands did the rest.

Question: What? What, what, what, what, what?
Answer: [clutching side] Oh, god! You... oh! My appendix-

Question: You all right? You ok?
Answer: [stops whining and charges Jim] Rrrah!

Question: [to Cathy] Where the hell is he? I cannot do this without him.
Answer: I don't know. He's not picking up.

Question: Sup?
Answer: [notices Andy boxing up things from Erin's desk] What are you doing?

Question: [notices Andy boxing up things from Erin's desk] What are you doing?
Answer: I'm just dealing with Erin's stuff since apparently she's not coming back. And she didn't bother to tell anyone.

Question: Ryan, why didn't you tell me?
Answer: Thought you checker my Tumblr?

Question: Thought you checker my Tumblr?
Answer: You never update it.

Question: Does anyone else think this is weird? And like, kind of uncool, actually? To leave us without a receptionist?
Answer: We'll find another receptionist. I mean, that's easy. We'll be fine. [Andy nods reluctantly]

Question: What are you doing?
Answer: I was trying to go-

Question: Get up. All right? I'm not gonna let you by.
Answer: Then you know what? I'm just gonna have to run right through you.

Question: Then you know what? I'm just gonna have to run right through you.
Answer: OK. [Dwight runs in place] What are you doing? Are you really revving up? you know that doesn't work.

Question: OK. [Dwight runs in place] What are you doing? Are you really revving up? you know that doesn't work.
Answer: [tries to jump off wall] Jackie Chan! [falls and groans]

Question: Okay, now who do I ride to the kitchen like a pony?
Answer: Don't make me be your pony, Kevin.

Question: What do you mean?
Answer: I'm out. And so is Toby.

Question: [tackled by Dwight] What are you doing? No. No, no, no.
Answer: This. Ends. Now.

Question: Why?
Answer: Anything else you need to talk about?

Question: Anything else you need to talk about?
Answer: Nope. I think that was it. [Dwight gets up and walks away]

Question: [to Nellie] Are you kidding? [to Robert] She's the queen of the whole freaking Magilla!
Answer: And yet Todd, it's you who's fired.

Question: What, you, I, I can't get fired. I'm an institution. I have been at this company for 20 years. How many of you have been here that long, huh? [Dwight exits meeting room and helps Jim up]
Answer: [Dwight and Jim enter office] Hey, hey. They're back. [Everyone greets them]

Question: Dwight, what are you doing here? I thought you were supposed to be in Florida?
Answer: Yeah, the crazy thing about that is, um, wow you look great. Did you lose some weight?

Question: Yeah, the crazy thing about that is, um, wow you look great. Did you lose some weight?
Answer: Thank you, for someone who actually notices this. No, I didn't lose weight. But I started using my makeup to contour my face to look skinnier. I actually put on five pounds.

Question: I'm going to Florida to get Erin. [grabs coat, runs out, then returns] Forgot to turn off my email. It's crazy, right? It's just, when she said she was leaving, I felt so- [looks at computer frustrated] 'You're about to close four tabs, are you sure you want to continue?' Yes. I am sure. Ah, slow computer!
Answer: [telephone ringing] This is Pam. Oh my God, are you sure? Uh, okay. Okay, um, we'll be right there. Everybody, the balloon is falling.

Question: [telephone ringing] This is Pam. Oh my God, are you sure? Uh, okay. Okay, um, we'll be right there. Everybody, the balloon is falling.
Answer: Nice.

Question: How long do you think it's been up there, Kevin?
Answer: I just remember pushing aside my silky bangs to say, 'Look, a balloon.'

Question: Hey. So they accidentally gave us an extra egg sandwich this morning. Who wants it?
Answer: oooh

Question: Mmm. [bites sandwich] Oh, that is disgusting. Do you call that a King James breakfast pie?
Answer: What brings you to town?

Question: What brings you to town?
Answer: Certainly not the Harry Houdini Museum. What a nobody. Oh look, some Hungarian just found their way out of a sack. Let's build a shrine. No, I've come to work here.

Question: What?
Answer: How could Robert transfer Nellie here after the Sabre store debacle? She stinks of failure. The fact that she could show her face around here is an embarrassment. I should know. I'm in an identical situation.

Question: How could Robert transfer Nellie here after the Sabre store debacle? She stinks of failure. The fact that she could show her face around here is an embarrassment. I should know. I'm in an identical situation.
Answer: Robert did say you'd be joining us. Welcome. I'm Tony.

Question: What?
Answer: I- I said I'm Tony. Okay I made a mistake. I thought it might go unnoticed. But uh, I'm Toby.

Question: You messed up saying your name?
Answer: It happens, okay? Uh, so let's just find an empty desk for you, and uh, I'm sure Robert will be with you as soon as he gets in.

Question: It happens, okay? Uh, so let's just find an empty desk for you, and uh, I'm sure Robert will be with you as soon as he gets in.
Answer: That one looks empty.

Question: Oh, is it?
Answer: I have one simple philosophy in business: if the seat is open, the job is open. It's how I came to briefly race a formula one car. The three slowest laps ever recorded.

Question: How are you? How's your family doing?
Answer: Bye.

Question: How are you adjusting to life in Scranton so far?
Answer: So far, so good.

Question: Ah, well, it is astounding what a difference that can make, isn't it?
Answer: Mm-hm.

Question: Now. Let's find you something fun to do here, shall we?
Answer: Oh, I've already found it. I am manager, a natural next step. It fits like a glove.

Question: Do you really? Because it is 10:00. I've been in this chair for an hour, and no other manager has come and sat in my lap.
Answer: Excuse me, has anyone seen Andy this morning?

Question: Excuse me, has anyone seen Andy this morning?
Answer: Huh. Yeah, that's weird. He's usually here by now. Right guys?

Question: Huh. Yeah, that's weird. He's usually here by now. Right guys?
Answer: [on phone] Hello.

Question: Andy, it's Robert. Why aren't you at work?
Answer: Hey, Robert. Ah, I really wish I could come in to work today, but I'm super sick.

Question: I'm in Florida to get Erin. As soon as I heard she wasn't coming back to Scranton, I jumped straight in my car and drove straight down till I hit the ocean. My heart is my map. Turns out, Tallahassee is about 200 miles inland, so I overshot a good amount. But still, not bad for a heart map right? [picking up dead fish] Oh, no. Thanks a lot, BP.
Answer: Not much we can do about this until he gets here.

Question: Can't you do something about this?
Answer: Sometimes the flowers arrange themselves, Jim.

Question: #NAME?
Answer: What is going on? And where's Andy? And what is going on?

Question: What is going on? And where's Andy? And what is going on?
Answer: Erin, you got a package.

Question: Where's the postage? I mean, there's no shipping label.
Answer: Did you wash your hands?

Question: Did you wash your hands?
Answer: Yes.

Question: Andy, what are you doing here? It's great to see you.
Answer: Uh, I am here to take you back to Scranton. Because I love you and I want to be with you.

Question: Where's the ring?
Answer: Hm?

Question: Hm?
Answer: Where's the ring, Lancelot?

Question: Where's the ring, Lancelot?
Answer: Uh, would you guys mind if we talked privately for a second? Sorry, Glenn.

Question: Uh, would you guys mind if we talked privately for a second? Sorry, Glenn.
Answer: Um, Andy... I am so happy to see you. But I'm not coming back with you.

Question: [whispering off screen] Why won't she go with him?
Answer: [whispering] I don't know. Maybe it's 'cause he's not that handsome.

Question: So what is going on? That does seem to be the question, doesn't it? [in American accent] Hey, this is messed up, bro. Who is this weird lady? [normal voice] I know. It's a lot. So, who knows what's going on? Anyone? You, yes. Wait, I am very good at intuiting names. Is it... chumbo?
Answer: I think it's a cross between Dumbo and Jumbo, with a hint of chubby. It's not a name.

Question: So no one can tell me what's going on. Well, let me illuminate things for you. We are getting to know each other. [in American accent] But why, m'lady? [in normal voice] Because I am your new manager.
Answer: Robert, is Nellie our new manager?

Question: Robert, is Nellie our new manager?
Answer: [laughs] This is an odd situation. But it's very interesting how it's playing out.

Question: We live in this world of routines and rhythms. Kevin ate someone's lunch. Phyllis has a new necklace. Who is this woman?
Answer: I came in here simply trying to get to know you, learn your names, maybe have someone teach me the company song. And what I got in return was nothing but disrespect. You leave me no choice but to get to know you in a more intimate way.

Question: Hot tub party?
Answer: Performance reviews.

Question: How can you give us performance reviews if you don't know us?
Answer: On first impressions, so I recommend smiling. It goes a long way with me.

Question: So, Andrew, how does your skinny brunette girlfriend Jessica feel about you visiting your ex-girlfriend?
Answer: Well, we're not really dating anymore, so... basically, I mean, I just have to cross a few Ts and dot a few I's, you know.

Question: You didn't even stop to pee? Gross.
Answer: Any luck?

Question: Any luck?
Answer: No. He just keeps letting all the calls go to voicemail.

Question: [on phone] Andy?
Answer: Jim?

Question: Jim?
Answer: Andy, where are you?

Question: Andy, where are you?
Answer: I- I'm home in bed. I've been in bed all day. I got the-- I got the serious poops, man.

Question: What? You're in Florida? Andy, Nellie Bertram's trying to take your job.
Answer: What do you mean, take my job?

Question: What do you mean, take my job?
Answer: Like, set up camp in your office and is calling herself the manager.

Question: Guys, we cannot do these performance reviews, okay? If we go into them, you're basically accepting Nellie as your manager, and trust me, you do not want her as your manager.
Answer: Trust you? The way Pam trusted you to provide for her so she wouldn't have to work?

Question: Trust you? The way Pam trusted you to provide for her so she wouldn't have to work?
Answer: I like working here.

Question: Dwight, should she be our manager?
Answer: I wouldn't let her manage a celery farm.

Question: And when was the last time Dwight and I agreed on anything ever? [clears throat]
Answer: All right. Let's get going. First up, it is the woman with the beautiful fingernails and the tiny feet, Phyllis.

Question: What?
Answer: Dwight, you carry this company on your massive shoulders. You are our Atlas, and for that do you not think you deserve a raise?

Question: Dwight, you carry this company on your massive shoulders. You are our Atlas, and for that do you not think you deserve a raise?
Answer: There's no limit to what I think I deserve.

Question: Then you accept it?
Answer: Five percent. No less.

Question: So Phyllis, now you know the rules of the game. Would you care to have a go? I'm fairly certain you're going to like it.
Answer: Phyllis.

Question: Really?
Answer: Oh, yeah. The way you conquered your fear and came in here, and now the way you sit there... all very impressive.

Question: Um... are you aware that Nellie is giving out raises?
Answer: I am not. Huh.

Question: Let me guess, you want one too? Take the family to Disneytown?
Answer: Land. World. Uh, it's not that I don't want a-- well, yes, I guess I'd take a raise. That's not what I'm saying. That's not-- sorry.

Question: Jim, would you prefer a nature metaphor or a sexual metaphor?
Answer: Oh, god, nature, please.

Question: And there are no rules to that game. That wasn't so perverted, now was it?
Answer: Was that it? No, that wasn't bad.

Question: Was that it? No, that wasn't bad.
Answer: My point is, there is one person in charge of every office in America, and that person is Charles Darwin. In the end, doesn't he decide who the manager is?

Question: My point is, there is one person in charge of every office in America, and that person is Charles Darwin. In the end, doesn't he decide who the manager is?
Answer: No. I would've said no.

Question: I mean, if we go in there and take these raises, what are we saying? That it's okay for someone to just take someone else's job? Shouldn't work like that.
Answer: No, you know what? Nellie's right. That is exactly how it should work. Darryl, this office is mine now.

Question: No, you know what? Nellie's right. That is exactly how it should work. Darryl, this office is mine now.
Answer: No.

Question: #NAME?
Answer: No, go ahead.

Question: Well, I was just going to say that, if I had my own fountain, it would be two frogs that are spitting into each other's mouth. It's just stupid. What were you going to say?
Answer: Andy, you broke my heart. Do you know what it feels like to be constantly rejected by you and to have to watch you date someone else?

Question: Andy, you broke my heart. Do you know what it feels like to be constantly rejected by you and to have to watch you date someone else?
Answer: You broke my heart too.

Question: Really? Okay, well, um, I like consistency in the manager's position, no weird silent coups. Stuff like that. I'm easy.
Answer: That's not really what you want. What you want is a good night's sleep, working mother of two.

Question: Whoa, that's kind of condescending. Would you say something like that to Jim?
Answer: Does Jim have to breastfeed? Did Jim carry around those babies for-- what is it? 12 months? Be honest, does Jim really get up in the night?

Question: Does Jim have to breastfeed? Did Jim carry around those babies for-- what is it? 12 months? Be honest, does Jim really get up in the night?
Answer: Well, I mean, the only reason he doesn't is because I'm breastfeeding, and Phillip doesn't like a bottle.

Question: You must be exhausted. Fancy a nap?
Answer: No.

Question: I think you're amazing. You know that, right? Go on, say it: 'I'm amazing.'
Answer: [drowsily] I'm amazing. [sighs]

Question: Really? 'cause you've been kind of a B to him all afternoon.
Answer: I was protecting you because I thought he was no good. But I can tell you really like him. And he's willing to lose his job for you, in this economy with Europe on the brink--

Question: Irene, what would you do without me?
Answer: We're not your concern, sweetheart. Besides, Glenn's going to sue Home Depot.

Question: Why?
Answer: He got his foreskin caught in some lawn furniture.

Question: Why are you so staunchly defending your friend, who has abandoned you? Wouldn't you rather come talk with me? Maybe definitely get a raise?
Answer: Yeah, that's the thing. I don't know if you can even give raises.

Question: Jim, have you ever heard of a character named Tinkerbell?
Answer: Yes.

Question: She dies! Now who here believes in Tinkerbell?
Answer: Let's see it. Show of hands.

Question: How?
Answer: Come on Jim, you're killing her!

Question: You don't have a toothbrush?
Answer: No.

Question: How do you not have a toothbrush?
Answer: I just... there's always one around.

Question: You just use whichever one is sitting there?
Answer: I always find one. Have you ever heard of buying a toothbrush?

Question: I always find one. Have you ever heard of buying a toothbrush?
Answer: Of course. I own my toothbrush.

Question: Hey Jim. Stanley's back from the hospital today. Can you sign his card?
Answer: Oh, great. [reads] 'Glad they didn't mix up your tonsillectomy with a moustachectomy.' Oh that's not good.

Question: Okay, Phyllis sits across from him every day. Phyllis, does he have a moustache or not?
Answer: Oh, I don't know. Now I think he doesn't.

Question: Okay, the man's worked here for 25 years. How can none of us picture his face?
Answer: Cause we come here to do our jobs. We don't stick our noses in other people's business.

Question: Okay, which one of these looks more right? [holds up drawing of Stanley with and without a moustache]
Answer: Neither of those looks like any person that has ever existed or been dreamt of in the history of human insanity. That said, the one on the left.

Question: [bell dings] Guys, that's the elevator. What if it's him?
Answer: Okay, quick. Who says moustache? [Pam, Oscar, Dwight, and Creed raise their hands]

Question: Okay, quick. Who says moustache? [Pam, Oscar, Dwight, and Creed raise their hands]
Answer: Yep.

Question: Who says no moustache? [Jim, Angela, and Phyllis raise their hands; Gabe enters, hiding Stanley's face]
Answer: [reveals Stanley's moustache] Ah! Ha ha ha!

Question: Is this a video conference you're having with 'Drake, featuring Swizz Beatz'?
Answer: Um, no, I was just, um, just having a cup of coffee, kind of warming up for the day.

Question: [laughing] Nellie, really, nine fifty?
Answer: Oh, here's what happened. Seven forty-six, my alarm clock goes off. I hear it. Whack the snooze.

Question: Well, yes, uh... there is the whole moving to Scranton nonsense. Thirty boxes arrived yesterday from England and two trunks from Florida. Then I have to move in to my apartment in this dreadful, God knows where it is backwater suburb of a suburb, and I mean, no offense but are there a lot of Irish people living around here?
Answer: [in unison] Yes.

Question: Who's a native?
Answer: Uh, excuse me, the tone here is getting quite hostile. I would appreciate it if you would keep that stuff on the basketball court. [everyone groans]

Question: What does that mean?
Answer: Okay, okay.

Question: If you'd let me finish- Or the squash court, or the Supreme Court. Hmm?
Answer: Nellie?

Question: Nellie?
Answer: Yes, Robert!

Question: Let's help her out, shall we? Go above and beyond today to show her some of that warm Scranton hospitality. Jim. Dwight. Take the day. Help Nellie move those boxes into her new place.
Answer: Why Jim?

Question: Why Jim?
Answer: The rest of you, let's throw a party at the end of the day to welcome the newest member of our little community.

Question: I'm sorry, we're throwing a party for someone because they're being horrible?
Answer: I'm sorry, we're taking work time to move someone's personal belongings into their new apartment.

Question: Why is she here?
Answer: [sings] Two crazy kids on the journey of life.

Question: I know, right?
Answer: She's always late, she's always rude...

Question: [whining] What?
Answer: I just need you to know-

Question: What is it? I didn't sleep well last night. [they laugh]
Answer: [lifting box] Ugh! Ow.

Question: Nellie, that reminds me. Do you want this chair in the bedroom? 'Cause to be honest, I don't think it's gonna fit through the door.
Answer: Don't listen to Jim. Have you ever seen him play Tetris? 'Oh, I think I'll just use this line horizontally. Oh, I had no idea what a gift this line is.'

Question: Don't listen to Jim. Have you ever seen him play Tetris? 'Oh, I think I'll just use this line horizontally. Oh, I had no idea what a gift this line is.'
Answer: That was one time-

Question: Oh, no. Really? Magic? No, no, no. Let's not go there. No, nothing is more repellant than magicians. Bunch of grown men waving wands, pulling bunnies out of body crevices. Magicians are repulsive. Next topic.
Answer: [cell phone rings] Excuse me, one second. Hi.

Question: Hey, what's up?
Answer: Ah, nothing, just hauling some cube with Dwight.

Question: What?

Answer: Oh, oh no, no. Look, it's alright. [Erin cries, Nelly comforts her] It really isn't your fault. No, no. Look, it's...you were so kind. And it isn't anything to do with you.

Question: Did you ever think that because you own the building, everyone in it, we're all kinda like your children?
Answer: You know there's a phrase about that in German. Bildenkinder. Used almost exclusively by childless landlords to console themselves. But now? I really understand it.

Question: You know there's a phrase about that in German. Bildenkinder. Used almost exclusively by childless landlords to console themselves. But now? I really understand it.
Answer: Well, now you have a bus full of real..bilden..kin..

Question: Oh! [Jim reenters bus through hatch] Hey! How'd it go?
Answer: It's pretty good actually.

Question: Yeah?
Answer: We bonded. We got to- [Dwight starts dropping into the bus on top of Jim]

Question: You feel OK now?
Answer: Oh, better than OK. [grabs Pam's shoulders] You know what honey? I'm gonna get you that rhubarb pie.

Question: Oh, better than OK. [grabs Pam's shoulders] You know what honey? I'm gonna get you that rhubarb pie.
Answer: Well, actually, rhubarb is-

Question: Oh, you signed it?
Answer: Yeah. Not as is, obviously. Made a couple changes. Added some sentences at the end. Trust me it needed it. [laughs] Well, yeah, whatever. So. [walks away]

Question: What?
Answer: I insult you! To your face!

Question: Then why don't you do something about it?
Answer: [laughs] Kevin, are you trying to get me to hit you? In the face with my pie?

Question: [laughs] Kevin, are you trying to get me to hit you? In the face with my pie?
Answer: You don't have the guts. You stupid, dumb, doo doo face! [Oscar pies Kevin] Yes!

Question: What?
Answer: This year I decided to really get into the spirit of Halloween.

Question: At first I drove myself crazy thinking about the things I should have done differently. I never should have played that joke on Erin. I never should have hollowed out this damn pumpkin in the first place. Then I realized that I was being silly. I mean the pumpkin should rot off of my head in a month or two. Right?
Answer: Hey guys.

Question: Pam, what are you?
Answer: I am Dr. Cinderella.

Question: Sure I am. I am... one of the Men in Black guys. [to Pam, under his breath] Can I have your sunglasses?
Answer: Jim, come on. I thought we were past this.

Question: So the sports marketing business that Jim told everyone about except for me?
Answer: There's a big investment lunch today, so I decided to skip the costume.

Question: Gettin' a lot of mileage out of this, aren't ya?
Answer: Yeah, well, get used to it, bud.

Question: A jitterbug. [giggles] You guys look great! Just a reminder. The party is right after lunch, so make sure you get all your work done before that or throw it out. Any questions?
Answer: The senator will be joining us later.

Question: Excellent. That reminds me, has anyone seen Treble? Anyone? I could have sworn I saw some Treble somewhere.
Answer: [singing]

Question: What lab did these little clones escape from?
Answer: My Cornell a capella group.

Question: You were in an a capella group?
Answer: You went to Cornell?

Question: You went to Cornell?
Answer: Yah! ah. Okay. Ha ha ha ha. But you have no idea how lucky you are because HCT is doing a set at our halloween party.

Question: Where you boys stayin? How does it work in the rooms? Do you get a privacy partition?
Answer: No. Nope. Nope nope nope. Stay away.

Question: You know what I just realized? They might actually call me up to solo on George Michael's Faith. That was one of my signature songs. Oh, man. That would be insane. I'm so not prepared.
Answer: Are you sure you're okay with me putting in this much money.

Question: [picking up spilled candy] Hello little pill. What do you do?
Answer: Dumatril is licensed to treat anxiety symptoms, such as panic attacks, excessive worrying, and fear. Translation: There's a madman in our midst.

Question: Okay I give up. What are you?
Answer: I'm sexy Toby.

Question: Something wrong Dwight?
Answer: Dumatril.

Question: Yes?
Answer: This is a pill that I found here in the office. But it's not for worms or eczema like any normal pill. It's not for any disorder of the body. [whispering] It's for a disorder of the mind.

Question: Okay, this is a pill that combats insanity, okay? Whoever is taking it is not only insane... [whispering] They are now off their meds.
Answer: Dwight, our co-workers' health issues are really none of our business so-

Question: Why are you trying so hard to bury this thing, huh? What's going on Nellie? Talk to me.
Answer: Hm?

Question: Hm?
Answer: It's my pill. I have an anxiety issue and I'm not ashamed of that, But I'm not loving the idea of Dwight having that information. I once saw him yell at Phyllis for sneezing wrong.

Question: Ruh duh duh da dudes! What's up?
Answer: [mumbled responses]

Question: I know that it's pathetic to re-live your college years, but cut me some slack, Okay? Because I was a freaking rock star in college. When I joined Here Comes Treble, that's when I became somebody. When I got the nickname 'Boner Champ,' that is when I became me.
Answer: You didn't come here to sit in a room, right? You came here for some intergenerational bro time. Well, now's your chance! I'm here. You got Qs; I got As.

Question: You didn't come here to sit in a room, right? You came here for some intergenerational bro time. Well, now's your chance! I'm here. You got Qs; I got As.
Answer: Did you say you've got AIDS?

Question: Did you say you've got AIDS?
Answer: No, I don't have AIDS. That's not what I said. Next question.

Question: You don't have any-- Any questions about the old days? [clears throat] You at least want to know why they call me Boner Champ?
Answer: I thought Broccoli Rob was the Boner Champ.

Question: I'm sorry, what?
Answer: I just thought Broccoli Rob was the Boner Champ.

Question: Did you maybe tell them that or...?
Answer: I just-- I just started yappin' about the old days, and I guess the wine coolers were flowing, and, you know, somehow things just got hinky.

Question: Could you just call them and tell them the truth? 'Cause I know it's really stupid, but it's also really, really, really important.
Answer: Will do. I love you, Andy.

Question: Oh, uh, is it too late to get in?
Answer: Oh Jim, I explained everything. So you're all set.

Question: Wow, well what level of investment were you thinking about?
Answer: We were thinking somewhere between five - ten thousand? I can do the full ten thousand. We should just - [blows air] - all in.

Question: We were thinking somewhere between five - ten thousand? I can do the full ten thousand. We should just - [blows air] - all in.
Answer: Welcome aboard!

Question: That makes sense to you, right? Or does it sound... crazy?
Answer: I can't really picture it. Can you... get it on there. Yeah. And maybe, get the cheeks.

Question: So this makes sense then. Or is it crazy?
Answer: Get under your chin first. Yeah.

Question: Is that where the nanobots like to come in?
Answer: Take it all the way up to your lip, yeah.

Question: Is that how they like to get in?
Answer: Yeah, that's crazy.

Question: Heard any good stories lately? Or new twists on old stories?
Answer: Yeah, I got a call from Broccoli Rob. I guess you really are the Boner Champ.

Question: Did he tell you how I got the name?
Answer: No.

Question: And I told Phyllis not to put it out, but she insisted. So, anyway... Hi! Oh, Oscar, remember my husband, the senator?
Answer: Senator Lipton, nice to see you.

Question: Wait a second, who designed this spread? The sweets and savories are all mixed together. This is mayhem!
Answer: So Oscar, you're a dinosaur.

Question: You know what? This is outrageous. I have to find Phyllis. You two talk, okay? Sorry babe.. Phyllis!
Answer: God, it's just so good to see you.

Question: All having this wonderful Halloween gathering. Excuse me, is that punch?
Answer: They didn't know about the snowman story, and when I told 'em, they were not impressed.

Question: What is with these turkeys?
Answer: Right?

Question: Right?
Answer: Hey! You better do 'Faith.' You get me?

Question: Hey! You better do 'Faith.' You get me?
Answer: We don't know it.

Question: Buts... are for pooping. Okay? Make it work. You have to or Andy will flip out... And make it a surprise, please. [to Pete] This isn't stupid.
Answer: What?

Question: What?
Answer: Hey.

Question: Are... are you me?
Answer: Yes.

Question: [laughing] It's funny right? [Toby starts to lean in for a kiss, then runs away]
Answer: All right. All right, just ...stay focused on the pill.

Question: You think I don't have anxiety? I have anxiety all the time. Every waking moment of my life is sheer torture. I have land disputes I've got to settle and idiot cousins to protect. And ne'er- do- well siblings to take care of. But I don't need some stupid pill to get me through all this.
Answer: Cool. Free upper.

Question: Gotcha! Yeah! Let's see ya get out of this web, huh?
Answer: Let me out!

Question: What?
Answer: Get her out.

Question: Oh Dwight, look, its just a pill, all right? It's for anxiety. I take it every day. And it makes me feel better. And maybe it could help you too.
Answer: Hey, how'd it go?

Question: Hey, how'd it go?
Answer: Oh man, it was great. They were great.

Question: Did you end up investing?
Answer: I did, yeah.

Question: How much?
Answer: Uh, man, by the end I guess it was about... ten...

Question: About ten?
Answer: Ten. It was the full ten.

Question: What is it?
Answer: Did everybody end up investing ten thousand?

Question: Did everybody end up investing ten thousand?
Answer: Um, oh man, I don't actually know.

Question: What?
Answer: They weren't really talking that much about money. They just said, We're good with investing and then I...and I...

Question: They said they were done with the investing and then you volunteered ten thousand dollars?
Answer: No, no, I had to. Look, I needed to look like a team player, Pam.

Question: So you invested ten thousand dollars to look like a team player?
Answer: You weren't there.

Question: Wait! Wait. Hold on. Where's the band? 'Cause there's just no way you guys are making this magic with just your mouths.
Answer: Yeah.  That's what she said.

Question: What, am I overdoing it? No. No.
Answer: [singing]

Question: Who?
Answer: It's Mr. Andy Bernard!

Question: Whoa! Whoa! What the hell is Broccoli Rob doing here?
Answer: She said you wanted to hear 'Faith'. That's Broccoli Rob's signature song.

Question: Wha...?
Answer: The more I hear about all this a capella drama, the more I think it's kind of pathetic. But when you're with someone, you put up with the stuff that makes you lose respect for them, and that is love.

Question: Are you okay?
Answer: [on screen] He's still mad.

Question: You thought I wanted to sit in the audience like some slutty Treb rat? A man's signature solo is his for life, okay? That's group policy and you know it.
Answer: Look, it's not my fault that I still live near campus, and it's my duty as an alum to be friendly to the young guys., and stop in two, three times a week.

Question: My pipes are primo, Champ. Why don't you ask Trey Anastasio about my pipes?
Answer: I knew you would go there, you son of a bitch!

Question: Oh you have to Jim? You literally have to?
Answer: Uh...

Question: No I'm just, I'm saying, what would happen if they didn't sing it? Would they go to jail? Would they be shot?
Answer: Okay. We'll, just forget it.

Question: It turns out, that Pam? Really, really hates 'Monster Mash.' I mean like, never bring that song up in front of her. Even though Jim was making great points, like, in favor of the song, Pam was like, No! Hate it! Stupid!
Answer: This is all so silly right? What am I gonna do? Move back to Cornell?

Question: This is all so silly right? What am I gonna do? Move back to Cornell?
Answer: [laughing] Yeah.

Question: I mean, what if we did that? Like we got jobs and we were happy all the time?
Answer: Oh well, Andy, we're not moving to Cornell.

Question: It could totally work though. I don't know why we wouldn't. Oh my god are we doing this?
Answer: Oy. Andy, what's going on?

Question: Oy. Andy, what's going on?
Answer: If I am not Boner Champ, I don't know who I am.

Question: Which one? Mose or the real Mose?
Answer: The real Mose.

Question: [on phone] Mom, I had this really charitable idea to set up this scholarship for a capella kids at Cornell and just need to wire some money over there. [pause] What?
Answer: What's wrong?

Question: What's wrong?
Answer: My parents are broke.

Question: [to camera crew] Can you guys come with me for a minute?
Answer: I know you saw me with the Senator. I think I'm in love, possibly for the first time. So yes, Senator Lipton and I are having an affair.  I hope that I can count on your sensitivity, maturity and discretion. [turns to see Kevin has overheard him]...Why?

Question: I know you saw me with the Senator. I think I'm in love, possibly for the first time. So yes, Senator Lipton and I are having an affair.  I hope that I can count on your sensitivity, maturity and discretion. [turns to see Kevin has overheard him]...Why?
Answer: Alright, good. Yeah. Just sell it and get the best price you can, okay?

Question: Alright, good. Yeah. Just sell it and get the best price you can, okay?
Answer: Or we can hope for a holiday rally?

Question: Or we can hope for a holiday rally?
Answer: White, I'm not a day trader, I'm just a first responder in a disaster.

Question: Right?
Answer: Are the 'Nard's hurting? Yeah, you bet. Got kicked pretty hard. Family shattered, super sad. But, I'm kinda crushing it in the damage control department. So, that's cool. I wish my dad could see me now. Of course he caused this whole mess, so, [bleep] him.

Question: Are the 'Nard's hurting? Yeah, you bet. Got kicked pretty hard. Family shattered, super sad. But, I'm kinda crushing it in the damage control department. So, that's cool. I wish my dad could see me now. Of course he caused this whole mess, so, [bleep] him.
Answer: Kevin, listen to me. I'm in love with the Senator. And I need time to sort this out in a responsible matter so I need your help in keeping it a secret because this means the world to me. Ok?

Question: Kevin, listen to me. I'm in love with the Senator. And I need time to sort this out in a responsible matter so I need your help in keeping it a secret because this means the world to me. Ok?
Answer: That's beautiful. No, I totally get that.

Question: Can you do this, Kevin?
Answer: I really want to. Whatever happens, always remember that.

Question: [On phone] Oh, great! Yeah, um, I'll get right back to you. [hangs up] Hey guys! Anyone ever heard of Iris Black on the radio?
Answer: Yeah, she hosts the Dr. Laura Show.

Question: Nope, that's Dr. Laura. Well, her show Biz Whiz wants someone from Dunder Mifflin to come on the air today. Does anybody feel particularly passionate about local business issues? [Dwight raises hand]
Answer: I do! I do. I do. I do. I do.

Question: The media can make you famous. And do you have any idea how easy it is to sell something when you're famous? [Pretends to be on phone] 'Uh, yeah wow. 10 reams of 40 pound bond at only $690 after discount? Um, whatever you say, Brad Pitt.' It's that easy.
Answer: Hey, so that good looking single brother of yours? Heard he's on a downward spiral with booze.

Question: Hey, so that good looking single brother of yours? Heard he's on a downward spiral with booze.
Answer: Yeah. He's in rehab actually.

Question: Which place? The one right near Philly? I could be there in an hour.
Answer: No, it's in New Mexico.

Question: Oh...So..- how are you holding up?
Answer: We're done Meredith.

Question: ...In a bitter battle..Hey, hey! Stop questioning my methods, OK? I was chosen for this task for a very good reason.
Answer: No, you chose yourself.

Question: Totally, except it is a no go. This boat was the heart and soul of the family. So...what else we got? Non-boat ideas. [Oscar looks outside conference room at Kevin and Angela at the copier]
Answer: What happened?

Question: What happened?
Answer: Jammed. This day couldn't get worse. [Kevin laughs]

Question: What does that mean?
Answer: Kevin!

Question: Alright, what's the grand total? Did we make our nut?
Answer: If we sell everything but the boat, your mom should be set for about six months.

Question: Don't you guys have that place where you used to spend your summers and have all those memories?
Answer: I worked at a Jiffy Lube.

Question: See? I bet you wouldn't sell that Jiffy Lube for all the money in the world. Would you Darryl?
Answer: I would if I owned it and I went broke.

Question: Yes the boat means everything to my family, but we need the money. Got the memories, don't need the boat. Can't cry about it.  What are you gonna do? Cry about it? [chokes up] Excuse me.
Answer: [On phone] Oh, OK. No problem. Thanks. Hey guys, WPTU called.  The interview's off. They're opening a new cupcake store at the Steamtown Mall and Iris wants to cover that, so...

Question: Yes. He is. And you know what? We cannot let that happen.
Answer: Fax?

Question: Fax?
Answer: Oh yeah, just. Watermelon teeth. This isn't how I would cheer up just anyone. But, it's a girlfriend's job to know her man and I know Andy. [laughs] He's seriously juvenile.

Question: Cool. He's like 40 though, right?
Answer: Oh no, he couldn't be more than late thirty's. Tops.

Question: Uh, did you need something?
Answer: Oh, I just need your signature on this.

Question: Kevin, we're out of 11-38 forms. Did you order more?
Answer: I... did not.

Question: [laughing in Oscar's direction] Oh really, Angela? That's interesting. Cause I do think that I could surprise you. I think that I could surprise you..oh! [Oscar makes sound trying to get him to shut up] I have to go to the bathroom!
Answer: That doesn't surprise me.

Question: Ok, who wants to go for a super fun lunch with a super fun girlfriend?
Answer: Look, it's not that I don't want-

Question: All I ever wanted to do was sail the damn thing. But dad wouldn't let me. Said 'You can't be a skipper until you're a man.' You know, I'd reach for the wheel and he'd smack my hand away. Well guess what? Now I'm the man of the family and... we're selling the damn thing. So I'm never gonna have the chance.
Answer: Well, when does the boat leave, exactly?

Question: Well, when does the boat leave, exactly?
Answer: Tonight.

Question: Seriously?
Answer: Of course, seriously. Get your coat on.

Question: [As Iris] So the day-to-day operations are entirely under your command?
Answer: Entirely is the perfect way to describe it, Iris.

Question: Uh, excuse me. [reading card held up by Jim] I'm being told by my sound engineer, Steve that uh there is a clinking sound coming from your end. Does your shirt have buttons?
Answer: Yes..?

Question: Yes..?
Answer: [Jim mimes taking shirt off] I'm so sorry we're going to have to ask you to remove the shirt all together.

Question: Are you by any chance wearing pants with a metallic zipper?
Answer: The Senator is exhausted. This campaign is wearing him out.

Question: What?
Answer: Please, stop.

Question: [pantless] OK, how is my voice now?
Answer: I'm getting the all clear from Steve, so Mr. Shrute, what is your response to the consumer product safety commission that says Dunder Mifflin paper is toxic?

Question: I'm getting the all clear from Steve, so Mr. Shrute, what is your response to the consumer product safety commission that says Dunder Mifflin paper is toxic?
Answer: [holding hand over phone] This is gotcha journalism. You know what? They're not gonna gotch me.

Question: [holding hand over phone] This is gotcha journalism. You know what? They're not gonna gotch me.
Answer: [looking at folder he brought Toby]It's clearly not an accounting mistake.

Question: Let's get straight to the point. Is your paper toxic?
Answer: No the paper's not toxic.

Question: What the heck is going on?! The stock prices are plummeting! Are you gonna take control of the message or do I have to send in someone who understands the media?!
Answer: Get out of here moron! [Jim leaves]

Question: Excuse me, Mr. Dwight, who are you talking to?
Answer: uhhhh....no one.

Question: Did you just call Ms. Mick a moron?
Answer: No, everything's fine.

Question: Are you insulting my guests?
Answer: [chokes up]

Question: [on phone] Yeah, I will be right there. Hey Oscar, what if I'm getting a promotion?
Answer: I hope that's it, Kevin.

Question: Guys? Excuse me. Um, a quick word, please just..
Answer: Oscar, we're in the middle of talking.

Question: What are you doing?
Answer: Those figures I gave you? They're false.

Question: Those figures I gave you? They're false.
Answer: How?

Question: How?
Answer: I was mad at Kevin, we had a fight and I acted vindictively.

Question: What are you talking about? I just did this now.
Answer: A few years ago, when I was on the jury of the Scranton Strangler..

Question: Tough? I put an innocent man on death row.
Answer: The fallout from this morning's revelation continues to mount, since Mr. Dwight Shrute began speaking, Dunder Mifflin share prices fell 73%.  Mr. Shrute, shareholders demand accountability from corporate leadership. Can we announce your resignation at this time?

Question: The fallout from this morning's revelation continues to mount, since Mr. Dwight Shrute began speaking, Dunder Mifflin share prices fell 73%.  Mr. Shrute, shareholders demand accountability from corporate leadership. Can we announce your resignation at this time?
Answer: My resignation? What are you talking about? No! I was just following orders! Listen, the person responsible for this catastrophe is the CEO and chairman, David Wallace!

Question: My resignation? What are you talking about? No! I was just following orders! Listen, the person responsible for this catastrophe is the CEO and chairman, David Wallace!
Answer: That's yours?

Question: That's yours?
Answer: That's the family boat!

Question: Right?
Answer: I thought it was gonna be tiny. Oh my gosh it's beautiful. So this is how your family came to America.

Question: Sorry?
Answer: Trying to rig a boat here.  I don't know how to do that when you're standing in the way.

Question: Geez, a little bit. [to boat] How you doing old buddy? Missed you.
Answer: What does that one do?

Question: What does that one do?
Answer: It raises the main sail. That was my job when we went sailing.

Question: Really?
Answer: Yeah.

Question: Oh, it's OK. My girlfriend and I were actually gonna take her for a little spin and a picnic before you guys head out tonight. You know what? Get some dinner on me.
Answer: Nope. Can't do that.

Question: You know what? Chill, ok? I own the boat. Not gonna sue myself. Alright, so just- [Raises sail, guys slaps hand again] wow.
Answer: I can smack you all day if you keep touching what you're not supposed to touch.

Question: Right?
Answer: Yeah.

Question: What?
Answer: I'm taking it over from here.

Question: Fine. Good. Keep it. Just leave the supplies, I paid for those. But how much for that cool fisherman sweater?
Answer: For those just joining us, terror in Greenwich.  Where police have surrounded the house of Dunder Mifflin CEO David Wallace. Wallace is said to be despondent over the company's stock plummet and is taking a mailman hostage. On the line, we have chief of Greenwich Police, Mr. Bill Jackson [points to Jim].

Question: Do you even know what you're doing?
Answer: Yeah. Yeah I know how to hoist the mail sail, I know to...I, I, these buttons control boat pumps and stuff. I also know where the booze stash is. So, hello.  [Opens door, Andy's brother is passed out inside] Walt?

Question: Yeah. Yeah I know how to hoist the mail sail, I know to...I, I, these buttons control boat pumps and stuff. I also know where the booze stash is. So, hello.  [Opens door, Andy's brother is passed out inside] Walt?
Answer: Oh god, thank goodness you're here. I was having a little trouble with this door. Yesterday. I um, I think it was yesterday.

Question: Yeah, uh, I just, I figured I'd get that first relapse out of the way. God, what's happened to our family? Everything is so messed up! How did you even know I was in here?
Answer: I didn't.  I, I just came to say goodbye to the boat.  But I've decided to sail it to Bermuda.

Question: [On phone] Hello?
Answer: David, is that you?

Question: David, is that you?
Answer: Dwight?

Question: Dwight?
Answer: Oh, thank god. Oh, thank god. Are you ok? Is everyone ok?

Question: Oh, thank god. Oh, thank god. Are you ok? Is everyone ok?
Answer: Yeah? Are you ok?

Question: Yeah? Are you ok?
Answer: Oh, I'm OK.  I just want you to know that I believe in you. I really do. And I believe in your ability to make the right choices. I always have, David.

Question: You're welcome, sir. But David, listen to me carefully. I'm gonna need you to let the mailman go. Ok?
Answer: Dwight?

Question: Dwight?
Answer: Walk out of the house...

Question: What?
Answer: ...with your hands on top of your head, everything is going to be fine. Dunder Mifflin will be in good hands while you're away in prison.

Question: [enters main office, group claps] Wait a minute, you guys? You heard?
Answer: Shrute! Shrute! Shrute!Shrute! Shrute! Shrute! Shrute! Shrute!

Question: Why on earth would you think you were getting a promotion?
Answer: You know what Angela? I- Oh my god. [Senator enters]

Question: You know what Angela? I- Oh my god. [Senator enters]
Answer: Honey! What are you doing here?

Question: Honey! What are you doing here?
Answer: I just had a little intuition that someone I loved needed a little bit of attention today. Oscar, you're looking very healthy. Getting lots of vigorous exercise? [touches Oscar's shoulder. Oscar jumps away quickly]

Question: I just had a little intuition that someone I loved needed a little bit of attention today. Oscar, you're looking very healthy. Getting lots of vigorous exercise? [touches Oscar's shoulder. Oscar jumps away quickly]
Answer: No.

Question: Oscar? What is going on? What was that?
Answer: What was that? I'm sorry, I didn't mean any offense. I was just trying to be friendly.

Question: What was that? I'm sorry, I didn't mean any offense. I was just trying to be friendly.
Answer: You know what? I'm sorry. I overreacted. Because I'm stressed out. Why am I stressed out? Who's not stressed out? Who's not stressed out? Who-

Question: You know what? I'm sorry. I overreacted. Because I'm stressed out. Why am I stressed out? Who's not stressed out? Who's not stressed out? Who-
Answer: Come on Oscar, we're not just gonna sit here and ignore the obvious. Senator Lipton has a big election next week. We all need to give him our support. [claps, group joins]

Question: Alright guys, cast us off. Walt, all aboard! Erin, this is because of you.  Do you realize that? You're the best ever!
Answer: [Standing on dock] Oh, you know. Just being a good girlfriend.

Question: [pulling away from dock] Good? Come on. Above and beyond. World's Greatest. You did this! Dammit I'm happy!
Answer: Yes, I am very pleased I did help Andy. Would I have gone with him if he'd asked me? On his sailboat cruise to the Caribbean? Yes. I think it would have been really fun and romantic.

Question: Yes, I am very pleased I did help Andy. Would I have gone with him if he'd asked me? On his sailboat cruise to the Caribbean? Yes. I think it would have been really fun and romantic.
Answer: [waving from boat] I'll see you in three weeks!

Question: Yeah, no problem. How was it?
Answer: Fine.

Question: Hey, some buddies of mine are going to Poor Richard's for beers and pool, you wanna come? I can't promise you too much, but uh, you might get to meet my friend flipper.
Answer: Does he have a flipper?

Question: Does he have a flipper?
Answer: Oh. Nope. It's not that, he uh, uh he flipped a table one time when he was drunk.

Question: [on computer screen] Ah, what else? I've seen Dirty Dancing like, ten times.  Breaks my heart every time, you know?
Answer: Whoa!

Question: Don't you have any sunblock?
Answer: No, Walter J has been hoarding it. You want to worry about a part of my body, worry about my eyes.  They're like two flaming meatballs in my skull.

Question: What else can I show you? Oh, damn it!
Answer: Oh, Andy, was.. was that your drinking water?

Question: [on the phone] Directory? Movie Star department. Back. Directory.

Answer: Hey, wait, wait, how'how are we doing this?

Question: [Snorts and grunts] I can't hear what you said. [snorting, grunting] You got your slop? [Squeals]

Question: What?
Answer: Relax.

Question: That's great. So what you're gonna do then is come over here to the eye washing station and then just kinda flush out your eyes.  You know, get the chemicals out. Alright?

Question: So?
Answer: I can't squirt stuff in my eyeball.  I've never even used an eye dropper.

Question: Oh. Is she a gambler?
Answer: In a way.  But not in a stand up and cheer kind of way, like the song.

Question: What's the hold up here?
Answer: The actor's crying.

Question: Andy Bernard can't squirt water in his eye and act like it doesn't freak him out. But you know who can? Older Male Lab Assistant Number One.

Question: Do you believe in me?
Answer: I believe I want to go home.

Question: Hey that's work, hold on. Hey Wade, did Cole Hamels call back or what? Great. Good.

Answer: I guess I will swallow my truth.

Question: Are you guys high? Because if so, to speak my truth, I would appreciate the sacrifice of including me in some hits off your kind buds.
Answer: We're not high.

Question: [fake throws and drops plane] Oh! Oh man! It slipped out of my hand, what a whiff. Ah, how'd that happen? God. [Angela smiles]
Answer: We want you to win. Dwight told me about your situation. It's such a pity. Use the money wisely. [Angela looks disgusted]

Question: Two grand huh? I know a guy who can turn that into eight hundred dollars. And it's me.
Answer: [To Esther] Well, I guess you needed the money more than me huh? Use it wisely.

Question: [To Esther] Well, I guess you needed the money more than me huh? Use it wisely.
Answer: I was disappointed in Dwight today. He showed a weakness that was unbecoming. Even if he did do it for me. I don't need pity and I don't need charity. I have my dignity and that's enough. And as long as I have that, I'll be ok.

Question: I know this was really weird, and it was really hard. But I think we're making progress. So I'm really sorry that I have to go but let's keep at this. Ok?
Answer: Ok. [intense moment where Jim leaves and Pam seems conflicted.  She notices his umbrella and runs out to follow him]

Question: Hey. Which tie makes me look like a guy who likes sofas? My agent's putting me up for a furniture commercial.
Answer: Ah, definitely blue.

Question: Totally, right? So, Big Tuna, what's up? Back in the small pond?

Question: Tell me about it, you know? I've been trying to act and manage this branch. Half the time I don't know if I'm wearing my stage makeup or my work makeup.
Answer: Huh. Well, you know, you can't have everything so you gotta ask yourself what makes you the happiest. You just go all in for what's most important. That's my new thing.

Question: [noticing Angela looking very unkempt] Is everything ok?
Answer: No. Everything is not okay. The county took my cats.

Question: Wait, all of them?
Answer: Two sacks' worth. Apparently my apartment complex has rules about how many pets are too many for a studio. And while I was out picking Phillip up from daycare, they came. They came into my house.

Question: Attention, everyone. May I have your attention? There are four new deadly weapons in this office. [kicking and punching] Basher, Thrasher, Crasher and'
Answer: Smasher!

Question: Smasher? No, where'd you get that? Fireball. This morning after hours of combat with some of the city's best teenagers I earned my black belt in Goju Ryu martial arts.
Answer: I had to find a new dojo after sensei Ira and I parted ways. My new sensei, sensei Billy, thought I had more than enough training to take the test. Turns out, sensei Ira was a bit of a shyster. Sensei Billy says most students don't spend $150,000 over 20 years to get their black belt.

Question: Hey, Erin. Is Andy in?
Answer: Oh, is Andy in? Sorry, I thought you said 'is Indian' and was like, 'Is Indian what?' Is Indian food good? Is Indian jewelry pretty? Is Indian hair an expensive kind of wig? Yes, to all three, by the way.

Question: Oh, is Andy in? Sorry, I thought you said 'is Indian' and was like, 'Is Indian what?' Is Indian food good? Is Indian jewelry pretty? Is Indian hair an expensive kind of wig? Yes, to all three, by the way.
Answer: Lately, I've been having a lot of trouble keeping track of Andy's calendar. His student film audition schedule is crazy hectic.

Question: Hey, Andy. Can we go in your office and talk?
Answer: Yeah.

Question: So you think you've been too focused on your job?
Answer: At my last head shot sitting, I was so distracted wondering what I was missing at work that I came across totally manic. And I was going for zany.

Question: So you'you want to quit Dunder Mifflin to pursue acting?
Answer: Well, no, actually. I see no reason to limit myself to just acting. I am pursuing fame of any kind. Could be singing, could be dancing. I don't'it just' I owe it to myself and my future fans.

Question: There's probably no way I can talk you into staying at this point, can I?
Answer: Nope. I have made up my mind. I'm really sorry.

Question: I think just anybody could be a star. My postman, the night janitor here, but Andy? No, definitely not. Charisma black hole.
Answer: Oh, Clark. I'm actually here today. Surprise! So I was wondering if I could maybe have my desk back.

Question: Right. Yeah. But, you know, I've actually been working pretty hard here on a daily basis. So, I kind of feel like I've earned this. I mean, you know?
Answer: You totally have. You have earned this. But maybe I could be with my wife. Kind of the whole reason that I'm here.

Question: All right, Jim, look, I just got made junior salesman. Right? And'and Wallace is here today. And I don't him to just think of me as a customer service rep that sits in the annex. I mean, you can get that, right? Right? And what do you need more face time with Wallace for? You trying to get a second second job here?
Answer: it's okay. You can sit in the annex.

Question: What?
Answer: I'll come visit you.

Question: I wasn't fired. What are you talking about? I'm fired up, yes. Guys, I'm'I'm leaving to pursue my lifelong dream of being famous.
Answer: Oh, Andy.

Question: Hey, how am I doing as your desk mate, by the way? You probably miss Clark.
Answer: Yeah, a little bit.

Question: I'm 38, Darryl, how much slower should I go?
Answer: Show business is cold. Let's say you get a job, which you probably won't. They're not gonna cut you any slack. You're meant for a job with lots and lots of slack.

Question: Andy's from the generation that thinks they should all be famous. What happened to the generation that knew you shut up, did your work, and died quietly from a heart attack?
Answer: Could Andy make it as an entertainer? I don't know. You know who's really funny? This bird, in the park, that can't fly right. I'd pay to see him. But I don't have to cause the park is free!

Question: Could Andy make it as an entertainer? I don't know. You know who's really funny? This bird, in the park, that can't fly right. I'd pay to see him. But I don't have to cause the park is free!
Answer: I will now perform the ceremonial changing of the belts.

Question: Hold it'Take a step back. Take a step back. [they bow, then Dwight thrusts again] Okay, okay. I can't'I can't do this if you're gonna be thrusting like that, okay? I think we're gonna have to cut this off.

Question: Thanks. I will now perform my final kata forms. You're gonna watch me right?

Question: Watching?
Answer: I'm watching.

Question: Watch this part, okay?

Question: Sensei, do you generally do house calls like this?

Question: He said that? He's an odd guy, isn't he?

Question: Well, I gotta tell you, Jim, a lot of guys in my circle? They wouldn't even change their golf schedule to shore up their marriage let alone their professional goals.
Answer: Dude, there is no way that Jim is just back here to hang out with Pam.

Answer: Yeah. Yeah, it's hot. The music is awesome. And the tacos are'for real.

Question: What for? We haven't even gotten bread yet. Does anyone wanna split a twice baked potato? [to the dancing stripper] Do you have those? Those aren't deep fried, right?

Question: That was interesting. [creaking sound] What was that?

Question: Okay. [opens door] It's just the wind, see? Nothing.

Question: What's happening?

Question: Oh, it's the girls. Hey Pam. What? Angela's been kidnapped! Phyllis left the door open and some freak came and grabbed her and fled.

Question: What is that?
Answer: A ceremonial bridal kidnapping. He will take the bride and hide her at a local pub and when I find the place, I have to buy everyone drinks. Ah, all right! Oh Mose.

Question: Wait a minute. You said the tradition is for the groom is search for her and it ends at a pub. So how about the last pub you'd ever set foot in in this town?

Question: Right. Which one is that?
Answer: Mm, hey driver. Why don't you take us to 3030 Adams?

Question: Mm, hey driver. Why don't you take us to 3030 Adams?

Answer: It's like seeing a documentary about how your food is made. It's kinda disgusting. You learn a lot, but I didn't wanna know any of it.

Question: Well, I mean, How do you pay back someone for something like that? But, uh, I don't know. I'm working on something.
Answer: She pays me back every day just by being my wife so that's fine.

Question: [pause] I'm sorry. Is there a question?
Answer: Uh, no.

Answer: Oh, um, well, you know, I' I just' I just think I would rather keep that private. You know, if you'd been filmed for nine years of your life, there'd be some things that you just wanna keep to yourself.

Question: I hear ya. What did it say?
Answer: We're gonna move on. Next question please.

Question: Do you find that your life feels pointless now that nobody's actually filming you anymore?
Answer: Yes.

Question: I wanna know how everyone felt they were portrayed. Was it accurate?
Answer: I got a beef with that. Um, for the first seven years, I was getting my PhD in School Psychology and they didn't show it. Yes, I was getting hammered but, hey, it was college.

Question: I have a question for Jim and Pam. Everyone watching sees how much you love each other and how you're soul mates. So, Pam, how could you doubt that when Jim moved to Philadelphia?
Answer: Um, you know what, I actually didn't handle that move, uh, very gracefully. From not communicating to being a little selfish.

Question: Listen, um' I was scared, you know? I loved what I had, and I didn't want to risk it. And I think that maybe I did doubt him a little too. Which was wrong because he's shown me time and again. But when the documentary started airing, people on the street told me that I had this fairy-tale romance. But there were a lot of times last year where it did not feel like a fairy tale. But then it got deeper, and it got stronger and now it's better than a fairy tale. It's like a long book that you never want to end.  And you're fine with that because you just never, ever wanna leave it.
Answer: Like Harry Potter.

Question: Really?
Answer: Yes. Um, the thing I found most compelling about the documentary was your search for your birth mother.

Question: So my question is, um, do' don't you hate her? I mean, I would just imagine that you were so angry at her that you would hate her.
Answer: Maybe sometimes. But not like 'hate' hate. More just like, 'Mom, I hate you!' And then she would say 'go to your room, young lady.' And I'd stamp my foot and run upstairs and I have a room, which is really cool. And then we'd just have dinner together. But I don't know. I'd have to meet her. Thanks.

Question: Yes?
Answer: Um'Oh, Erin..

Answer: Erin' Same question but about your dad? [they hug]

Question: Erin' Same question but about your dad? [they hug]
Answer: Well, this feels like a good place to stop. Let's thank all of our wonderful panelists for being here on this wonderful panel today.  [audience claps] Next week at the Scranton Cultural Center don't forget, Irish Step Dancing semifinals. Winning team to Mid-Atlantic. [applause and scattering cheers]

Question: Actually, could you go inside? I'm feeling a little dehydrated. I could really use a little break, have some water.

Question: Are you sure you don't wanna go in?
Answer: Ravi, just do it. That baby is burning up. Isn't this, like what you live for? Just go. Go.

Question: Ravi, just do it. That baby is burning up. Isn't this, like what you live for? Just go. Go.

Question: What's going on?

Question: [sighs] [whispering] Why are you still here?
Answer: [whispering] I'm so sorry. They were an hour late.

Question: No, really, what's going on?
Answer: Okay, Okay. Um' so' this past year has been really great, and you've been great and I just' I know that you had to make this choice and you had to give something up for me. But I never want you to have to give up anything. I just thought if I could get us an offer then there wouldn't be anything standing in our way and I could come to you with this big Jim gesture' and show you all at once just how much I love you and how much I really do believe in your future.

Question: I mean, you were gonna do this without me?
Answer: Well, you' you bought the house without telling me, so I thought I could sell it without telling you.

Question: Oh' okay. Where would we go?
Answer: Austin? Maybe.

Question: Austin? Maybe.
Answer: I promise you, you don't have to do this for me.

Question: You wanna do this?
Answer: I wanna do this.

Question: You really want to do this?
Answer: I really want to do this!

Question: What? All right!
Answer: We're so excited.

Question: Uh, could I please have your attention? And then someone spray painted a bunch of butts on it and I had to start from the beginning. But it all worked out for the best because I think that I've painted the perfect thing which is the history of us. All of us. And this is for you Jim. [applause] And go ahead! [drape drops and everyone cheers]
Answer: Everyone, Let's take our picture in front of the mural. Oh, um, I just'I kind of meant just everybody from the office.

Answer: Oh, the honeymoon can wait till tomorrow. We wanted to hang out with you guys. I mean, when are we all going to be here together again?

Question: Oh, the honeymoon can wait till tomorrow. We wanted to hang out with you guys. I mean, when are we all going to be here together again?
Answer: Aww, J, P and D. The Three Amigos. Ah, it warms my heart. Hey, what do you say, when I get back from out honeymoon, the three of us have a conference room meeting just for fun? [pause] What is that meaningful look?

Question: Aww, J, P and D. The Three Amigos. Ah, it warms my heart. Hey, what do you say, when I get back from out honeymoon, the three of us have a conference room meeting just for fun? [pause] What is that meaningful look?
Answer: You know what? Maybe we should talk.

Answer: Hey, come here. You guys need to see this.

Question: What is it?
Answer: [on the computer] You're probably sitting there wondering what will be your mark. What will you be known for? It might surprise you to learn...

Question: [on the computer] You're probably sitting there wondering what will be your mark. What will you be known for? It might surprise you to learn...
Answer: I finally feel ready. Athlead is growing'

Question: Woah. Right. For what, the art? The music? The incredible nightlife? No thank you. But if you're ever in the area, you'll always have a place to stay'in my barn.
Answer: There it is.

Question: Do I get along with my co-workers? Well, first of all, I don't have co-workers anymore, I have subordinates. So' have I gotten along with my subordinates? Let's see. Angela Schrute, my former accountant is now my wife. My top salesman, Jim Halpert was best man at my wedding and office administrator Pamela Beesley Halpert is my best friend. So'yes. I'd say I have gotten along with my subordinates.
Answer: [on computer] You might feel sorry for me but I actually feel sorry for you. Because you're about to leave Cornell. So say it with me: [all]: Oh, I can so just sit here and cry.

Question: Do you even have a mattress?
Answer: No, but I still have my medal from that.

Question: Why do you say that?
Answer: [sniffles] It's just that I'm so emotional.

Question: How did you do it? How did you capture what it was really like? How we felt and how made each other laugh and how we got through the day? How did you do it? Also, how do cameras work?
Answer: Everyday when I came into work, all I wanted to do was leave. So why in the world does it feel so hard to leave right now?

Question: Everyday when I came into work, all I wanted to do was leave. So why in the world does it feel so hard to leave right now?
Answer: It all seems so very arbitrary. I applied for a job at this company because they were hiring. I took a desk at the back because it was empty. But'[chuckles] no matter how you get there or where you end up, human beings have this miraculous gift to make that place home. [standing with two cops] Let's do this.

Answer: Dummy
